column2: Stocks were ragged at the close yesterday. Rails were sharply lower and industrials moderately higher, with the resuit that The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks eased 0.06 point to 325.52.
BANGALORE, India, Dec. 4-- This is the sixth day of the Chinese Communists' tour of India, and the following conclusion may now be drawn: It was a lot more fun traveling with the Russians.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 (AP)-- Dave Gorman, the leading rider at Pimlico, gained his second victory of the day and his twenty-third of the meeting in the Kent County Purse today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4--Both the Soviet Union and its puppet government in Hungary have rejected Yugoslav demands for the return to Budapest of former Premier Imre Nagy.
ALBANY, Dec. 4--The New York Central's in-and-out West Shore Line was back in court today, but nothing decisive happened.
The money market for financing industrial real estate yesterday was termed "tight at this particular time."

EN ROUTE TO FRANCE, Dec. 4 --The disastrous consequences of Anglo-French intervention in the Middle East make almost inevitable a new development of considerable strategic importance--creation of another atomic military power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Two of the largest unions in the country decided today to pool their strength in the aircraft and guided missile industries. These industries employ nearly 1,000,000 workers.
Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan yesterday signed a Taft-Hartley Law injunction barring a strike by East and Gulf Coast longshoremen until Feb. 12. It contained a novel proviso.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The State Department said today it had "under consideration" Dr. German Ornes Coiscu's application for a visa to re-enter the United States from Cuba.
The Board of Education is planning to establish a full-time school for adults.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 4--A projected trans-Israel oil pipeline, as an alternative to the Suez Canal, was balked by the United States Government's attitude, an authoritative Israeli source said today.

Elizabeth Arden's business ventures are about as spirited as her horses. She has just opened a men's shop for the Christmas season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, said tonight that the Federal Government would prosecute all persons who endeavored to block integration of the public schools in Clinton, Tenn.

THE lettering on the huge scoreboard in Melbourne's Olympic Stadium bears an unmistakable message: "Classification of points on a national basis is not recognized." This is another way of emphasizing that there is no such thing as a team championship or a team standing in the Olympics.

The American Museum of Natural History has spent time recently leafing through its family album for an exhibition showing its long teaching history. The results, on view today, do full justice to the pictured interpretation of the museum's special teaching role from its pioneering beginnings in 1869 to the present.

A coalition slate, considered to be the right-wing group in the New York local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, has defeated the middle-of-the-road slate in an annual election of thirty-five board members.

Shipbuilding stocks have fared better in the last month than the stock market as a whole. The wind in their sails has been the Suez crisis.

Out of the lead only twice during the season, the Oklahoma Sooners finished on top yesterday in the final Associated Press poll to be rated the No. 1 college football team of 1956 for the second straight year.
The city's bill for public improvements is slated to be $665,606,137 in 1957. This is $32,413,756 less than the City Planning Commission had proposed.

A committee named by leading city bar groups attacked yesterday the sliding scale of fees for lawyers in negligence work that has been fixed by the Appellate Division, First Department. The fee scale is scheduled to take effect Jan. 1.

Michigan's timetable for financing its limited-access highway program was slowed yesterday by the inability of the state to borrow $52,000,000 in the public bond market at an interest cost of 3 per cent or less.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Dec. 4--A fire of unknown origin early today destroyed a warehouse of National Movers, Inc., at the intersection of State Highways 3 and 20 Here. The blaze tied up traffic for five hours on these routes and on State Highway 17.
The First National City Bank of New York voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend on its common stock to 70 cents a share. Previous payments were 65 cents a share at quarterly intervals.

Placido (Tony) Gomez, Brooklyn College's basketball coach, finds it difficult to conceal his enthusiasm concerning his quintet. The Kingsmen are experienced and fast and possess the shooting ability to better last season's 11-7 won-and-lost record.
TONIGHT'S performance of the York Nativity Play will be the last of three at James Memorial Chapel, Claremont Avenue at 121st Street.

Directors of the Guaranty Trust Company yesterday authorized payment of an extra dividend of 80 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of the same amount. The board also recommended a 20 per cent stock dividend.

A man's house may be his castle, but a woman usually runs it. And running it, she has decided opinions on how a house should be designed.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Prepare the planting hole for the live Christmas tree that will be set outdoors soon after the holidays. Make the hole wide and deep to give the root ball plenty of room. Fill with straw to keep it from freezing and place straw and burlap over the pile of earth so it can be worked.
IF you are well caught up on your sleep and don't mind an extra long day or driving you now can zip right through from New York to Chicago without stopping for a single traffic light or crossroad.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 8(AP) --John Philip Weyerhaeuser Jr., president of the vast timber company that bears his family name, died today of leukemia. His age was 57. He was stricken a month ago and had been hospitalized since Nov. 23.
Money borrowers are not the only people who stand to be disappointed or thwarted by a "tight money" period such as that of today.
Night games and doubleheaders mark the 1957 home schedule Of the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers.
MIAMI, Dec. 8--Ralph Jelio and Tom Jenkins, two underrated fullbacks, supplied the spark today that carried Pittsburgh to a 14--7 victory over Miami's previously unbeaten Hurricanes.

LONDON, Dec. 8--Princess Marie Louise, oldest member of the British royal family and a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, died today at her home in Fitzmaurice Place, Berkeley Square. She was 84 years old.

FOR more than a quarter of a century they have been making automobiles lower, longer and more pow erful. As the years have gone by these changes have been gradual and have not always been industry-wide. However, for the 1957 car all three of these trends have been unanimously given an energetic boost.
Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Dec. 1 were 1 per cent below sales in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Board.
Two explanations are offered for the Federal Reserve Board's action last week in raising the ceiling on interest rates that commercial banks may pay on savings deposits.
LONDON, Dec. 9--With the easing of international tension, stock prices showed encouraging gains last week.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 9-- The pursuit of money was becoming desperate in this Catskill community today.
Louis A. Handman of 108-27 Sixty-fifth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, a composer of popular songs and a vaudeville pianist, died yesterday of cancer in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. His age was 62.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 9-- President Eisenhower has been warned that public works planning still is "a sprawling monster with many heads and arms reaching haphazardly into every phase of our everyday life."
Coal cargoes again led the way last week in sending the steamship charter market to new highs. Grain also moved at prosperous rates, and the market continued in full command of the vessel owners.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP)--J.C. Caroline scored the only touchdown and, on the game's last play, tackled touchdown-bound Dick Lane in a 10-3 Chicago Bear victory over the Chicago Cardinals today. The triumph kept the Bears' divisional title chances burning brightly.
HAVANA, Dec. 9--Twentyfive rebels were killed and thirty-two taken prisoner in fighting between Government troops and insurgents under Fidel Casto, military authorities announced today.
CLINTON, Tenn., Dec. 9-- David James Brittain Jr., the principal of Clinton High School, was a scrub-team football player in his freshman year at Maryville (Tenn.) College.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 --Motion-picture and television stars who have established personal production corporations to gain income tax advantages may be taxed out of existence.
Prices of cotton futures continued to lose ground last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange had losses ranging from 40 cents to $2.55 a bale.

VIENNA, Dec. 9--An approximate census showed here tonight that 123,907 persons, 3 bears, 21 fox terriers, 100 horses, 50 pigs, 100 head of cattle, 2 sheep and an inestimable number of geese and chickens fled Soviet-occupied Hungary in the last six weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- Sam Baker's 21-yard field goal with 25 seconds remaining in the game capped a thrilling rally that enabled the Washington Redskins to gain a 19-17 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 (AP)-- Carl Braun tossed in 24 points as the New York Knickerbockers rallied for a 100-91 triumph over the Minneapolis Lakers tonight. The National Basketball Association victory was the Knicks' fifth straight.

VIENNA, Dec. 9--Eight planes with 574 Hungarian refugees left Austria for the United States today. It was the largest single day's movement of refugees across the Atlantic thus far.

The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened its fortyfifth annual appeal yesterday. However, even before the official start, 285 contributors had sent gifts totaling $124,223.87. This was an increase of more than $8,000 over the gifts on hand when last year's appeal began.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday, in general orders to be published today, the awarding of 300 citations for meritorious service.

Walter Cronkite, news reporter and commentator, has been denied permission by the Columbia Broadcasting System to serve as master of ceremonies of a new television quiz program titled "Nothing But the Truth."

PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 9-- Port Said was declared out of bounds today for British and French troops except those on duty.

Labor stability on the New York waterfront was described last week as of vital concern to Latin-America shippers and business men who depend on the port for the bulk of their oceanborne imports from the United States.
GAZA, Dec. 3--Postal service in this capital city of the Gaza Strip will be started tomorrow as an integral part of the operations of the Israeli post office.

FOR one hour yesterday afternoon the Columbia Broadcasting System took its viewers to the National Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum. The telecast, carefully and expertly planned, was an outstanding achievement.

The United States Commerce Department announced yesterday that it would take a special census of New York City and of four counties, six cities, seven villages and at least fiftyseven towns in the state next April.
Bernard M. Baruch has come out against any state law to bar employers from discriminating against job applicants over 40 years old.
Jack Barry of the Shanahan Catholic Club in Philadelphia was timed in 2 hours 40 minutes 43 seconds in winning the national junior marathon championship in South Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday.

Rain and snow at the Yankee Stadium yesterday didn't help the Giants, but the elements didn't beat them. The Cleveland Browns did that, 24--7, with a take-charge performance that made the home team look like an also-ran, rather than the title-bound outfit it still is. Or is it?
MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 9-- Long Island won the intercity court tennis doubles tournament today by defeating Philadelphia, 2--1. The victors regained the Payne Whitney Memorial Trophy.
The Bill of Rights was discussed yesterday by students of high school age on The New York Times Youth Forum. The panelists touched on such matters as censorship and Congressional investigations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9--Yugoslavia sent ninety more Hungarian refugees back to their devastated homeland this morning.

Edward S. Hawkins, one of this country's top authorities on Government subsidy accounting practices, has retired after five and a half years with the Robin Line. With Robin, Mr. Hawkins supervised the preparation of the line's accounting reports to Government agencies.
An extensive appraisal of efforts to improve the Morningside-Manhattanville area was announced yesterday.
Today, the eighth anniversary of the United Nations General Assembly's adoption of the Declaration of Human Rights, has an ironic significance that no eloquence and no dear hopes can overcome.
Burlesque, which was outlawed here in 1937 but permitted in a restricted format until 1942, is coming back. A theatre license, granted by License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell, is paving its way.
A Brooklyn conference called upon the Board of Education yesterday to use zoning as "a positive force for integration in the schools."

The Fund for the Republic-- which has been criticized at various times as "soft" to the dangers of communism--warned yesterday that the Communist party in the United States was "still conspiratorial in nature and in certain of its activities."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Experts here report that now it is the Stalinist regime of Bulgaria that is having serious internal troubles.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 9-- Habib Bourguiba, Premier of Tunisia, returned to his capital today with words of praise for the attitude of France at the United Nations.
Jack Cohn, co-founder and executive vice president of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, died late Saturday night of a pulmonary embolism at Midtown Hospital. His age was 67.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 9 (AP)--A list of fifty former football players and eight coaches, from whom ten are to be selected to the football Hall of Fame, was released today by George E. Little, the executive secretary of the organization.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 9 Miss Annette Pauline Silver, daughter of Morris Silver and the late Mrs. Silver was married this evening to Alan Leonard Fain. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Fain of Brookline, Mass.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 9-- A Trans-Canada Airlines plane carrying sixty-two persons from Vancouver to Montreal was reported several hours overdue today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP)-- The Defense Department is drafting a plan that would cut the nation's military reserve program. It will place emphasis on quality rather than quantity, the Pentagon disclosed today.

The caddie scholarship fund sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association was pronounced a resounding success yesterday at the annual meeting of the association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

THE tip-off on Australian swimmers came during the final Olympic tryouts Down Under. A depth bomb could not have roiled the water more. But the chances are that few in America even noticed it. Ours is a sports-minded nation but the concentration is on baseball, football, boxing, basketball and turf, the so-called major sports. Every four years we also become aware of the Olympics and always the emphasis is on track and field.
Arthur Lipper of Deal, N.J., a retired New York investment banker, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. His age was 80.

Front-court help, sought by the New York Knickerbockers since midsummer, was acquired yesterday in a man-for-man trade with the St. Louis Hawks. The Knicks, sending Slater Martin to the Hawks, obtained the 6-foot 6 -inch Willie Naulls, a former University of California at Los Angeles ace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Corn farmers go to the polls tomorrow for one of the most important farm votes in years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The National Education Association suggested today combining the "flat grants" system of the school construction bill with the Administration formula granting more funds to needier states.

Retail toy sales this year will reach a record-breaking $1,417,000,000 according to Gilbert G. Southwick, retiring president of the Toy Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Dr. Luther H. Gulick tonight called for new governmental structures designed to bring about a more balanced and rational evolution of industrial urbanization.

A heavy fall of facts nearly buried the Joint Legislative Committee on Winter Tourists at its fourth hearing here yesterday. The tourists in mind were primarily 250,000 skiers from the New York metropolitan area with travel habits leading to Vermont, New Hampshire and even Canada.
PARIS, Dec. 10--The French National Assembly gave the Government six votes of confidence today but none of them was overwhelming.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian sector), Dec. 10--This sector of Jerusalem looks like a dead city. The Old City, with a population of about 60,000, has no visible means of support.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 10-- The British commander here protested to the United Nations today against the first overt Egyptian attack on British occupation forces.
Salesmen reportedly wrote orders for $350,000 in passenger cars and trucks yesterday at the National Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum.

The New York Football Giants, stymied in the mud at the Yankee Stadium last Sunday, are rooting for a firm field at Philadelphia's Connie Mack Stadium on Saturday. Jim Lee Howell and his coaching aides were in agreement yesterday that the Giants are the type of team that fares better on solid turf.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--Four Asian nations proposed today that Dag Hammarskjold consider going to Moscow "without delay" to discuss the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Hungary.
VIENNA, Dec. 10--The showdown between the Soviet-imposed Hungarian Government and the workers' councils remained undecided today, according to reports from Budapest.

A welfare leader warned yesterday that the needs of children might be overshadowed because of emphasis on the problems of the aged, who have the vote and thus can place political pressure on legislators.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 10 (UP)-- Coach Ben Schwartzwalder refused to let snow disrupt his plans today as Syracuse University's football team began its second week of Cotton Bowl drills.
TRENTON, Dec. 10--The New Jersey Assembly approved today a supplemental appropriation of $8,738,036 to provide matching funds for the multimillion-dollar Federal highway aid program.
A comprehensive plan for the reorganization of the New York City Center has been blocked by the center's board.

The six-story apartment building at 115 Henry Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Society of the Divine Savior to a client of H. Goodman of Goodman Mabel, attorney. The sale was for cash over mortgages of $145,000, according to HelmsleySpear, Inc., broker in the transaction.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 10--Yugoslavia seems prepared at last to write off the Kadar regime in Hungary as a total failure.
The big-money quiz shows, which built a reputation by awarding princely sums to persons of small means, are now on the alert for celebrities to appear occasionally as contestants.
A broad counter-offensive to refute "false claims", that oneway avenue operation is undesirable has been initiated by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 10 --Four agencies moved today to ease the plight of this Catskill Mountains resort community, where the leading bank has been closed because of a $1,300,000 shortage. Moratorium Granted
"Operation Rebound"--the revival of basketball at Long Island University--is scoring highly with the school's students these days.
"I'm happy to be even a small contributor to your fund. I've contributed since its inception. May the fund have a banner year!"
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The Administration is making no provision for a general tax reduction in the coming year, a Treasury spokesman told Con gress today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP)--In an erratic market, soybeans scored modest gains on the Board of Trade today. Final prices were considerably under the day's best levels.
At least three New York and Brooklyn savings banks have filed notifications with the State Banking Department that they intend to increase their dividend rates from 3 to 3 per cent.
THE present price of ready-tocook broiling and frying chickens in several chains is comparable to that at which the birds sold during the depression.
PARIS, Dec. 10--Secretary of State Dulles began today what was regarded as a fence-mending operation within the North Atlantic alliance.
ROME, Dec. 10--The leadership of the Italian Communist party and of the Soviet Union itself were sharply criticized at today's meeting of the Italian Communist Party Congress.
TOKYO, Dec. 10 (AP)--Prince Fumitaka Konoye, first son of the late Prince Fuminaro Konoye, died Oct. 20 in a Soviet prison camp, the foreign office reported today.

SOL HUROK'S second "Festival of Music," presented last night on "Producers Showcase" over Channel 4, was a fine treat for the viewer who yearns for more adequate representation of serious music on the home screen.
Alex Miteff, a rugged Argentine heavyweight, extended his winning string to eight last night by gaining the decision over Archie McBride of Trenton at the St. Nicholas Arena.

It is now possible to put into perspective some of the scope of the veterans' training program with which we have been concerned for a little more than ten years. Some of the figures have been released by the Veterans Administration. They should give pause.
Massive atomic weapons by themselves are not enough to insure international order, Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, said here yesterday.

Wool prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The decline was one of the sharpest of the year. Volume was heavy. The decline was termed a reaction to the recent sharp rise. Foreign markets generally were lower.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 10--Seventeen aircraft combed a mountainous area today for a Trans-Canada Air Lines plane missing since last night with sixty-two persons aboard.

A partnership covering the production of plays and films has been formed by Blevins Davis, Edith Lutyens and Norman Bel Geddes. According to Mr. Geddes, the organization will adhere to a policy of producing a play and a picture annually.

The City of Montreal borrowed $22,481,000 in the United States market yesterday through the sale of serial bonds at an interest cost of about 5.258 per cent. The money will be used to finance street, sewer, pavement and sidewalk improvements. The bonds are payable in United States money.

Eighteen railroads operating in New York and New Jersey have given assurances that nondiscriminatory employment practices are now a part of company policy. This was announced yesterday by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination.
Mayor Wagner may confer later this week with two of his top aides about two union officials identified as suspected Communists. The unionists represent employes in nine city departments.

The power of constitutional principles and the strength of civil authority are being given a real test these days in the small mill town of Clinton in east Tennessee. This is the community whose public high ...

Many hostesses will entertain at dinner parties this evening before the 1956 Symposium for the benefit of the public education program of the United Negro College Fund. The event will take place in the Hunter College Assembly Hall at Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street.
LONDON, Dec. 10--More active trading on the stock market here today brought many price increases despite a late reaction in industrial and oil shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture today estimated the 1956 cotton crop at 13,303,000 bales. This final estimate of the year was about 1 per cent above that of a month ago but about 9 per cent below the 1955 crop.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The State Department urged the Federal Maritime Board today to release vessels from its reserve fleet to carry coal exports to Europe. The United States is facing an emergency in shipping, it said.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Frank C. Lane, the master dealer of baseball talent, broke the major league trading mart open today as the club owners began their annual winter meetings.
Seventeen New Haven Railroad trains, mostly commuter carriers, were delayed during yesterday morning's rush hour by the derailment of a power car in switching operations in the Port Chester yards.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--France asked today for the end of trusteeship status for French Togoland.

Two apartment houses on the upper West Side, known as 459461 West 163d Street, have been resold by David B. Solove, operator and investor, after a brief ownership. The purchaser is a client of Jack Garfield, attorney.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 --William Wyler will join Gregory Peck on a partnership basis to direct and co-produce "Thieves Market." Rights to the adventure-romance written by Liam O'Brien and Vincent Evans were acquired last June by Melville Productions, independent company organized by Mr. Peck and Cy Bartlett.

Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain, a 7-foot sophomore with a 45.5point average in his first two college games, helped Kansas move out front yesterday in the first Associated Press basketball poll of the 1956-57 season.
Cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday on a small trading volume.
"Now ... if I could just recall the size." This lament is being heard over and over in department stores these days.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--The United Nations' smaller states refused today to go along with suggestions by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold for sharing the cost of the United Nations Emergency Force.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 (AP)--The Olympic Village at Heidelberg was fast becoming a ghost town today as one team after another left in a gigantic airlift from Melbourne's Essendon Airport.
The Chicago and North Western Railway notified its securities holders yesterday that at the recommendation of its accounting consultants it had adjusted its balance sheet charges ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 10-- The president of Princeton Theological Seminary proposed today that a delegation of American Church leaders be sent to Communist China to re-establish contact with colleagues there.
The Maritime Administration, which has met with success in repowering the slow wartime Liberty ships, apparently is considering installing a nuclear reactor in one of the vessels.
Events today: Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15; Philadelphia Orchestra, Temple University Chorus and soloists; Eugene Ormandy conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The United States tax court ruled today that when a partnership qualifies for income tax exemption on business conducted in an American possession, the calculation must be made in relation to gross rather than net income.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A non-Communist oath taken falsely by a union officer does not expose the union to penalty even if the union members are aware of the crime, the Supreme Court ruled today.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 10-- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China arrived here today and must have discovered that times had changed in Burma since his last visit, in April, 1955.
A HUNTER from western Massachusetts made the agonizing decision yesterday, after forty-eight hours of prayerful thought, to move to New York City and never to set foot in the woods again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10-- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, said today that the Department of Justice would rely primarily on voluntary compliance of carriers to end racial segregation in state and interstate transportation.

RICHARD STANKIEWICZ places less emphasis on anecdotal character in his work in his recent iron and steel sculptures, shown at the Hansa Gallery, 210 Central Park South. Some of the figures, composed of rusty metal ...

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 10 (UP)--Captain Billy Talbert of the United States Davis Cup team, expressing pessimism that no one took seriously, complained today that practice conditions were so unsatisfactory he couldn't get his team in shape for India this week-end.

A personable, 40-year-old gentleman went to Evander High School 12 years ago to teach in the school's physical education department. Although he had coached football and basketball and had been an excellent baseball player, he was asked to coach the school's swimming team. This was Bill Gay.
Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan declared last night that some members of the bar had shown "apathy, timidity and selfishness" toward proposed reforms of state courts.

The trial of Johnny Dio and three others for conspiracy in the acid-blinding of Victor Riesel was adjourned yesterday until April 24. Federal Judge William B. Herlands postponed the action, originally set for today, over vigorous defense objections.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10--K.P.S. Menon, Indian Ambassador to the Soviet Union, appears to have assumed a key role in negotiating a solution of the Hungarian problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The President has not yet passed on a proposal before him that was made in the interest of improving Government coordination in the execution of the policies laid down by the President. The proposal was that the Vice President instead of the Under Secretary of State act hereafter as chairman of the Operations Coordinating Board.
LONDON, Dec. 10--Sir Anthony Eden is not making any "particular efforts" to see President Eisenhower, R.A. Butler, the leader of the House of Commons, said today.
Sales of Food Fair Stores, Inc., for the twenty-eight weeks ended on last Nov. 10 set a record high, but earnings were little changed from the period a year ago.

The groundwork has been laid for a major battle over higher education at the next session of the State Legislature. The issue will be fought between private colleges and universities, on the one hand, and persons favoring expansion of the State University, on the other.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--The major league club owners, anxious to rush through their separate league meetings so as to be able to wind things up with the joint session before Commissioner Ford C. Frick tomorrow, wasted little time today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10-- The contract bridge pair of Paul Hodge of Abilene, Tex., and Ben Fain of Houston, Tex., early today finished far ahead of 112 finalist pairs to win the 1956 National Open Pair Championship.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 Screen Gems has given a new title, "Dr. Mike," and a revised format to the projected filmed television series previously called "Emergency."

CAIRO, Dec. 10 (AP)--Lieut. Col. Abdel Hamid Serraj, intelligence chief of the Syrian Army and a man of mystery throughout the Middle East, says his Army bought arms from the Communist bloc because Western countries imposed conditions "we were unable to accept."

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Harry B. Baker, general manager of The Chicago Sun-Times Syndicate, died today at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 61 years old. He suffered a head injury in a fall at the Sun-Times Building last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A provision of the New York City administrative code under which two parcels of property assessed at $52,000 were seized for $887 in unpaid water bills was upheld by the Supreme Court today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Harry B. Baker, general manager of The Chicago Sun-Times Syndicate, died today at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 61 years old. He suffered a head injury in a fall at the Sun-Times Building last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A provision of the New York City administrative code under which two parcels of property assessed at $52,000 were seized for $887 in unpaid water bills was upheld by the Supreme Court today.
A new computer offspring that is said to be the biggest electronic filing device yet to be marketed was exhibited yesterday by the Burroughs Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The widow of a worker at the Watertown (Mass.) Arsenal will receive $60,000 compensatory damages for the death of her husband, as a result of a Supreme Court ruling today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Supreme Court upheld unanimously today the discretionary power of the National Labor Relations Board to require an employer to provide a union with information concerning individual rates of pay and working hours of its employes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The International Monetary Fund authorized Britain tonight to draw up to $1,300,000,000 to increase world confidence in the pound and forestall a British economic crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--The plight of the Hungarian people in their struggle for freedom lent special significance today to the eighth observance of United Nations Human Rights Day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A House of Representatives investigating panel recommended today that Congress not intrude legislation into discord within labor unions.
After pushing ahead for most of the day, shares on the New York Stock Exchange weakened in the last hour yesterday and ended irregularly off.
LONDON, Dec. 10--Britain narrowed the gap last month between her income from exports and her expenditure on imports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The United States told the puppet Government of Hungary today to stop blocking diplomatic communications channels between Budapest and Washington.
Steel-making operations of 102 per cent of rated capacity have been scheduled by the industry for this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.
The business connections and finances of all City Councilmen are slated for investigation by a special committee of the Council.
CAIRO, Dec. 9--Egypt's relations with the United States are at a high point today. But there appear to be some rocky detours ahead.
FIRED with Christmas spirit, we have investigated the wares of eight tobacconists, nosed into their sweet-smelling humidors and tread with not a few qualms on what is really no woman's land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) --Companies holding defense contracts were accused today of spending large amount of taxpayers' money to "pirate" engineers and scientists from the Government and from each other.

Fears were expressed yesterday that the men's clothing industry would be thrown into chaos by a change in the duty policy on imported woolen and worsted fabrics. A brief filed yesterday by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. with the Committee for Reciprocity Information in Washington registered its opposition to the move.
CLINTON, Tenn., Dec. 10 --Classes at Clinton High School, shut down last Tuesday because of community violence resulting from classroom integration, were reopened today ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Two man-made "moons" may be hurtling through space near each other within the next two years.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11--Some observers in the Soviet capital believe that the Central Committee of the Communist party is preparing major economic revisions to give a better break to consumers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 --Hecht-Lancaster Productions became the target of another legal action today. John van Druten, playwright, filed suit in Los Angeles Superior Court seeking to collect $91,667 assertedly due as the unpaid balance on a contract for $105,000 signed last July 12.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 11--The second trial of Milovan Djilas, former Vice President of Yugoslavia, opens here tomorrow. M. Djilas is accused of undermining the Tito regime by articles in the foreign press.

City College gained its third victory in four starts, defeating the Wagner quintet, 66--58, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, last night. The game was tied eight times in the first half and the lead changed hands five times.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11--Following are excerpts from speeches in today's General Assembly debate on the Hungarian situation and the text of a revised resolution submitted by twenty powers, including the United States:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11-- Louis Goldblatt was ejected from the hearing of the House UnAmerican Activities subcommittee here today. He is Secretarytreasurer of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, which is headed by Harry Bridges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today defended restrictive monetary policy, with its rises in interest rates, before a day-long onslaught by two members of Congress.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11--An emergency program to rush relief supplies to Hungarian children and mothers was approved unanimously today by the United Nations Children's Fund.
With aircrafts and a few specialties strong and chemicals and oils weak, the stock market yesterday continued the downward reaction that set in late on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) --The Department of Agricul ture today forecast a bigger crop of oranges and lemons in the coming season, but a smaller grapefruit crop.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 11-- Iraq's vast development program has not been affected by her loss of oil revenues resulting from the fighting in Egypt.
Twenty-one artists yesterday registered strong disapproval of the interior plan of the Frank Lloyd Wright museum building, now in its first stages of construction an upper Fifth Avenue.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman, nearing the end of a quartercentury in public office, said last night that he had never been "more troubled and alarmed" by the state of the country and the world.

WASHINGTON: Dec. 11 (AP)-- The Export-Import Bank of Washington today announced two loans totaling $24,200,000 to Japan Air Lines for the purchase of eight passenger planes from the Douglas Aircraft Company of Santa Monica, Calif. Four of the planes will be turbo-jets.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 11-- The tax-free status of religious institutions was criticized sharply here tonight by a leading Protestant churchman.

UNITED NATIONS, N.I., Dec. 11--Imre Horvath, Hungarian Foreign Minister, walked out of the General Assembly this morning. He charged that his Soviet-supported Government had been "rudely and disgracefully offended" by the debate on the Hungarian issue.
ALBANY, Dec. 11--The Republican legislative leaders announced today that they would sponsor tax reductions for small business in the 1957 session.
VIENNA, Dec. 11--A general strike went into effect today through most of Hungary. The stoppage had been called Sunday by the Budapest Central Workers Council before the...
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 12--Corn farmers rejected yesterday an Administrationbacked plan that would have given them more acreage but lower price supports in 1957.
Net income of the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 was reported yesterday at $4,853,950. This was equal to $2.61 a share on the common stock.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, Dec. 12--Irish Republican extremists staged a series of raids along the Northern Ireland border early today.

The New York State Bankers Association said yesterday savings banks and savings and loan associations should be prevented from paying higher interest rates than commercial banks on large deposits which tend to flow from one bank or institution to another.

BERLIN, Dec. 11--Recent diplomatic activity by East German Communist leaders indicates they are searching for another Cominform or a juniorsized substitute for the party organization that died in April.
The Sanitation Department was accused yesterday of paying the salaries of at least sixty-one persons who do no work for the department and serve full time as union officials.
Out of a small glass chamber, devised to study means for taming the explosive energy of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful uses, has come a new vision of creation.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11--The Soviet ambassador to Sweden resigned today amid published demands that he be forced to leave.
MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 11-- Two hundred Hungarian refugees took off from Munich for the United States today in the start of they Air Force airlift ordered by President Eisenhower.
State loans to enable deserving high school graduates to obtain a college education were proposed yesterday by L. Judson Morhouse, Republican State chairman.

Chet Forte, the little hero of Morningside Heights, put on another of his fine court displays last night, to the consternation of the Fordham Rams. Scoring 32 points, he led Columbia to a 99-84 triumph before 2,000 fans at University Hall.
WARSAW, Dec. 11--Rioting in Stettin (Szczecin) last night culminated in an attack on the Soviet consulate.
Eighteen railroads operating in New York and New Jersey have rendered a, signal service to American democracy for which they deserve the nation's applause.
"Can Do," a two-week-old program that has failed to keep pace with its title, is already scheduled for cancellation.
Prices of all woven and tufted wool carpets will be raised by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company an average of 6 per cent, effective next Jan. 2.
CHICAGO, Dec.11--The board of directors of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company authorized today a proposal to split the capital stock four to one.
The Henry Street Friends Committee will hold its annual Christmas Cotillion on Dec. 24 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Unless thins happen "awfully fast," the outlook for a 1957 fall season by the New York City Opera Company is beginning to appear remote, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of the City Center, said yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 23 points (15 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 11--Prices of industrial shares went ahead on the stock market here today although gains generally were small.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, proposed tonight a major expansion in atomic power plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Mrs. Golda Meir, Foreign Minister of Israel, said today that, while Israeli forces would withdraw from Egypt, "the Gaza Strip is a special problem."

Premier Chou of Communist China is now on a six weeks' "goodwill" tour of Asian countries to persuade them of his good intentions. On the whole, he seems to have had a cooler reception than on his visit last year.
Copying of American advertising and marketing methods throughout the world should be encouraged in the view of Vincent Tutchings, vice president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.
BOSTON, Dec. 11--New England fishermen were bitter today over President Eisenhower's refusal to raise import duties on fillets of groundfish.
Signs are everywhere in this vast city that indicate the holiday drawing near.
GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 11 --Frederick Ballard Williams, landscape artist, died here today at his home, 31 Highland Avenue, after a short illness. His age was 85.

THE wife of a government trapper who hunts bobcats, wolves and mountain lions in the wilds of California won the grand prize of $25,000 in the eighth annual Pillsbury Bake-off at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 11-- President Eisenhower served notice today he would renew his request to Congress that the United States join the Organization for Trade Cooperation.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 11-- The mayors of eighty-two Algerian cities and towns revolted today against the French Government's decision to dissolve all popularly elected city and regional councils in Algeria.
City and state officials called yesterday for increased state appropriations to provide more recreation, special housing and greater job opportunities for the aged.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 11 --The lawyer for the Anjopa Paper and Board Manufacturing Company, Inc., asserted here today that the concern had no idea that its account in the Home National Bank was $900,000 overdrawn until the bank was closed.

Earnings of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., for the quarter ended Oct. 31, finest quarter of its fiscal year, were above profits in each of the two preceding quarters, Whitley C. Collins, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Hawthorne, Calif.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 11--A five horsepower heat pump said to carry a residential installed price, 10 per cent lower than competitive models was announced here today by the Carrier Corporation.

The International Longshoremen's Association and five of its locals were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Alexander Bicks to show cause tomorrow why they should not be restrained from allegedly engaging in "strikes, work stoppages and concerted refusals to perform services" for a New York trucking company.

Coffee prices may go up again, not as a result of any undersupply but because of concerted action by producing countries. Mexico has announced that it favors coordinated marketing among producers of mild coffee.
Steel production in the United States last month at 10,566,000 net tons was the heaviest on record for a November, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) --Philip L. Graham, publisher here, today termed the present limits on campaign spending unrealistic. He said they had turned politicians into hypocrites.
BEHIND the dignified bronze doors of 1007 Fifth Avenue, a pale five-story and roof-studio house, Jane Peterson lives among art treasures.
THERE has been a great deal of discussion lately in literary haunts and joints about what a sportsman should take along with him to read in hunting or fishing lodges, hotels and camps.
GUATEMALA CITY, Dec. 11 --The Government and the United Fruit Company date yesterday signed amendments to existing contracts that regulate the company's Atlantic division operations.

PARIS, Dec. 11--West Germany will call on the North Atlantic Council to continue giving primary attention to the Soviet military threat in Europe, sources close to Bonn's delegation to the meeting said tonight.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $38,000,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Administration will renew in Congress its proposal that sales of surplus farm products to Iron Curtain countries be permitted, Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

Today, seven weeks after the Hungarian revolution began, the political and moral bankruptcy of Moscow's policy in Hungary is clearer than ever. That policy has attained none of its objectives. It has been defeated by the courage of the Hungarian people.
ALBANY, Dec. 11--Governor Harriman attempted today to take a firm stand midway between the State University and private colleges, but he found the footing decidedly unsteady.

ROXBURY, Conn., Dec. 11-- Mrs. Paul Arthur Shepardson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Fuller Shepardson, to Dr. Johannes A. J. Stohwijk. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Stolwijk of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
The New York Knickerbockers and some records in the National Basketball Association books were swept aside last night at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11--Wheat futures declined today on the Board of Trade. The market showed some sympathetic reactions on a sharp break in Kansas City December wheat.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec, 11--A friendly golf game between President Eisenhower and Louis St, Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada, emphasized anew today the informality and amity that have marked relations between the two nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- A coal shipping executive warned today that estimates of United States coal needed by Europe and the number of ships to carry it were "entirely conservative."

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 11--Within the next few days the United States Air Force hopes to complete the initial phase of its air dropping missions over the South Pole. It then will withdraw its huge Globemaster transport planes to New Zealand.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 11-- Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler, United States Army, retired, arrived today in this shrinking British and French beachhead to settle the major outstanding problem, the fate of the BritishFrench canal clearance fleet.

THIS is the date for the fight between Sugar Ray Robinson and Gene Fullmer for the world middleweight champion ship. At least this WAS the date. But Sugar Ray always has been a slick, resourceful operative. When he was at his best, he was as impossible to hit as Marley's Ghost. It's still difficult to hit him because Robinson can vanish faster than Marley's Ghost.
Whitey Ford, the Yankees' star southpaw pitcher, topped the American League in two departments, it was revealed by the 1956 official averages released yesterday.
Robert D. Lion Gardiner will give a tea this afternoon in his home at 990 Fifth Avenue for chairmen and committee members who are planning the second International Debutante Ball.

A Federal Court ruling on an injunction to bar the International Longshoremen's Association from demanding an industry-wide collective bargaining contract on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts was postponed for another twenty-four hours yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 11--The Metropolitan Regional Conference approved in principle today a proposal for an emergency air pollution control organization with broad police powers for quick action in periods of dangerous smog.
Vehicle Accident Court, where Manhattan traffic trials are held, was jammed yesterday as never before.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 11 (AP) --The president of the American Farm Bureau Federation today urged that the Federal Government stop buying and storing surplus farm commodities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11--A General Assembly committee approved today a convention on the nationality of married women. Work on the convention had been in progress for the last five years. The vote was 41 to 0, with 21 abstentions, including the United States.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Dec. 11--Commercial life in Haiti's capital of Port-au-Prince was almost at a standstill today in the second day of a strike against the regime of Gen. Paul E. Magloire.
Floyd Patterson, who at 21 is the youngest heavyweight champion in ring history, yesterday was named "righter of the year" by the New York Boxing Writers Association.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 11 (UP)--Lew Hoad, playing topflight tennis as Australia's Davis Cup team selectors watched, whipped Bob Howe of New South Wales today. The scores were 6--2, 6--3, 6--4.

Riders on a New Haven Railroad train were required yesterday morning to change trains in mid-track. That difficult and unusual operation was carried out successfully on the eastern approaches to New Rochelle a little after 10 o'clock.
