Julia is the altogether engaging heroine of Ann Bridge's "The Lighthearted Quest," a romantic novel about intrigue, detection, archaeology, love and the world crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11--A South Korean delegation presented a token petition today containing 10,000 names, urging acceptance of that country as a United Nations member. The petition was offered on the eve of a Security Council meeting on the admission of new members.
CHICAGO, Dec, 11--The 1,500,000-member United Auto Workers Union is aiming at the biggest wage increase in its history in 1958.

PARAMUS, N.J., Dec. 11-- Mrs. Mary Ann Timmons Finneran, former chief telephone operator for The New York Times, died here today in Bergen Pines Hospital. She had suffered a stroke twelve days ago in her home, 1570 Center Avenue, Fort Lee. Her age was 57. She was the wife of Martin J. Finneran.
The nation's chain and mail order concerns chalked up their seventh consecutive month of sales increases in November, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
An examination device that lights up like a pinball machine to show grades has captivated students at Metropolitan Vocational High School.
BOSTON, Dec.11--The Navy's guided missiles will soon constitute an effective anti-aircraft screen around the fleets in any type of war, "big or little," Admiral Arleigh A. Burke said tonight.

Four apartment buildings at 157-61 East 150th Street and 674-76 Courtlandt Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the Miller estate to Louis Danto and Samuel Gottlieb, who plan to remodel the property into forty apartments.

EVERY color scheme is an island, according to designer Paul McCobb, who puts this theory into practice in the new showroom for his Directional furniture. Located at 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, it deals through decorators.
Time took a giant step backward to get into the Old Timers program yesterday at the National Automobile Show at the New York Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11-- Mrs. Patrick Francis Kielty Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Kielty, to Francis Leo Moran. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Moran. The couple plan a spring wedding.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 11 (AP) --Three bills to permit insurance companies to sell variable annuities--which caused a stir in the insurance field--are dead. That's the word from Senate Republican Majority Leader Albert McCay of Burlington County.
The Port of New York did about $100,000,000 less in foreign trade general cargo business last month as a result of the nine-day strike on the waterfront.
If the New York Giants hold the Philadelphia Eagles even in Saturday's game at Connie Mack Stadium, the Eastern Conference title of the National Football League will belong to Jim Lee Howell's club.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 11 --Weather conditions described as "impossible" hampered aircraft searching the mountainous Hope area today for a TransCanada Airlines plane missing since Sunday with sixty-two persons aboard.

PARIS, Dec. 11--The trials and hopes of the Atlantic alliance, and ways of facing current crises, were discussed today by officials of the fifteen allied nations. The talks took place both within and outside the North Atlantic Council.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11--Major league club owners, in a surprise move today, voted to remove all restrictions on the signing of college players.

Boxer Berger, realty investors, have purchased the sixstory garage building on plot 100 by 100 feet at 505 West 166th Street from clients of William R. Altman, attorney, for cash over a first mortgage of $98,000. Morris A. Kapplow and Samuel Bardfeld were the brokers. The property is assessed at $140,000.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 11-- Egyptians kidnapped a British officer at the point of his own gun here today.
CLINTON, Tenn., Dec. 11 (UP) --Court-enforced racial integration at Clinton High School proceeded normally today under protection of the city police and sheriff's officers.
MADRID, Dec. 11--The shadow of further inflation is creeping slowly over the face of Spain.

Two scratch players, R.G. Fiske of the Harvard Club and C.Y. Sarnoff of the Yale Club, were among the first-round victors in the Norman Torrance Memorial squash tennis tournament at the City Athletic Club yesterday.

Gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund increasingly show a response to the individual stories of hardship listed last Sunday, when the forty-fifth annual Christmastime appeal was formally opened.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 11--The Most Rev. Bartholomew Joseph Eustace, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Camden, died this morning at his residence in near-by Haddonfield. He was 69 years old.
New York City has borrowed $40,000,000 on tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.
The United States is developing into a nation of "cities" hundreds of miles long, the eighteenth annual meeting of the Institute of Life Insurance was told yesterday in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 --"His Master's Voice," a musical review of the R.C.A. Victor Company, is being planned for spring production on the National Broadcasting Company television network. The spectacular, under the supervision of Ken Murray, is subtitled "From Caruso to Presley."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11-- Charles Warner, Philadelphia business man and Delaware civic leader, died today in Hahnemann Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Wilmington, Del.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Nick Shuk, the leading jockey in Maryland for the past five years, virtually guaranteed himself a sixth title today by winning five of the eight races at Pimlico.

Futures movements on the New York Exchanges were irregular yesterday in generally dull trading. Potatoes, cocoa and soybean oil rose; sugar and tin declined, and coffee, cottonseed oil, wool, hides, rubber, burlap and zinc were mixed.

PARIS, Dec. 11--In order truly to resuscitate NATO it is necessary first to heal the wounds existing in United States relationships with Britain and with France. Secretary Dulles, quite wisely, seems determined to start this process in separate bilateral negotiations.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Major Eugene Sabatini of Bristol, Pa., said today he had been evicted from his London home by a landlord angered by United States opposition to the British-French attack on Egypt.
The film industry has revised and relaxed its code of morals and taboos for the first time since the code was adopted in 1930.
VICTOR BORGE, the oneman production, gave the second half of his "Comedy in Music" last night over Channel 2.
IT was on St. Valentine's Day, 1955, that Mayor Wagner appointed his former roommate at Yale as his Commissioner of Investigation.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11.-- Moses (Mosey) King, Yale University boxing coach for fortysix years until his retirement in 1952, died last night a few hours after being struck by an automobile. He was 72 years old.
Eighteen leading civic groups yesterday called upon the Board of Education to start planning to select a successor to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

NEWARK, Dec. 11--The victims and the practitioners of the confidence game called "pigeon drop" testified here today at a Senate subcommittee hearing presided over by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.
Former Supreme Court Justice Emil N. Baar was honored last night by the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, which named him "man of the year."

A 56-year-old former secretary who is accused of having devoted most of her time for the last fifteen years to "swindling prominent persons in the musical world" was indicted yesterday on charges of grand larceny.
THERE is a widespread belief that concert audiences inhabit a rarefied world, shielded from the facts of life. It isn't so.
The events in Haiti these days make unhappy reading for all Americans who know that attractive, carefree and unfortunate country.
A private builder has proposed constructing a skyscraper on East Fifty-first Street that would house a police station and a firehouse.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 7-- Groups of young students in khaki overalls, armed with short barreled Czechoslovak submachineguns, may hold the future of Syria in their hands.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 11-- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China began using his diplomatic skill today in an effort to woo Burma.

Up to this week the largest single operation carried out by the International Monetary Fund with one of its member countries in the ten years of its existence took place in 1947-48, when it made $300 million...
Two of the nation's largest steel companies plan to merge in defiance of the Department of Justice.
Mrs. John Carrott of Greenwich, the defending champion, led the way into the semi-final round of the Women's New York State squash racquets championship yesterday.

Bill Lloyd of Greens Farms, Conn., seems to have the best formula for winning major sports car races. It goes like this: You wheel out your old, beat-up, three-liter Maserati, pile it with all the gear you think you'll need and get it down to Miami (either drive it or haul it), put it on a boat and ship it to Nassau in the Bahamas.
The National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences has voted to make its resources available to Hungarian scientists driven from their country by Communist terror.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Subversive Activities Control Board heard more questions raised today on the credibility of Government witnesses in the Communist party case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Senator Charles E. Potter of Michigan today became the fourth Republican Senator to back an attempt to change the Senate's rule protecting filibuster in January. He joined a group of six Democratic liberals who are leading the move.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Republican chairman of New Jersey said today that the party had "a very good chance" to beat Gov. Robert B. Meyner next year if it could avoid a primary fight for the nomination.

From London comes word than Sir Lawrence Olivier and his wife, Vivien Leigh, are weighing a proposition to act in Yugoslavia next summer. They would appear at the head of a company from Stratford-on-Avon's Shakespeare Memorial Theatre.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 12 (U.P.)-- Federal Judge R. Dorsey Watkins today dismissed as without merit a patent infringement suit brought by the B.F. Goodrich Company against the United States Rubber Company.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12Representative Emanuel Celler shocked United States Embassy officials and Mexican and United States newspaper men today by discussing at length "the President's unfortunate illness" and the problems of succession in the event of General Eisenhower's death.

Oscar S. Lerman has added a third project to his Broadway production plans for next season. It is a musical comedy called "Cupid Wears a Mustache," based on the life of James Mont, interior decorator and designer.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 12 (AP)--Walter S. Robertson, United States Assistant Secretary of State, described today as "absolute nonsense" reports that the United States intended to cut aid to Indonesia.

With the human tragedy of Hungary and the explosive potentialities of Eastern Europe overshadowing all other issues, there is a growing danger that the Middle Eastern problems will be permitted to drift into a prolonged stagnation that...
A two-story garden apartment building on a plot 300 by 70 feet at 769 to 793 Avenue Z, near Ocean Parkway, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the A D Realty Corporation.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 12 (UP) --Gov. Luis Munoz Marin offered today to open Puerto Rico as a haven for Hungarian refugees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- The Indian Bureau is purchasing twenty-one school buses as part of its program to step up school enrollment on the Navajo reservation in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah, the Interior Department announced today.
A New York County grand jury will soon begin hearing evidence concerning the acid blinding of Victor Riesel, a labor columnist.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The Navy is carrying out a dispersal action around the world to prevent the concentration of vessels in home ports during the Christmas holidays.

Neil J. McKinnon, vice president and director, has been named president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Toronto. He succeeds James Stewart, who was named chairman on the retirement of Stanley M. Wedd.

Lieut. Col. Maxim J. Dowd has been assigned as chief, industrial office, Purchasing division of the new Military Clothing and Textile Supply Agency at the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot. Colonel Dowd recently returned from Yohahama, Japan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--France and Britain complained to the United Nations today that Egypt was mistreating their nationals in Egypt.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 12 --A committee of fifteen local business men worked tonight against time in an effort to save the largest commercial bank in this mountain resort community of 5,000 persons.

The New York City long-distance workers' local has rejected a new labor contract negotiated Dec. 5 between the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America.
The Christmas season may mean an electric train, a gaily decorated tree or a warm Candlelight Service rich in meaning. It is a time when families gather to celebrate.
Opposition arose yesterday to major league baseball's removal of restrictions on the signing of college players.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 12-- It was announced here today that about 600 political prisoners in Algerian detention camps would be freed before the end of the month.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP)--The Wheatley Stable scored its first triumph of the winter season today when Dark Ruler won the featured seventh race at Tropical Park.
Governor Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut said yesterday that there must be public support of enforcement authorities to help reduce highway deaths.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 12 (AP) --Australia's Ken Rosewall will join Jack Kramer's professional tennis tour after the Davis Cup challenge round in Adelaide, Dec. 26-28, but a team-mate, Lew Hoad, will remain an amateur at least another year, it was learned authoritatively today.

Groundfish fillets are simply the meat (without bones) of certain kinds of fish that live on or near the bottom of the sea, including such familiar species as sole, haddock and cod. They are a mainstay of the New England fishing industry.
WARSAW, Dec. 12--Representatives of 30,000 Poznan steelworkers capped three days of anti-Soviet demonstrations with a demand today for the immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops from Hungary.
Antonio A. Sorieri, a deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Welfare, has been elected president of the New York State Welfare Conference.
BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 12 --Switzerland's traditional neutrality was reaffirmed today as a policy in a world whose future remains "singularly somber."

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP)--With Clyde Lovellette scoring 29 points, the Minneapolis Lakers crushed the New York Knickerbockers, 121--103, in a National Basketball Association game tonight before 6,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court returned to the bench today after a brief stay in the Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., for treatment of a mild urinary infection.
Ship construction in this country's privately owned shipyards is at its highest volume in the last three and a half years, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

William Power Maloney, former chief trial counsel for the Department of Justice, was found not guilty last night of "willfully" failing to file his Federal income tax returns for 1952 and 1953 on time.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--Following are the totals of offers of assistance to Hungarian refugees and of actual arrivals in countries other than Austria, as of 9 A.M., as reported by the United Nations today:
LONDON, Dec. 12--Britain's chief medical officer proposed today that a ban on smoking in theatres and public vehicles should be considered in connection with the nation's campaign against cancer.
R.A. Appleman has been appointed general traffic manager of the Esso Standard Oil Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) --Harrison King, a retired Army colonel, and his family have found a way to spend a "richer and more meaningful Christmas."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--The Security Council voted unanimously today to recommend Japan for membership in the United Nations.
TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 12 (AP) --F.K. Weyerhaeuser of St. Paul, Minn., was elected president of the Weyerhaeuser Timber...
Automobile safety equipment was the first consideration of 60 per cent of the buyers yesterday at the National Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum.

The 47,120-deadweight ton tanker Evgenia Niarchos, the latest addition to the vast fleet of Stavros S. Niarchos has successfully completed her builders' trials. She is now en route to the Persian Gulf to pick up her first cargo of oil, Transoceanic Marine, Inc., New York agent for the Niarchos shipping interests, announced yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12-- Jewish deportees who arrived by plane today from Egypt said fifty-eight men had been held in chains in the barn of the Mosque of Mohammed Ali in Cairo for...

Space for a branch office here has been leased in the Empire State Building, 350 Fifth Avenue, by the Don Kemper Company, an advertising agency with headquarters in Dayton, Ohio, Cushman Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.

BUSHNELL, Fla., Dec. 12 (UP) --The trial of seven white men accused of having beaten a Negro ended suddenly today with an acquittal. The verdict was ordered by the judge at the request of both the defense and prosecution attorneys
HAITI'S chief of state who resigned yesterday followed the "Emperor Jones" tradition: bright spangles in appearance, iron-fists in rule.

WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 12-- Charley Napoli, a 20-year-old tackle from Concord, Mass., and Maury Stein, a 20-year-old fullback from Bloomsburg, Pa., were named co-captains of Brandeis University's 1957 football team today.
Marguerite Piazza, singer, will be hostess at a cocktail party to be given this afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Variety Club Foundation to Combat Epilepsy.

It has been twelve years almost to the day, from the time Maj. Glenn Miller disappeared over the English Channel to the appearance of the latest version of the Miller band at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. Ray McKinley now directs the 1956 reincarnation of the Miller hand.
The Government filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here to block the proposed merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

Henry Edwards, a Czechoslovak immigrant whose memories went back to the Austro-Prussian war of 1866, died of a stroke Tuesday in his home at 108-44 Sixty-eighth Road, Forest Hills, Queens, at the age of 103.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP)--Frank G. Millard, 64, general counsel of the Army and former Michigan Attorney General, is in good condition following surgery Friday for the removal of part of one lung, University of Michigan hospital authorities said today.

CROSSETT, Ark., Dec. 12 (AP) --A plane from Vincent Air Force Base, near Yuma, Ariz., crashed five miles southeast of here last night. Captain Theodone M. Hallock, 32 years old, of Concord, Calif., and Capt. Thomas M. Baker, 35, of Lockhart, Fla., were killed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- Democratic Congressional leaders have destroyed a movement by party liberals to put the national organization directly into legislative planning for the new Congress.

VIENNA, Dec. 12--The Red Cross said today that it had found no critical shortage of food in Budapest at present but that it expected scarcities and widespread suffering when winter and the effects of the crippling strikes hit the Hungarian capital.

Robert Moses appealed yesterday to New York's hotel owners for more friendly employes and less catering to guests with big expense accounts. He was a guest speaker at the annual meeting of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., in the Park Sheraton Hotel.
HONEGGER and Hindemith, modern masters at their best, were represented by some of their finest product at last night's Carnegie Hall concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

TOKYO, Dec. 12--Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today that he was convinced the restoration of Japan's relations with the Soviet Union would "contribute vastly to the peace of East Asia and the whole world."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- The Air Force reported today a decline of 50,000 in military personnel in the twelve month period that ended Sept. 30 and an increase of 35,000 in civilian workers.
A program to desegregate the city school system was proposed yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--United States trade, tax and credit policies were viewed here today as the chief hurdles impeding the economic development of Latin America.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 12-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will make a brief preChristmas trip to Austria to study Hungarian refugee problems.
LONDON, Dec. 12--The rise in stock market prices here continued today, but on a somewhat narrower front than yesterday. Net changes generally were under a shilling (14 cents).
PARIS, Dec. 12--The French National Assembly approved by a vote of 320 to 216 today the accord between France and West Germany on the Saar.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP)--Komsomolskaya Pravda published an interview and pictures today of a United States turncoat. He is James M. McMillin, former United States Army sergeant.
Robert W. Dowling was reelected president of the New York Board of Trade at India House yesterday. He is president of the City Investing...
An outstanding American decorator will receive an award this evening at the Elsie De Wolfe Award dinner, which will be...

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 12 (AP) --Basketball's longest losing streak ended unexpectedly tonight when Millsaps upset William Carey, 87--81, for its first victory in forty-seven games. Millsaps set the national record of forty-six straight losses last Saturday by bowing to Arkansas State Teachers, 103--68.

The first payment of union dues by six controversial "paper" locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters showed yesterday that they had a combined member ship far below the average for other teamster locals here.
Mr. and Mrs. H.V. Kaltenborn will give a tea dance in their home at 167 East Sixtyfourth Street on Dec. 27 for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Erika Anais Robinson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The State Department seemed exasperated today over a statement Monday by C. Douglas Dillon that the threat of Soviet force had stopped the British-French invasion of Egypt.

Savings bankers conceded yesterday that there might be room for compromise between themselves and commercial bankers, who in the past have opposed the savings banks' fight in the state Legislature for greater branch privileges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) --United States and Soviet scientists, unable to get their Governments to agree to joint operations over the North Pole, apparently are making more progress with plans for the South Pole.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Representative Stewart L. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, said today he would propose repeal of the two-term limitation on the Presidency at the next session of Congress.

Morton Sobell, who is serving a thirty-year prison sentence for conspiracy to commit espionage, yesterday asked the United States Court of Appeals for a new trial. He contended that the Government had knowingly used perjured testimony at his trial.
"The Marriage of Figaro" was performed at the Metropolitan last night, with Laurel Hurley singing her first Susanna with the company.
BERLIN, Dec. 12--An increasingly rebellious mood among young East Germans is evoking stern measures from Communist leaders. A purge of collegiate ranks is the latest such move reported here.
In outward appearance the arrival this morning of the superliner United States will be only a routine docking along "luxury liner" row.

A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, declared yesterday that there was a "plot" in the high command of the Democratic party to strip Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of Manhattan of his Congressional perogatives. The union leader charged that Mr. Powell was being punished for having supported President Eisenhower for re-election.

THE infantry the cavalry, the Navy and the flying chauffeurs of the Air Force have won our various wars in a thousand different volumes. Now, in Fairfax Downey's "Sound of the Guns," the artillery has its day of splendor.

Memphis, Tenn., completed yesterday the permanent financing of a 750,000-kilowatt electric generating plant, the municipal power project that spurred the Eisenhower Administration last year to cancel the controversial Dixon-Yates contract.
Earnings of Swift Co. for the fiscal year ended last Oct. 27 dropped 38.8 per cent from the previous year and were the lowest since 1951. Sales, however, gained 1 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 12--The Belgrade District Court tonight sentenced Milovan Djilas, former Vice President of Yugoslavia, to a three-year prison term for having criticized the foreign policy of the Tito regime in the Western press.

In the article in The New York Times yesterday, headlined "Physicist 'Creates' Universe in a Test Tube," it was reported that "the titanium ions would attain 100,000 degrees Centigrade." This was a typographical error. The correct figure for the temperature is 100,000,000 degrees Centigrade.
DENVER, Dec. 12 (AP)--The Government sent Delmer Robideaux, a Sioux Indian, a check for 3 cents today.
A Rembrandt painting, "Portrait of the Artist's Father," was purchased for $13,000 yesterday by Louis Statham of Beverly Hills, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The international problems centering on the Suez Canal in the Middle East and Communist China in the Far East will dominate the four days of talks between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Nehru.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12 --Miss Katharine L. O'Connell, a retired New York City teacher specializing in the correction of speech defects, died Monday in Carlisle Hospital here after a short illness. Her age was 74.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 12--Gen. Paul E. Magloire, who has been provisional chief of state since last Thursday, resigned today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--Response to the United Nations fund appeal for Hungarian refugees has been disappointing and is causing concern here.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 12 (U.P.)--Anonymous donors have given Colgate University $350,000 for a study of the religions of the world. Everett Case, Colgate president, said the fund would support research of Prof. Kenneth W. Morgan, who will study methods of encouraging student interest in religions.
Felix Appino, fondly remembered by theatre folk as the former headwaiter and night manager of Sardi's Restaurant, died early yesterday at his home 34-16 Twenty-fifth Street, Astoria.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (Reuters)--A letter from Rene Descartes, seventeenth century French philosopher and mathematician, was sold for 2,100,000 francs ($6,000) at an auction here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--The General Assembly tonight condemned the Soviet intervention in Hungary.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Immigration service officials here said that there was no restric tion placed on the Russians as such.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was reported today preparing a decision, in case he has to rule, that would go against a Senate bloc trying to prevent filibusters.
Dr. Jacob Greenberg, Deputy Superintendent of Schools, has been promoted to the rank of Commander in the French Legion of Honor.
Members of the International Typographical Union have voted down a proposal by their leaders for creation of a union defense fund of $5,000,000 to $10,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold sent his greetings today in a radio message to members of the United Nations Emergency force in the Middle East. The message served to begin special radio programs to the troops.

Ski Sketch: As Governor of New York State, Averell Harriman has little time for participation in winter sports, principally because the annual legislative session falls when most of the snow does--January through March.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The Bethlehem-Youngstown merger plan revived agitation in Con gress today for a more effective anti-merger law.

Announcement has been made here of the birth of a daughter, their second, to Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lagman of Phoenix, Ariz., on Dec. 2 in that city. Mrs. Lagman is the former Miss Pauline Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mitchell of New York.
A rise last week of 220,550 barrels daily in the nation's output of crude oil was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 (AP) --An Israeli Army spokesman said today the rail line near the Jordanian border in central Israel had been blown up by a mine planted by Arab raiders. The section hit was on the Haifa-Lydda line about midway between the two localities. The spokesman said a train passing at the time was not damaged.

Perhaps the unluckiest tennis player these days is a 31-year old southpaw player named Art Larsen. Blind in his left eye and partially paralyzed, the Californian did not even have hopes of paying his mounting doctor bills--until yesterday.
A miniature statue of Miss Helen Keller was presented yesterday to the deaf and blind writer and lecturer by the Japanese Consulate.

OWENSBORO, Ky., Dec. 12 (AP)--A Federal judge today ordered Union and Webster counties, scenes of racial strife last September, to file school desegregation plans before the February term of United States District Court here.
WINSTED, Conn., Dec. 12 (UP) --Thomas A. Haggerty, editor of The Winsted Citizen, observed his eighty-third bithrday today by putting in his usual eighthour day at the office.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 12 --Dr. Samuel Tomlinson Arnold, Provost of Brown University, died of a heart attack this evening as he was walking from his office to his home, 10 Euclid Avenue. His age was 64.

Sports officials and athletes throughout the nation were urged last night to protect amateur standards with greater effort in the wake of recent examples of "vituperation and vindictiveness" during the Olympic Games in Australia.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. Dec. 12-- Six business places were burned out here today when fire swept a one-story commercial building at Railroad Street and Cedar Avenue, Estimates of the damage to the building, stocks and fixtures range to $250,000. The fire was discovered about 1:30 A.M. The cause has not been determined.

Gerald Nolan, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, Second Department, announced yesterday that the court had appointed Municipal Court Justice Augustine B. Casey as the County Clerk of Richmond County. He succeeds the late Charles F. Pallister.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Political background as well as straight military courses have bean ordered for the military personnel of members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organizations who attend classes at the NATO Defense College near Paris.
With the Legislature not scheduled to meet until Jan. 9 and the Governor's annual budget not due until about Feb. 1, Republican legislative leaders are already busy cutting taxes.

ROME, Dec. 12--A leading Polish Communist challenged here today the Soviet thesis that unrest in his country and the Hungarian uprising had been upstirred by Western agents. Jerzy Morawski, member of the Politburo of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party, also called for "more democracy" in communism.
"Tom Courtney proved you can be a hero twice in one race."

The tide of Christmas began flooding over the city yesterday. The distribution of toys to hundreds of children was begun at a series of festive entertainments, a number of business firms had begun staging early Yuletide parties and stores and shops were thronged.

Sales of the E.W. Bliss Company this year should reach about $80,000,000 and earnings about $3,000,000, or $3 a share on the 1,006,000 shares outstanding, Robert Potter, president, told a group of security analysts yesterday at the Wall Street Club.

Representative Wright Patman, as head of a subcommittee of the Joint Congressional Economic Committee, has been conducting this week what has become over the years a solemn, more or less regularly recurring, ritual on his part.

PARIS, Dec. 12--The problem of the Suez Canal has been discussed here by the foreign ministers ef the United States, Britain and France and their experts, assembled for the meeting of the North Atlantic Council.
A RECENT and accurate report here on a historic debate over the question of whether Bears have fleas has reminded a reader of one of the mysteries of nature over which he has been brooding for years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12--Following is the text of a French draft resolution on the states of foreign nationals in Egypt:

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 12 (AP)--Spokesmen for four communities today foresaw financial emergencies if the state should develop Niagara River power without allowing local taxation of state properties.
IN local professional food circles, Mrs. Eleanor Street oc cupies a place somewhat similar to that held by Coty in perfume and Cadillac in automobile manufacture.
VIENNA, Dec. 12--The League of Red Cross Societies and the Austrian Government signed a contract today authorizing the leagues to assume the care of 25,000 refugees in fourteen camps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) --The Air Force announced today it was setting up a special base on the West Coast to train men to fire the long-range ballistic missiles of the future.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12--Leading Soviet newspapers called today for better party propaganda, and more attention to the problem of students inside the Communist homeland.
Walter Rothschild, board chairman of Abraham and Straus, has been chosen to receive the 1956 Tobe award as "Retailer of the Year."
ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP)--Governor Harriman today appointed Kevin Kennedy, East Aurora lawyer, to the Temporary State Commission on the Courts.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the Mayor, participated yesterday in the opening of the Heinsheimer children's floor at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Madison Avenue and 123d Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP)--For one of the few times in the history of the Academy of Music, a concert was canceled here last night. The reason: the crowd was too small.
Students and staff members of Union Theological Seminary, 120th Street and Broadway, will give blood to the Red Cross today.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (U.P.)--The State began distribution today of $990,697.82 in motor vehicle tax receipts of the fifty-seven counties outside New York City. The total is the share of statecollected motor vehicle fees for the three months ending Sept. 30, 1956. It is being returned to counties in accordance with state law.
CARBONDALE, Ill., Dec. 12 (AP)--A college prank that backfired sent a freshman to jail today on a charge of killing a football star at Southern Illinois University.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) --The public cashed in more United States Savings Bonds than it bought last month.
ALBANY, Dec. 12--Representatives of forty-five upstate cities urged the Legislature today to re-examine the entire picture of state financial aid to localities.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12 (AP) --Most of the time you hear of fight champions being warned for not fighting enough. But Raul Macias, the National Boxing Association bantamweight titleholder, is on the carpet for fighting too often.

The Broadway swing bridge that spans the Harlem River Ship Canal at 225th Street will be closed to traffic, including rapid transit service, on Sunday between 8 A.M. and 6 P.M.

Seats are still available for the Monday evening performance of "Happy Hunting," which will benefit the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children in Farmingdale, N.J. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 12 --A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Allan B. McNie of Brookline on Monday at Richardson House in Boston.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12-- Miss Almena Dawley, a founder and retired associate director of the Child Guidance Clinic here, died today at her home in suburban Flourtown. She was 66 years old.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 12-- The mere presence of Israel always will be a danger to stability in the Middle East Burhanuddin Bashayan, Iraq's Foreign Minister, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- Small business in the field of automation needs a better tax climate to grow and meet the demands for greater productivity, a business man and enginer told a Congressional subcommittee today.

The president of the National Council of Jewish Women called yesterday for a revision of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act. The official, Mrs. Moise S. Cahn of New Orleans, said such a revision would serve as a tribute to "the heroic people of Hungary."
BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Dec. 12 (AP)--A Phillips Petroleum Company executive and seven other employes were killed today when their plane crashed and exploded in a snowy pasture.

A variety show has been organized to entertain airmen at United States bases in Labrador, Greenland and Newfoundland. The troupe will leave tomorrow and return here next Tuesday. Those who will make the trip are Ella Logan, Lisa Ferraday,...
The State Department appealed yesterday to New York longshoremen to relax a part of their self-imposed boycott against handling shipments from behind the Iron Curtain.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 12-- Protestant church leaders called on the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. today to send a delegation of American churchmen to Communist China.

Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn had an easy task with Paul Jorgensen of Port Arthur, Tex., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The local featherweight gained the unanimous decision.
The Riverdale area was the center of Bronx realty activity reported yesterday.

The State Medical Society and the Federal Government have signed a contract under which the society will administer the new Medicare plan which provides civilian medical care for the dependents of military personnel in this state.

The Tobe award committee today named Walter Rothschild, chairman of the board of Abraham Straus, "Retailer of the Year."

WARSAW, Dec. 12--Polish newspapers disclosed today that rioters in Stettin (Szczecin) had not only smashed the windows of the Soviet consulate there Monday night, but also broken into the building, wrecking the interior and looting its contents.

LONDON, Dec. 12--The drive toward British political and economic unity with Europe jumped forward tonight. More than 100 Conservative Members of Parliament urged the Government to call a conference of Western European powers to strengthen collaboration.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 12 --Mr. and Mrs. Jack Randolph Warwick have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Warwick, to Frederick Clyde Dyson of Columbus, Ohio. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Herbert Dyson of Tarpon Springs, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

The five-story apartment building containing a store occupied by Duffy's Tavern at 230 West Forty-eighth Street has been purchased by Stanley W. Kempner Son for investment. It occupies a lot 17 by 100 feet, adjoining the Longacre Theatre, and was bought from Lenore Galowitz. M. S. Gaumont were the brokers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12--The average starting salary offered to male college graduates by business will be $100 a week, a Northwestern University survey showed today.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 12-- The fate of Second Lieut. Anthony, G. Moorhouse, British officer kidnapped here yesterday, still was a mystery late today, thirty-six hours after his disappearance.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 12 (U.P.) --North Carolina State College revealed tonight that the Atlantic Coast Conference had ruled the school violated conference rules. The ruling concerned the recruiting of a freshman basketball player, Jackie Moreland of Minden, La.
HAVANA, Dec. 12--The in surgents in Oriente Province are surrendering in response to a forty-eight-hour ultimatum given them by Government troops, according to military headquarters here today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (U.P.)-- The purchase of the Randall Park race track here by a group of Pennsylvania sportsmen was "substantially agreed upon" today in a meeting with Homer Marshman, an attorney who is acting for the owner. Marshman said the owner, Saul Silberman, had priced the park at around $3,800,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- The Community Facilities Administration announced approval today of a $9,100,000 loan to help Purdue University finance a $21,500,000 building program.
The twenty-acre estate of Laura Chang on Westchester Avenue, Harrison, N.Y., has been sold to the Sisters of the...
IRVINGTON, N.Y., Dec. 12-- Benjamin S. Halsey, former executive vice president of the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., died yesterday at his home here after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 12-- A Marine corporal who traveled 3,000 miles in 1945 to comfort the mother of a friend who had been killed on Okinawa will receive $25,000 under the mother's will for "his act of kindness."
A YOUNG painter, Wolf Kahn, who early identified himself with expressionism in the tradition of Kokoschka and Kirchner, is showing recent work at the Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Corn farmers have given Congress the go-ahead signal for a new political fight over farm policy. They did so by voting in yesterday's corn referendum to stick with a program authorized under the New Deal in 1938.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru will take to Washington a conviction that the Chinese Communists are more eager than ever for a settlement with the United States.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP)--Tass, Soviet News Agency, released today a message from President Tito to Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet chief of state, expressing hope for stronger friendship and cooperation between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 (U.P.) --Pascual Perez of Argentina, the world flyweight champion, outpointed Conrado Moreyra of Chile in a ten-round non-title fight tonight. Perez weighed 107 pounds, Moreyra, 113 .
Issues of $18,000,000 of Los Angeles, Calif., general obligation bonds to finance various public improvement's will be offered for sale on Jan. 18, it was anonunced yesterday.

Yes, Santa Claus, there is a Virginia--and a Pablo, a Mercedes, a Tony and a Ricky. And they all believe in you and hope you will not forget them this Christmas, as you may have in the past.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 12--The Defense Ministry has decided to adopt the United States M-48 medium Patton tank as the basic weapon of its mechanized divisions, it was reported today.
Nick Gaetani scored 22 points last night as the Brooklyn College basketball team downed Queens, 72--68.
When and if the New York Giants wrap up the Eastern Conference championships of the National Football League, they will qualify as the host club in the title play-off game on Dec. 30.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 12-- Dr. Arthur Sperry Pearse, nationally known zoologist and retired Duke University faculty member, died here yesterday at the age of 79.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday continued gains in sales, orders on hand, total revenues and net income for the first nine months of this year compared with the like 1955 period.
The new Holland-America liner Statendam will be named in a high-seas ceremony, it was announced yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the company for North America.

A loan or an outright gift of up to $5,000,000 from the United States Government to the Austrian people who have aided Hungarian refugees was urged yesterday by Angier Biddle Duke, president of the International Rescue Committee.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 12-- The joint search for uranium here by Brazilian and United States geologists was resumed quietly two weeks ago.
Mrs. John Carrott of Greenwich, Conn., won her third New York State women's squash racquets championship yesterday on the courts of the Riverdale Yacht Club in the Bronx.
An advertising and merchandising program is being worked out by Foote, Cone Belding for the introduction by Dole Hawaiian Pineapple Company, Ltd., of Honolulu, of a frozen pineapple and citrus blend.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 12-- Neil Devaney of Peekskill Military Academy set a prep school record of 1:00.6 for a 60-yard pool in the 100-yard butterfly stroke today as Peekskill defeated the Columbia University freshmen swimmers, 59--18.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12-- Charles H. Tompkins, a prominent Washington builder, died of cancer this morning in George Washington University Hospital. He was 73 years old.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 (UP)-- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers, announced today the union executive board had approved a plan for sponsoring 1,000 Hungarian refugees.

The Downtown Athletic Club completed the second platoon of its John W. Heisman Memorial Award all-star team last night.

"How big a bird should I buy?" is a question home cooks often ask when planning a poultry dinner.

VIENNA, Dec. 12--Any doubt that the forty-eight-hour general strike that began in Hungary yesterday morning was a success was dispelled today. The Government newspaper Nepszabadsag declared that the "workers' movement has never seen such a strike."
A gift to the Neediest yesterday cited the role of charity both at home and abroad.

EDWARDS, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP) --A Navy guided missile lost contact with the jet plane that was guiding it on a test shot yesterday. It streaked across the Mojave Desert and crashed 120 miles away on the edge of Death Valley.

Today's new film is "Anastasia," Twentieth Century-Fox screen version of the stage play, starring Ingrid Bergman, Yul Brynner and Helen Hayes, at the Roxy. The 8:30 P.M. premiere will be for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) Mail trucks will be used to promote equal job opportunity regardless of race or religion during the Christmas season, the Government said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) --Government debt--Federal, state and local--hit a record total of $320,800,000,000 last June 30.

WARSAW, Dec. 12 (AP)--Lisa Larsen, Life magazine photographer, said today she had been ordered to leave Poland by Dec. 17, when her visa expires. She said the Foreign Ministry's press department had asserted the action to Life's publication of an article by Jozef Swiatlo, former Polish secret police officer who defected to the West.
Legalizing the sale of the "package tour deal," including theatre tickets, by amending the General Business Law was suggested at a trial yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.

A better mouse trap has been built. "The Electronic Cat," made of the Catalin Corporation's polystyrene, is sprayed on the interior with an electrically conductive metal film. A piece of bait is placed inside the dome-shaped case. An electrical outlet is plugged in and any rodents who enter should be killed instantly.
Stockholders of Lone Stan Cement Company at a meeting yesterday in Portland, Me., approved a two-for-one stock split.
Motions by the National Basketball Association and others to dismiss a $1,000,000 anti-trust suit against them were denied yesterday by Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman.

The National Broadcasting Company is seeking to obtain a long-term television contract for the services of Orson Welles as an actor, producer and director. The two parties reportedly are close to an agreement.

LONDON, Dec. 12--A rule requiring an evening break of one hour from 6 to 7 P.M. weekdays in broadcasts by British Television stations was abolished today. The break was adopted to give parents a chance to get children away from television sets and to bed in good time.
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation and the Kennecott Copper Corporation are forming a joint subsidiary to produce titanium metal by means of a new continuous process.
The appointment of two new general merchandise managers for its upstairs store has been announced by Gimbels, New York.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Steamship Company, which operates the largest iron ore fleet on the Great Lakes, decided today that ice conditions were getting so bad it would have to start laying up its vessels tomorrow.

The Norwegian Hospital of the Lutheran Medical Center has notified more than 200 persons who were treated at the hospital last week after the Brooklyn pier disaster that they will not be charged for the services.

Stephen Naft, a writer who was active in the European Syndicalist movement in his youth, died yesterday at the Flushing Manor Nursing Home, 35-15 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, after a long illness.

Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Minton of New York have made known the engagement of Mrs. Minton's daughter, Miss Anne Elizabeth Fosbroke, to Raymond Forsyth DeVoe Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. DeVoe of New York. The couple plan a February wedding.

Some 106,000,000 Americans will own a new peak of $415,000,000,000 of life insurance by Dec. 31, Edmund Fitzgerald, president of the Life Insurance Association of America, told 500 top insurance executives at yesterday's opening session of the group's fiftieth annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The American Brake Shoe Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock and the regular quarterly of 60 cents a share. Both are payable Dec. 28.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--The British Embassy and the Export-Import Bank announced today that negotiations had begun for a line of credit to Britain.

Mrs. Freda Hliddal has been appointed executive assistant to the director of New York University's Hall of Fame for Great Americans. She succeeds Mrs. Bertha L. Lyons, who was associated for thirty-two years with the national shrine, which is on the Bronx campus.

The Ford Foundation has granted $500,000 to the National Committee on the Aging, the National Social Welfare Assembly announced yesterday at the end of its two-day annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel.
Cotton futures moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 32 points ($1.60 a bale) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The far months showed the most strength.

Foster T. Rhodes, vice president of the Onondaga Pottery Company, Syracuse, N.Y., was elected president of the U.S. Potters Association yesterday. He succeeds David G. Boyce, vice president and secretary of Harker Pottery, East Liverpool, Ohio.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., will offer for public subscription today a new issue of $30,000,000 of 5 per cent debentures of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation due Dec. 1, 1976. The debentures are priced at 100.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP)--BrenDan Sexton, education director of the United Auto Workers, said today the Soviet Union was training thirty to forty times as many technicians as the United Sttaes. He spoke at the annual UAW skilled trades conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Dr. Leroy E. Burney, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, suggested today that families use the holiday season to arrange poliomyelitis vaccine shots for all persons under 40 years of age who have not had three injections.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- Clayton Fritchey said today he would resign as deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee about Jan. 1 to explore prospects for establishing a "new journalistic enterprise."

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 12-- Despite the fact that Victor Seixas is troubled with a knotted muscle in his right shoulder, the United States is still strongly favored to defeat India in the interzone Davis Cup tennis final starting here Friday.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday important management changes. They were designed, it was said, to bring younger men into top posts.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that there had been a "frightening increase" in automobile deaths here in the last month.

The New York Sinfonia, conducted by Clayton Westermann, gave its first Town Hall concert last night. The group, in its one previous performance, played last season in Carnegie Recital Hall. Last night's was the first of two scheduled Town Hall performances this season; the next will take place on Jan. 23.
An overhauling of the professional bail bond business was urged yesterday by a New York County grand jury in a presentCounty grand jury.
ROME, Dec. 12--Mankind needs to defend itself against noise--above all, unnecessary noise--Pope Pius XII said.
Mayor Wagner made available to the City Council last night all investigative and legal resources of his office requested by the Council in its projected inquiry into its own members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) --Excavation of the westerly end of a ten-mile St. Lawrence Seaway canal being built to permit ships to bypass a power dam is now 93.3 per cent completed, the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation said today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 12 --A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Fisher on Monday in the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. Mrs. Fisher is the former Miss Greta Gustafson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Gustafson of Scarsdale. The child, who will be named Melinda Grace, is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Fisher.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) --Bernard Deutch, a student at the University of Pennsylvania, was found guilty of contempt of Congress today for refusing to give the names of persons he knew to be Communists.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain conceded yesterday that eleven employes of his department were drawing city pay although they devoted full time to labor union activities and performed no departmental duties.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 12 (AP)--Gasoline rationing, brought on by the closing of the Suez Canal, has made Danish gasoline prices just about the highest anywhere. A motorist must pay 11 kroner, or about $1.50, to get the equivalent of a United States gallon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)-- American Airlines and Trans World Airline have asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to suspend and investigate a proposal by Capital Airlines to offer special low fares to groups of college students.

Members of the Free Nurses Institute, Inc., will close the group's twenty-ninth annual fund-raising campaign with a dinner dance in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 31.

The stockholders of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company at a special meeting here yesterday approved a two-forone stock split.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12--Futures trade in the wheat pit was modest most of today but picked up materially during the closing hour and prices turned sharply higher.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12--Israeli border policemen killed fortyeight Israeli Arabs in the village of Kafr Kassem near the Jordanian border on Oct. 29. The shooting of the Arabs was officially acknowledged today.

Financial details of the sale of A.H. Bull Steamship Company, Inc., to American Coal Shipping, Inc., still have not been disclosed by either concern. However, Wall Street now understands that the transaction, which will be closed next Tuesday, is a $40,000,000 one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 --"The Golden Triangle," with Kirk Douglas in the lead role, will be the first motion picture venture of the newly formed Associated Artists Productions, a subsidiary of PRM, Inc.
SHARON, Conn., Dec. l2-- Thomas S. Olsen of Salisbury, a director and former executive vice president of the General Baking. Company, died today at Sharon Hospital.
The Chicago White Sox won most of the fielding honors in the American League this year, the official averages reveal.
The appointment of Donald A. Eldridge as president of Bennett Junior College, Millbrook, N.Y., was announced yesterday by C.K. Woodbridge, chairman of the board of trustees.

Samuel R. Milbank, an investment banker, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of Barnard College last night. He succeeds Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, who has been a member of the board since 1941, and has served as its chairman since 1947.

SO busy with Christmas shopping are most home cooks that they do not have much time to spend at the kitchen range. Steaks, chops, cutlets and other quick-to-cook foods are what they at a buying, according to reports the City Department of Markets has received from grocers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13--Trading in wheat futures was Fairly active today on the Board of trade. At the close, prices showed mixed changes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 --Ethan Allen, colorful Vermont patriot of the Colonial era, will be the subject of a new halfhour filmed series. GoodsonTodman Productions will make it in association with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 13--The Defense Department announced today the formation of a huge new Military Air Transport Service. It will take over airlift operations now run by the existing interservice agency of the same name, and smaller ones run independently by the Air Force and Navy.

LONDON, Dec. 13--Britain will refuse to allow salvage ships of the Royal Navy to be used for clearing the Suez Canal unless their crews are also employed on the task. This was disclosed today by R.A. Butler, Leader of the House of Commons.
A resolution condemning the use of false and deceptive price claims was adopted yesterday by directors of the National Better Business Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--The Navy announced today an expanded program to study natural and man-made radioactivity. It will establish ten to twelve monitoring stations extending along the 80th Meridian, West, from Greenland to Antarctica.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 13 --Dr. and Mrs. Frank A. Williams have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Ann Williams, to Andrew Jackson Werner Scheffey, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Scheffey of Haverford, Pa.
A Negro pilot will go to work on Monday for New York Airways, the city's helicopter airline. He is the first Negro hired as a flight crewman by any of this country's scheduled passenger airlines.
NEWARK, Dec. 13--A gloomy picture of young America's lack of physical fitness was painted today by a top Federal official.
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday filed a notice of appeal against a Federal Court's temporary injunction barring the union from demanding an industry-wide contract.
KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 13-- Fordham scored an 85-71 triumph over the University of Rhode Island quintet tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today for the first time statistics on domestic uranium production and reserves.
LONDON, Dec. 13--Alan Lennox-Boyd, Secretary of State for the Colonies, flew to Athens today for talks with the Greek Government on the future of Cyprus.

Santa Claus cheerfully rolled up one red sleeve and got his first anti-polio shot here yesterday. He said that he would get his second and third shots at the North Pole from his private physician.

A master plan to end segregation in the city's public schools has been proposed, to take effect in September. It would drastically change the present zoning regulations that determine the schools to which the pupils must go. Provisions are made in the plan to obtain a better racial balance in all the city's schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--In reporting in this space recently the purpose and progress of a proposal before the President to make the Vice President chairman of the very important Operations Coordinating Board, which has the duty of assuring that a national policy approved by the President will be carried out consistently and all down the Government line, there were several references to assistants to highpolicy makers, known as "Indians."
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 13-- A British major was seriously wounded today by a bomb tossed through the window of his car. The weapon was wrapped in an Egyptian loaf of bread.
Eighteen Massachusetts municipal housing authorities borrowed $52,491,000 at short term in the public market yesterday to finance housing projects for war veterans and old people.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 12-- The Turkish Government is embroiled in a dispute with university professors that threatens to raise a major debate on academic freedom.
THE work of Mrs. Vanderbilt Webb in elevating American crafts to an art was honored last night at a dinner held by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Decorators at the Plaza Hotel.
Mayor Wagner congratulated thirteen members of the United States Olympic team yesterday on their performances at Melbourne. Three won gold medals at the games, which ended last week.

The J.J. Newberry Company and the S.S. Kresge Company, both variety department store chains, and Stop Shop, Inc., supermarket chain, will be major tenants in the $20,000,000 North Shore Shopping Center, at Peabody, Mass.

The Celotex Corporation, which makes building materials, has taken note of what women say they want in housing. Ideas advanced at a recent women's congress on housing, summarizing all sorts of wants, have led to a national advertising campaign by Celotex scheduled to run through 1957 in national magazines.

JACK ROOSEVELT ROBINSON entered baseball as a social symbol. He will leave it as more than just the first Negro to crash an exclusively white circle. He will be remembered also as an authentically great and exciting player of the game.

TRENTON, Dec. 17--The Sunday sale of automobiles in New Jersey was outlawed today by a State Supreme Court ruling.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (UP) --The New York Giants, Eastern Division champions of the National Football League, placed seven men on the thirty-onemember Eastern All-Star squad for the seventh annual Pro Bowl game here on Jan. 13. The selections were announced today.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 17--Terrorists struck again tonight at several points in Northern Ireland.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- Thirteen New York school teachers who were dismissed for invoking the Fifth Amendment lost a new appeal to the Supreme Court today.

Whitford Kane, character actor known for his portrayals of benign, grandfatherly old men and for repeated runs in "Hamlet," died of cancer yesterday at the University Hospital here after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- The 531 members of the Electoral College cast their votes for President today. But in Alabama one Democratic elector refused to vote for Adlai E. Stevenson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The most elaborate table service of the White House--the Monroe flower stand, matching compotes and candelabra, and gold flatware--was used at a ladies' luncheon today.
WHEN the Chicago Bears were in the process of annihilating the Washington Redskins in the 73-0 landslide, a crisis arose near the end of that unforgettable championship play-off.
A move to meet "the severe shortages" of newspaper men qualified to write on science, business and finance is now being contemplated at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.
SUCCESSFUL prizefighters seldom make good actors. And, conversely, as demonstrated on "Studio One" last night over Channel 2, actors are not likely to be convincing in the ring.
Schenley Industries, Inc., is taking to the United States Supreme Court its challenge of the constitutionality of the tax forceout law on distilled spirits.
Frank Costello moved yesterday in Federal Court to set aside his conviction for income tax evasion and to get a new trial. He is serving a five-year prison term.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--From conversations with persons familiar with the subject a number of impressions emerge of Prime Minister Nehru's attitude toward the United States in this second and more hopeful of his visits:
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 17 --The stock subscription of $1,050,000 needed to open the new Ellenville National Bank was oversubscribed today by more than $44,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP) --Eighty-nine Korean orphans arrived on a chartered airliner today to begin new lives in foster homes.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 17 (UP)--James Weaver, Atlantic Coast Conference commissioner, said today the University of North Carolina football games in which Vince Olenik participated during the 1956 season had been forfeited.
The Board of Higher Education last night requested an increase in the hourly wage rates paid to evening and summer session teachers in the four city colleges.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 17 (AP)--Two gunmen got $60,000 or more from a bank here early today after abducting the head teller from his home and forcing him to open a night depository.
Brief official ceremonies yesterday noon began the two-year, $3,475,430 job of reconstructing the Manhattan street approaches to the Brooklyn Bridge.
"The Good Woman of Setzuan," starring Uta Hagen in the title role, arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the Phoenix.

Establishment of additional bank holding companies in New York State should be encouraged so long as they do not result in marked reduction in competition, says Dr. Marcus Nadler, New York University professor of finance.

Commodity futures prices were mostly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, rubber, wool, lead and burlap rose; copper, tin, cottonseed oil and potatoes declined, and price movements for sugar, zinc, and hides were mixed.
LONDON, Dec. 17--Prime Minister Eden received a warm but far from tumultuous reception when he returned to the House of Commons today after an absence of thirty-two days.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 17-- Pressure is mounting on President Juscelino Kubitschek to veto a "sleeper" amendment to the foreign exchange bill passed by Congress last week. The amendment provides that all payments abroad are to be made at the official "free" exchange rate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs for the second consecutive week had risen to the highest point in twenty-three years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17--The Soviet Union asked today for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations as the price of enlarging the Security Council.

DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP)--Striking out at what he called "a disastrous trend that is making pro football a slugging match," Buddy Parker today threatened to resign after six seasons as head coach of the Detroit Lions.
The Mills College of Education yesterday purchased the eight-story building in which it was a tenant at 66 Fifth Avenue, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17-- George W. Helme 3d, an investment counselor, was held in $2,500 bail today on charges of involuntary manslaughter, driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident.
Thirty-three signatures, most of them in the handwriting characteristic of central and eastern Europe, accompanied a gift to the Neediest Cases received yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized emergency railroad freight rate increases of 7 per cent in the East and 5 per cent in the West.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 9 points up (10 cents a bale higher to 45 lower), yesterday.
A Government-sponsored airlift brought seventy-nine more Hungarian refugees to this country yesterday.
A general tuition increase of $100 a year will go into effect at New York University next summer. This will make the full-time day undergraduate tuition $900 a year.
The week--before-Christmas round of holiday parties got into stride yesterday.
RAGS to riches has always been the traditional American success story. But just as much effort is needed when a successful father has already made the family famous. Such is the case of Mary Rodgers.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 17 --The latest British proposals about Cyprus have produced the first faint hopes that Turkey might accept a compromise on a constitution for the island.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its ruling of Nov. 13 that racial segregation on city buses in Montgomery, Ala., was unconstitutional.

The International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to "recommend" to its members that they exempt from their informal boycott of Iron Curtain freight any diplomatic consignments to the delegations of the Soviet Union or its satellites.
More public housing construction is to begin in 1957 in the eight-state northeastern region than was started in 1956 or 1955.

The Armco Steel Corporation is planning to sell about 1,093,000 new shares of common to its stockholders. A registration statement covering the proposal is to be filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
An order authorizing the merger of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation with the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was signed yesterday by Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock.

The Joy Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh manufacturer of coal mining and other machinery, oil well, construction and industrial equipment, attained the highest sales and earnings in its history during the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 17--Floyd Patterson received a warm welcome home here tonight from the Mayor and the townspeople. It happens that Patterson doesn't live here, but nobody seemed to mind.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) --A rubber industry spokesman said today that natural rubber consumption in 1957 would equal this year's, despite strong competition from the synthetic industry.
Plans to build an integrated steel plant on the New Jersey side of the Delaware River about twelve miles south of Trenton, N.J., were disclosed yesterday by the Phoenix Iron and Steel Company.
The Consolidated Edison Company argued yesterday that conjunctional billing gives undue preference to certain classes of consumers and so should be ended.
Department store operators apparently are going to have to be content with a second-best Christmas sales period.

STORIES about the sharp decrease in Hungarian part ridges on Prince Edward Island have inspired Alfred Schreiber of Rochester to throw in a few suggestions on how to nurture both pheasant and partridge populations.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 17 (UP)--Iowa's Rose Bowl football squad staged a public workout today at East Los Angeles Stadium before 350 spectators.
American colleges and universities are extending a helping hand to the Hungarian scholars and students who are here as refugees.
The Aluminum Company of America is going after the recreation market with an expanded "Playday, U.S.A." promotion.
Bill Russell, the 6-foot 10inch Olympic ace, will make his first start for the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association on Saturday afternoon in Boston.
Less than six months ago we were congratulating the Wagner administration on hiring Dr. William J. Ronan as First Deputy City Administrator.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- Randall Jarrell, consultant in poetry at the Library of Congress, devoted his first lecture tonight to "The Taste of the Age." It added up to bittersweet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge to New York's Uniform Support of Dependents Law.
ALBANY, Dec. 18--Westchester County officials appealed to the Legislature today for more power to adopt the State's unwieldy Permanent Personal Registration Law to their local problems.
The forty-seventh annual Blue Ridge Ball will be held on Jan. 25 in the ballroom of the Pierre, it has been announced by Mrs. Frederick Lee Liebolt, the chairman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)-- A Federal judge assailed today four business practices that he said "forbode evil."
Geological and seismograph maps, which four men were accused yesterday of stealing from the Gulf Oil Corporation, may be most valuable in locating underground oil deposists.
A man with a magic touch in managing steamship freight has decided to call an end to his career--but with reservations.
Ill winds blowing no good between New York and New Jersey are to be studied by the Interstate Sanitation Commission.
The changing moods of American literature since 1917 have been captured and arrayed behind glass.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)-- The Eisenhower Administration again urged Congress today to strengthen the organization and administration of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.
John Fitch was one of those young men who took the baccalaureate sermon seriously. So the world was an oyster and he would open it; he would see all...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The Democratic national organization abandoned attempts today to give non-Congressional elements a greater voice in the party's legislative planning. Party leaders in Congress had fought the move.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)-- Sponsors of a private atomic plant under construction in Michigan asked the Government today to exclude their company from the label "electric utility."

Vice President Nixon has gone to Austria as President Eisenhower's personal representative for the primary purpose of studying the Hungarian refugee problem. His trip should also help to keep the Hungarian struggle for freedom before the eyes and the conscience of the free world.
VIENNA, Dec. 18--There were indications from Budapest tonight that the Government had begun to realize it must compromise with the people of Hungary.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 18 (Reuters)--Sir John Harding, the Governor of Cyprus, announced tonight the revoking of collective fines levied on residents of the island for not resisting terrorists.

ATLANTA, Dec.18--The chancellor of Georgia's sixteen state colleges and universities asserted today that he would recommend admission of a Negro to a white institution if the Negro were qualified. He adde such a view might get him dismissed.
Dr. Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, decried last night the "wholesale transformation" of Christmas into "so heathen a holiday."
Eight Eastern railroads are preparing to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for an immediate increase of 5 per cent in both first class and coach passenger fares.

It is good news that Brazil and the United States are about to reach an agreement on the use of the island of Fernando de Noronha off the coast of South America as a guided missile tracking station. There are still a few details to iron out, but they should give no trouble.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The establishment of priorities for steel plate necessary to build tankers will be decided tomorrow by the Defense Mobilization Board.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 18 --Charles Henry Campbell, director of the British Information Services in Washington, died here early today of a stomach hemorrhage. His age was 52.
The premiere of the motion picture "Baby Doll" last night at the Victoria Theatre raised approximately $40,000 for the Actors Studio.

The leveling of public school programs in favor of "easy knowledge, lax instruction, overemphasis on extracurricular activities and other escapes" was decried last night by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) --Temple University rolled to a 79-56 Basketball victory over Pennsylvania in the second game of a Palestra double-header tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 --Approval of a formula which provides for payment of $615,000 plus an additional prospective $100,000 to motion-picture actors from showing on television of theatrical movies made after Aug. 1, 1948, was voted last night by the board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild.
Following is the text of a television-radio address from Washington last night by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, as transcribed by The New York Times.

A brokerage company was temporarily restrained yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund Palmieri from representing that President Eisenhower was interested in a company newly formed by his wartime mess sergeant, Marty Snyder.
Albert S. Bard is 90 years old today. For a birthday present he'd like the top half of General Grant's tomb removed. He knows it isn't possible, but he'd like it.

Mrs. Blake Harjes of 129 East Eighty-second Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Frederica Harjes, to Michael Jasperson.
Thais Lawton, an actress for forty-five years, died yesterday at her home, 165 West Eighty-third Street, after a long illness. She was 78 years old.
NEWARK, Dec. 18--Sigmund Dornbusch of 67 South Munn Avenue, East Orange, operator of parking lots in New York, Newark and Miami Beach, Fla., died here today at Beth Israel Hospital. His age was 60.
LONDON, Dec. 18--Britain, grumbling through a second day of gasoline rationing, was warned today to expect an even harder pinch in other oil supplies in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--At the height of the Suez and Hungarian crises more than 1,000 United States jet bombers were on nonstop combat-training missions averaging 8,000 miles each.

Albert S. Bard, one of the oldest civic leaders in years lived and years served, observes his ninetieth birthday today, an occasion deserving salutation and appreciation. For a half-century or more he has been constructively and continuously active in the Citizens Union, the City Club and the Municipal Art Society.

The Ford Motor Company will break new ground in American education by its gift of $6.5 millions from the Ford Motor Company Fund and some $4 millions worth of land and buildings, now owned by the company itself, to establish what is to be called the Dearborn Center.
RAS EL AISH, Egypt, Dec. 18 --A crowd of 2,000 marched through the main streets of Port Said this morning celebrating the arrival of a group of Egyptian police reinforcements from Cairo.
A 4-year-old girl who had been rushed here at dawn yesterday from Stamford, Conn., after she had accidentally taken an overdose of barbiturates died yesterday afternoon.
An aged liner that served as a troop carrier in both world wars will bring the United States Government more than $1,000,000 as she heads for the scrap heap.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18--Moscow renewed its war of words today with Yugoslavia. The Soviet Communist party, through its newspaper Pravda, accused Edvard Kardelj, a Yugoslav Vice President, of having misinterpreted history and strayed from fundamental Communist theories laid down by Marx and Lenin.
A drive by the united labor movement to wipe out shakedown publications operating under the guise of union sponsorship got an assist yesterday from District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn.
TOKYO, Dec. 18--the Japanese Government expected to take office this week will strive to reopen deadlocked negotiations with South Korea in the hope of establishing diplomatic relations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 18-- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today Israel would not allow the Egyptians to return to the Gaza Strip.

The Giants will be watching lots of movies from now until the National Football League championship play-off, on Dec. 30. Starting this morning at the Yankee Stadium, they will view a series of gridiron "whodunits" as part of their preparations for the big event.

Frederick A. Muschenheim, for many years operator of the Astor Hotel, died yesterday in the Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old.
