A court order granted to the New York Yacht Club has opened the way to a challenge for the America's Cup in more realistic yachts than the anachronistic J boats that have sailed for it in the past.

Birmingham, Ala., placed on the marketing calendar yesterday an issue of $6,650,000 of general obligation bonds to finance various public improvements. The bonds will be put up for bidding on Jan. 23. They will come due serially from 1957 to 1987.

PARIS, Dec. 18--The combination of scientific ingenuity and economic necessity is forcing NATO to depend increasingly upon atomic weapons' devilish power to protect Western civilization.

BEEF steaks, featured now in many stores, are particularly apt for this season. No one has time these busy, pre-Christmas days for involved cooking and broiled steaks obviously are among the most delicious quickto-cook meats.
Net income of the New York Central Railroad this year will be about $5.50 a share, Alfred E. Perlman, president, told reporters yesterday. Last year it was $8.03.

The northeastern states asked yesterday for a voice in the development of regulations for the Federal flood insurance program.
THE Museum of Modern Art has staged many larger and more important exhibitions, but it has perhaps never presented a greater contrast than in the two retrospective one-man shows opening today.

Maintenance of the 15-cent subway fare was promised yesterday by Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP)--The Fairway Farm's Tropic King, disqualified from first a week ago, made amends with a photo-finish decision over Fabricator at Tropical Park today. Two riders were hurt in earlier races on today's program, and the filly Gold Vale was destroyed.

Once again the lines on the stock market graphs moved side ways yesterday, neither rails now industrials making an appreciable change.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--Secretary of State Dulles suggested to the Soviet Union today that it move quickly to assure real independence to the countries of East Europe.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18--Wheat futures dropped this morning after the final crop estimate for 1956 had shown a somewhat un expected increase of about 22,000,000 bushels.

A syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler is offering for public subscription today $5,115,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad at prices to yield from 4 to 4.25 per cent.

ANOTHER quiz game, "To Tell the Truth," was added to the television schedule at 9 o'clock last night on Channel 2. It is something of an inverted cousin of "What's My Line?" But if the show could be speeded up its basic gimmick may survive.
Plans are being completed for the annual Yuletide Assembly Ball to take place in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Dec. 29.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The Inaugural Committee issued today the ground rules for venders of souvenirs, food and beverages during the ceremonies surrounding President Eisenhower's second inauguration on Jan. 21.

A hustling New York Knickerbocker team turned in one of its better performances of the season last night.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 18 (AP)-- Darrell Royal, the coach at the University of Washington, today was named head football coach of the University of Texas. Ed Olle was made athletic director. Olle is now the university business director.

LONDON, Dec. 18--Early losses in the stock markets today were either canceled or reduced. Indeed, some shares closed slightly higher on the day although volume of business again was small.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 18 (UP)--Governor Harriman, noting the "strategic position" of the port of Rochester, today called for its speedy development to handle the expanded transshipment business to be produced by the completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 18 (AP)-- Hundreds of Hungarian sports fans shivered in a cold fog around Budapest's battered Western Railway Station today to greet the returning section of Hungary's Olympic squad today.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18-- American and Foreign Power, Inc., has submitted a proposal to the Argentine Government to help solve the nation's electric power crisis by investing $89,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18--The General Assembly increased the size of the International Law Commission today from fifteen to twenty-one members.
GENEVA, Dec. 18--An espionage network headed by Mate Vegh, second secretary of the Hungarian legation in Bern has been smashed, the Swiss Government announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18--Japan today was elected as the eightieth member of the United Nations. The Japanese application already had been approved by the Security Council.

That midseason deal that sent Al (Red) Schoendienst and Jackie Brandt from the St. Louis Cardinals to the Giants last July paid off in more ways than one. In acquiring Schoendienst and Brandt as part of the big fourfor-four transaction, Manager Bill Rigney wound up with the best-fielding second baseman and outfielder in the National League.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 19 --Dr. Hetty Goldman, an archaeologist and the only woman appointed a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study here, was honored tonight on her seventy-fifth birthday.
PASSAIC, N. J., Dec. 19 (AP)-- Assemblyman John Junda, Republican of Passaic County, died today in Passaic General Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 39 years old.

LONDON, Dec. 19--The British Government rejected tonight suggestions that the Western powers offer the Soviet Union a new plan for German unity in exchange for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Hungary.
A group of city teachers is attempting to turn the clock back more than forty years--but only in one respect.
The city's Investigation Commissioner has found the employment of Councilman James J. Murphy by two concerns in the marine industry not in conflict with his official duties.
VIENNA, Dec. 18--The United States is expected to accept more than 21,500 Hungarian refugees as a result of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit to Austrian refugee camps.

There is a kind of heart-warming togetherness at Christmas when the tree in the parlor sheds a rosy glow over the home and the heaps of gifts at its base send out their own tinseled reflections. It is a time for counting blessings, for thankfulness, as we gather with our loved ones.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19--A young Hungarian writer, winner of the Stalin Prize of 1952, has repudiated his work as a Communist.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 --The romantic lead opposite Marlon Brando in "Sayonara" will be played by an American girl of Japanese ancestry with no acting experience. Her name is Niiko Taka; she is 24 years old and a resident of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) --The Government disclosed today that for the first time in two years total profits of United States corporations were running behind those of a year earlier. They may fall half a billion dollars below 1955 profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Drought and retirement of land under the new $1,200,000,000 soil bank program have joined to reduce 1957 winter wheat crop prospects about 15 per cent from this year's harvest, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India said today that he had found an unexpected flexibility in United States policy toward the "changing world."
Civil defense planning in New York State must now emphasize that the enemy would get in the first blow in a war, Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, State Civil Defense Director, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP)--Marion Kerby, retired Broadway actress who was a collector and singer of folk music, died last night while convalescing from recent surgery. She was 79 years old. She had resided here for the last twentyfive years.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 20 --Tanzan Ishibashi was elected today to succeed Ichiro Hatoyama, as Premier of Japan.
Under the leadership of du Pont, which fell 2 points, stock averages declined yesterday in the smallest market since Nov. 23. Sales were 1,990,000 shares, against 2,370,000 on Tuesday.

PARIS, Dec. 19--A United Nations proposal to use British and French ships with foreign crews to clear the Suez Canal met with French rejection today. It had already been declared unsatisfactory by Britain.
Fordham University's basketball team scored an 87-86 victory over Holy Cross in overtime at the Rams' gymnasium on Rose Hill in the Bronx last night.
Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19--The General Assembly elected Iraq. Colombia and Sweden to the Security Council today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19--A Chicago television station today withdrew under fire its plans to present a showing Friday night of "Martin Luther," a motion picture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- A Negro educator contended with tongue in cheek today that most of the 101 Southern Congress members who had signed the Southern Manifesto opposing facial integration in public schools fell into the slow learning category.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Syracuse University's basketball team breezed to an 86-59 victory over Cornell in the first game of a double-header at War Memo rial Auditorium tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19--The United Nations is sounding out large United States banks on the possibility that they will agree to advance the first $10,000,000 needed for clearing the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following prinCipal changes for the week ended Dec. 12:
On pain of fine and imprisonment, fourteen members of the Motormen's Benevolent Association were put on notice yesterday not to call a subway strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 --National Broadcasting Company officials in New York will view tomorrow two closed circuit demonstrations originating in Hollywood of the new $75,000 Ampex video tape recording machines, which were delivered to the network's Hollywood engineers last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The Federal Maritime Board today was advised officially that the demands of the American merchant marine for more cargo-hauling capacity would justify the withdrawal of "as many as sixty-nine" more ships from the mothball fleet.
THE man chosen by the United Nations to direct the clearing of the Suez Canal probably has worked on some of the heaviest jobs tackled by the heavy construction engineers of the world.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP)--Continued growth of the national economy, with a 10 per cent increase in domestic new car sales and "substantially full employment," are predicted for 1957 by Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors.
Directors of the Corn Products Refining Company have declared a quarterly dividend of 37 cents, payable on Jan. 25. It paid 35 cents in previous quarters.
WHEN the patter of little feet seems like a din during the coming week mothers may wrap their youngsters warmly in mufflers and mittens and squire them to the nearest museum, library or theatre.
Sales and net earnings of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries rose to record highs in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Labor's top leadership set up a program today to expedite the resettlement, employment and unionization of Hungarian refugees.
TRENTON, Dec. 19--Elber Cooper Lucas, a 40-year-old handyman, admitted today having set five church fires here, one of which cost three lives.
All records for attendance, wagering and revenue to the twenty-four states where parimutuel betting is legal were smashed in 1956. That was established yesterday by an Associated Press survey.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's directors paved the way yesterday for onetenth of next year's record expansion budget of $2,500,000,000.

Ski Sketch: John J. Clair Jr., the chairman of the 1956 United States Olympic Ski Games Committee, made his first attempt at skiing on the Hillcrest golf course in Jamalca, near his home, many years ago. He stepped into a pair of Northland pine seven-footers with toe straps and went skimming over the fairway toward the eighteenth green.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Dec. 19--Nassau County's new $4,000,000 "maximum security" jail was dedicated this morning at ceremonies in its 200-seat chapel.

The eleventh hour Christmas shopping is widely deplored. The clerks in the stores do not like it. After the many days' rush they regard tardy shoppers as a species of monster, lifted bodily from a personal nightmare. The drivers of de
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Eight Eastern railroads have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for an immediate increase of 5 per cent in first-class and coach fares.
The American Red Cross has earmarked $1,200,000 more for Hungarian victims of Communist oppression.
Columbia threw its hat into the ring as a top contender for the Ivy League basketball title last night by decisively defeating Dartmouth, last season's champion of the circuit.
NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 19 (UP) --Alan Cann, a Syracuse fullback, was hobbled with injuries today that will cause him to miss several days practice between now and the Cotton Bowl game.

In his first press conference since the recent North Atlantio Council meeting Secretary Dulles turned thumbs down on a move that has been gathering strength in Washington and elsewhere to force a major revision of American foreign and military policies.
THIS week, Roy and Ede Halvorson flew into New York in their own two-motored plans, a fitting symbol of their success in a rather unusual business--fresh frozen Christmas trees.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 19-- Communist China and Burma failed to find a permanent settlement of their controversial border problem during the visit here of Premier Chou En-lai.

Miss Jill Gloria Weldon will make her debut on Dec. 28 at a supper dance to be given in the Ambassador by her parents, Mrs. Nathan Milstein of 1010 Fifth Avenue and Henry H. Weldon of 775 Park Avenue and Amagansett, L. I.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19-- Ned Ransom Powley, former president and board chairman of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, died at his home in Hillsborough yesterday after a short illness. His age was 71.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 19--An army court martial that has divided the Korean armed forces began today.
Between Nov. 15 and Dec. 14, the aggregate short interest in New York Stock Exchange stocks rose 68,294 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 19--Britain proposed today limited self-government for Cyprus under a strong Governor.
The official spokesmen for organized industry in the metropolitan area recommended yesterday that United States employers stay in the International Labor Organization.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 19--After five years of trying to cope in ordinary ways with an exceptionally fast-growing school population here the Board of Education today advocated a major expansion program.
WARSAW, Dec. 19--Eight Yugoslav officials arrived here today to exchange ideas with Polish Communist leaders on the critical state of Eastern European affairs.
Checking account turnover in November was 4 per cent greater than in October in New York City and 3 per cent in the rest of the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Two contributors are waiting for the word that this year's response to the Neediest Cases appeal has exceeded last year's, when the total set a record.
Four up and four to go. This about sums up the Christmas sales picture at New York City's major department stores.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 19-- Iraq's chief opposition politician was sentenced today to three years imprisonment at hard labor after a court-martial trial that began Saturday.
Alfred R. Bachrach, accounting concern executive, was elected president of Congregation Emanu-El last night. He succeeds Saul F. Dribben, textile merchant, who had held the post since 1949.

There are 2,700,000 TV sets in distribution pipelines, it was estimated yesterday by television manufacturers. That means they are being held unsold by manufacturers, distributors and stores. Manufacturers call this number "uncomfortably heavy" although they emphasize that inventories are not alarming.

The National Association of Manufacturers yesterday criticized they Eisenhower Administration's spending record in the last two years. The association called the record "disappointing" in view of President Eisenhower's "firm and vigorous" pledges of economy and efficiency.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 19--More than 5,000 Negroes packed tightly around the Johannesburg drill hall today in vain hope of attending the preparatory examination of treason allegations against 152 persons.

The Princeton University freshman hockey team made excellent use of its superior size and speed to defeat St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., 5--1, in their annual Christmas vacation game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 19--The world's top amateur tennis player, Ken Rosewall, joined his Australian Davis Cup team-mates today in their preparations for defense of the trophy against the United States in the challenge round next week.

A joint labor-management committee reported yesterday that it had effected the peaceful settlement of nearly 100 jurisdictional disputes and other labor differences that had threatened to halt shows at the New York Coliseum.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points up to 4 points off yesterday. Business was slow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Arthur S. Flemming, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, will decide Wednesday whether to establish Government priorities for steel plate required for the building of oil tankers.

Consumers can force changes in farmers' growing habits--and fast. That was proved when the Department of Agriculture announced recently a 50 per cent cut in 1957 price supports for three varieties of flue-cured tobacco.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 19 (AP)--Wake Forest's doughty Deacons rallied from a 7-point deficit in the last half tonight to whip Auburn, 58--48, and repeat as the Carrousel Basketball Classic winner.

Governor Harriman said last night he would demand in the forthcoming Legislature that more public hearings be held on important legislative proposals. He premised to end "government behind closed doors in Albany." **** [ Possible missing text ] ****
The State Power Authority voted 3 to 2 yesterday to sell 239,000 kilowatts of power to be developed on the St. Lawrence River to the Reynolds Metals Company, an aluminum producer.

EVERYONE who sees "Speaking of Murder," which opened at the Royale last evening, will learn at least one good lesson. Don't have a soundproof, moth-proof storage vault in the library. Or, if you do, don't have Brenda de Banzie, the British blonde, slinking around the house in smart frocks and taking over control of your menage.

Oil imports in the week ended last Friday dropped markedly, reflecting largely the diversion of Middle East supplies to Europe. According to the American petroleum Institute, imports of crude oil and products averaged 1,226,500 barrels a day, or 457,900 a day below the 1,684,400 for the preceding week.

SEVENTY years ago hostesses spent hours making rolled sandwiches, tying each with a narrow strip of ribbon. In finding better things to do with their time, women have replaced such fussy tidbits at late-afternoon gatherings with something inelegantly and descriptively known as the "dip" or the "dunk."
CHICAGO, Dec. 19--Wheat futures generally advanced today on the Board of Trade. The oldcrop deliveries showed the most strength, and the maturing December option gained the most ground.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The arrest, for trial on charge of contempt of court by the Federal judge who issued the writs, of sixteen citizens of Tennessee involves some grave constitutional questions. These concern the power of a court to:

This morning we who live and work in New York City have the pleasant opportunity to greet the arrival in our metropolis of Prime Minister Nehru of India. We are sure that all New Yorkers will join us in extending a hearty welcome to the Prime Minister, the distinguished leader of a great democracy.

Georg Solti, Heitor Villa-Lobos, Franco Autori and Paul Paray will conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony during the four-week period, March 14 through April 17. The programs originally were scheduled for the late Guido Cantelli.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 (AP)-- A Federal grand jury here will examine evidence in the underworld theft of valuable geological maps from Gulf Oil Corporation.
"Uncle Willie," a new comedy starring Menasha Skulnik, will have its Broadway debut at the Golden Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
WEST TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 19--An Air Force transport's plane with a radical new feature was demonstrated under wraps here today.
The Giants, launching preparations for their Dec. 30 championship playoff meeting with the Chicago Bears, toiled earnestly yesterday, but it was mostly skullwork.

California announced yesterday plans to borrow $85,000,000 in the public market on Jan. 16. At that time, the state will offer bond issues to finance various public improvements. Some of the securities will come due on Aug. 1 from 1958 to 1977 and others on May 1 from 1959 to 1983.
UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Dec. 119--The month-old United Nations appeal to rush relief to Hungary has brought in a modest total of $82,000 from ten governments, it was reported today.

Control of one of the city's leading real estate companies, Pease Elliman, Inc., changed hands yesterday. A group of financiers and business men purchased the fifty-nine-year-old business from Samuel R. Firestone, who has been president of the company.

Spared by bipartisanship from self-inquiry into its members' business interests, the City Council has graciously committed to the city's Commissioner of Investigation the powers we believe he already had to investigate Councilmen.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 19-- Seven Swedes with no previous experience in government were launched today as the temporary rulers of this city of 180,000 volatile Egyptians.
North Carolina, undefeated in five games, will oppose New York University at Madison Square Garden tonight in the feature contest of a college basketball double-header.

Five two-family dwellings will be erected at the southeast corner of Carpenter Avenue and East 229th Street in the Bronx by Agnelo Mambrino Sr., builder, who has bought a vacant parcel, of land there from the Bridemac Construction Company.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (UP)-- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest producer, announced today it would purchase the Rotary Electric Steel Company of Detroit.
Mayor Wagner made a plea yesterday for a permissive, rather than a mandatory, houseto-house check of registered voters under the state's Permanent Personal Registration Law.

Mrs. Carol Fox Fuhrman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Fox of 101 Central Park West, was married yesterday afternoon in Greenwich, Conn., to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger of 1115 Fifth Avenue and Hillandale, Stamford, Conn.
The insurance industry indicated yesterday that it would initiate a court test of Attorney General Jacob K. Javits' ruling that labor-management welfare funds could self-insure.

A Coast Guard hearing has been scheduled for 10 A.M. today at 80 Lafayette Street to determine the cause of the collision between the freighters Alcoa Pilgrim and the African Star. The ore-laden ships collided here Tuesday night.
EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 19 (AP)--The police arrested a bachelor physician today on a charge of having murdered a wealthy widow who died at 81 years of age in her lonely mansion six years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, opposed today further tightening of tho controls, now found to be largely ineffective, on campaign contributions and spending.
Tha Rev. Russell Stevenson, returned here from Egypt yesterday with pictures purporting to show the "scorched earth" policy of the withdrawing Israeli Army in the Sinai peninsula.
Shelley Winters, who had a supporting role in a 1948 motion picture titled "A Double Life," will be the star when she recreates the same role in a television adaptation of the film next month.

Advertising budgets will go to new records in 1957--at least 10 per cent above those for 1956-- and they will be more closely examined, Printers' Ink, weekly trade paper covering advertising, selling and marketing; predicts in its latest issue, out today.
OSLO, Dec. 19 (AP)--Standard Oil Company (N.J.) announced plans today for construction of a $30,000,000 oil refinery plant and unloading facilities for big tankers in Norway.

PARIS, Dec. 19--Christian Pineau, French Foreign Minister, declared today that the desire of the United States to maintain its freedom of action in certain parts of the world was "hardly compatible" with the need for common policy in the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Five Republican members of Congress from the Midwestern Corn Belt raised anew today the prospect of another major farm fight next year.

THE State of Maine has decided to come back into the National Sports and Vacation Show and, having decided, is leaping in with hob-nailed, logrolling boots. Maine's aim apparently is to shame the eleven other states that will be represented at the Coliseum from Feb. 15 to 24.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa and Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday appeared in the guise of Santa Claus, and Mayor Wagner was requested, in rhyme, to do so.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The White House has told Joseph P. Adams that he will not be reappointed to the Civil Aeronautics Board, informed sources said today.
Work on nineteen attractive apartment houses for middle-income families is progressing on the site of a post-war Quonset hut colony in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
DUBLIN, Dec. 18--The Government of Prime Minister John A. Costello is proceeding cautiously in its attempt to end Irish Republican Army raids on Northern Ireland.
Contract negotiations between tugboat workers and the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association have been recessed until Jan. 2.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 19 --Pakistan's Prime Minister said today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser was dissipating Moslem sympathy for Egypt.

BILL RUSSELL signed a contract yesterday to play professional basketball with the Boston Celtics. The only person in the world whom this move could have surprised was Avery Brundage. The long, lean Russell was the star of the American Olympic quintet at Melbourne and has a gold medal to prove his excellence.

The Department of Agriculture has just reported that total crop production for the United States in 1956 was at a level 6 per cent above the average for the base period 1947-49. This makes the third time that the index of crop production has touched that mark, the previous cases being 1948 and 1955.
"Sara" came in from the sea at dusk yesterday. The largest warship in the world was a happy ship. On board were scores of wives, children and sweethearts.
A gunman wanted in Akron, Ohio, on three homicide charges was shot and captured in th Bronx last night, a few minute after he assertedly had tried to hold up a taxi driver.
VIENNA, Dec. 19--Premier Janos Kadar of Hungary said today that his regime was now virtually in a position to meet "provocations" of rebels without the aid of Soviet troops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- A Hungarian refugee said today that 30,000 of his countrymen had been deported to the Soviet Union since the start of the Hungarian revolt
DALLAS, Dec. 19--A Federal district judge ruled today that the public schools here could not be compelled "at the present time" to integrate whites and Negroes in the same classes.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ballet to the Mozart "Di vertimiento No. 15" had its local premi re last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center, Maria Tallchief made her first appearance of the season in the "Pas de Dix," everybody danced like a million dollars, and it was quite an evening.

LONDON, Dec. 19--Government funds extended their advance here today, while industrial shares continued irregular. Business dwindled before the Christmas holidays and in view of the Mideast uncertainties.
BUDAPEST, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The Christmas shopping season is in full swing in Budapest, and it is a scramble even to get a Christmas tree.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 19-- Harry R. Wellman, Professor Emeritus of Marketing at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack today in the State Hospital in Concord. His age was 75.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- There are few men in the world today who can get 500 Washington reporters out of bed to asks questions at 9:15 o'clock in the morning, but Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India did it today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19--The Yugoslavs counter-attacked today in the latest war of words with Moscow.

The resignation of five directors of Loew's, Inc., four of whom are vice presidents, has been demanded by Joseph Tomlinson, who with 250,000 shares, or five per cent of the stock, is the largest single stockholder in the motion picture producing comparry. If these resignations are not forthcoming, it was indicated, a proxy fight might result.
Thousands of gifts were added to Santa's pack yesterday for those who might otherwise be forgotten at Christmas.

The Hercules Powder Company and Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain have announced the formation of a jointly owned company for the manufacture of methyl mathacrylate, a chemical used in the production of plastics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--Following is the transcript issued by the Indian Embassy of the report of the news conference held today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India:

BABY'S first Christmas, whether he is one day old or three hundred and sixty-four, is generally the signal for a showering down of lush gifts. Many donors, however, neglect the fact that a baby cares not a bit for his first Christmas and his mother cares very much.
New York private nursing homes that care for welfare recipients will be required to give proof that they do not practice discrimination if they wish to be on the Department of Welfare list.

It has happened before; and, so long as there is an Electoral College operating under the existing rules, it will doubtless happen again. The first time was in 1796, when a Federalist elector who was supposed to vote for John Adams cast his ballot instead for Thomas Jefferson--leading one of his constituents to remark petulantly: "I chuse him to act, not to think."

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 19 --The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was warned today by the Louisiana Attorney General to suspend operations in the state or face criminal charges.

Federal and state inheritance taxes will take $6,088,200 of the $10,186,299 net estate left by William Woodward Jr., according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yester day. Mr. Woodward, sportsman and financier, was shot by his wife, Mrs. Ann E. Woodward at their home in Oyster Bay, L. I., the night of Oct. 30, 1955. She fired in the belief that he was an intruder.

The final issues of Collier's magazine and the Woman's Home Companion go on the newstands today. Neither contains any indication that the two magazines have been shut down, and ironically, both carry articles on how best to use free time.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Dec. 19 (UP)--Sugar Ray Robinson submitted today to the same electronic test that Gene Fullmer did yesterday, and learned that his punches appeared to be as hard as the challenger's, although not so fast. Robinson will defend his middleweight title against Fullmer at Madison Square Garden Jan. 2.
HARTFORD, Dec. 19--Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that he would ask the State Legislature to replace the local court system with a system of state-operated courts staffed by full-time judges.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold gave Britain and France today the United Nations program for clearing the Suez Canal.

WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Dec. 20 --Miss Barbara Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Rosen of New Haven, was married here this evening to E. Robert Goodkind, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Goodkind of Lawrence, L.I.
At a special meeting yesterday in Dallas, Tex., stockholders of Braniff Airways approved the issuance of $40,000,000 of 4 per cent equipment mortgage sinking fund bonds due July 1, 1976.

Reflecting a gain in sales, net earnings of the Piper Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 increased to $2,554,000 from $1,400,826 in the preceding year. Net sales totaled $25,084,000, compared with $16,812,804 the year before.
A man described by the Government as "a brilliant chemical research scientist" and a multimillionaire was accused yesterday of illegal dealings with Communist nations.
ALTHOUGH Menasha Skulnik is not down on the program as one of the authors of "Uncle Willie," it is hard to tell where the line should be drawn.
Plans for a giant chain of scientific "eyes" to track the first man-made space satellite were announced here last night by the Navy Department.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 20 (AP)--The United States Air Force has flown the last of its big Globemaster transports out of the Antarctic because fuel is short and the weather warm.

Because there is no such thing as a tie game when the championship is involved, the Dec. 30 play-off between the Giants and the Chicago Bears at the Yankee Stadium will be decided, if necessary, by "sudden death," in accordance with National Football League rules.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A Federal court of appeals set aside today the conviction of Harvey O'Connor, author, for contempt of Congress.

Commodity futures trading was featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices closed generally down. Sugar, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes and copper declined; rubber and tin rose, and price movements for hides, wool, coffee and zinc were mixed.
A revolution is in progress in the book stacks of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays Robert Leader from spreading sunshine.
The names of artists who will perform for the third International Press Ball of the Foreign Press Association have been announced by Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, chairman of the ball committee.

Sales and earnings of Dresser Industries, Inc., last year were the highest in the company's history. The company supplies equipment and technical services for the oil, gas, chemical and electronic industries.
Stocks returned yesterday to the levels of a week ago, The New York Times combined average dropping 2.21 points to 328.30.
CAIRO, Dec. 20--Haim Nahoum, Chief Rabbi of Egypt, said today that no foreign government, and especially not Israel, was authorized to speak on behalf of the Jews of Egypt.
MADRID, Dec. 20--The network of oil supplies that United States defense authorities are building across Spain received today its first shipment, 42,000 barrels of Diesel oil.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 --St. Paul's School, the defender, defeated Deerfield Academy, 7--0, as all four seeded teams won their first-round tests in the ninth annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- United States officials say they have not found a legal way to provide Poland with economic assistance.
A large and distinguished gathering attended the Gala Mediterranee last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WARSAW, Dec. 20--Poland adopted today methods once used by Yugoslavia to salvage the economy from Soviet-dictated practices.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 20 (AP) --The Greek Cypriote underground called today for a twenty-four hour general strike tomorrow to protest against Britain's offer of limited selfrule to rebellious Cyprus.
State Republican leaders planned to come to grips today with the problem of picking a successor to Senator-elect Jacob K. Javits for his unexpired term as Attorney General.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices moved 7 points up to 2 points off (35 cents a bale higher to 10 cents lower).
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed yesterday that an international agency be created to answer the need for development in the Middle East.
HAVANA, Dec. 20--Sporadic terrorism flared in Cuba during last twenty-four hours as the Government guarded against any further revolutionary outbreaks.
HOMEMAKERS who keep up with the architects will guess at a glance that this distinctive low-slung house was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 20--Dr. Samuel H. Anderson, a leading physicist at the Fort Monmouth Signal Corps Laboratory for twenty-four years until his retirement two years ago, died early today in Fitkin Memorial Hospital. His age was 76.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 20-- The Iraqi Government published today an announcement that five Opposition politicians had been court-martialed.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP)--Bennie Sorensen, a 22year-old native of Copenhagen, Denmark, completed a riding triple on Valley View Farm's Chateau in the sixth race today before a crowd of 6,979 at Tropical Park.
Last-minute shoppers, and people trying to get an early start for the Christmas weekend, are expected to crowd all transportation in and out of the city beginning today.
Business will be heavy today along the city's "luxury liner row," because thousands of persons wish to spend Christmas in New York or away from it.

Today, almost two months after the outbreak of the Hungarian revolution, an impasse seems to have been reached in that country. The mass murder by Soviet troops seems to have ended organized opposition in large part or entirely.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20--In an otherwise quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade, a selloff materialized in the new crop wheat positions. These dipped as much as a couple of cents on both the July and September deliveries but subsequently recov ered from the early lows.
A loan equivalent to $20,000,000 in various currencies for expansion of steel production in India was announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

WEST NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 20--Seventeenth-century pomp and ceremony attended the christening today of replicas of the three sailing ships that brought the first English settlers to the New World in 1607.

The British must have known when they made their offer of a new Constitution and limited self-government for Cyprus that it would be rejected by the Greek Cypriotes and --what is equally important--the Greeks.

It looks like an interest rate war in Florida. The Florida National Bank of Jacksonville said yesterday it would raise its interest rate on savings to 3 per cent on Jan. 7. That is not unusual, but it was the second increase in nine days.
A new Tweed plan to reorganize the state's court system was made public yesterday. It will be officially put before Governor Harriman and the Legislature today.
Joseph P. Blitz, builder and realty investor, has purchased the Ritz Theatre at 225 West Forty-eighth Street from John Minary in a deal negotiated by Herbert Charles Co., broker.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20--The Russian Republic of the Soviet Union has decided to crack down on its hooligans.

"Trapeze" was voted the top money-making motion picture of the 1955-56 season in the annual poll of independent film theatre owners and buyers conducted by the Independent Film Journal, a trade publication. The results were announced yesterday.
The management consultant is entering marketing, Arthur B. Dougall, chairman of Stewart, Dougall Associates, Inc., and of Crossley, S-D Surveys, Inc., said yesterday.
North Carolina's Sidewalks of New York basketball team ran into unexpected opposition from a lightly held New York University quintet at Madison Square Garden last night.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UP)-- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored twice tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to their fifth straight victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4--2, before a crowd of 13,577 at the Forum.

Gaspar Ortega will try to make it two in a row over a former welterweight champion of the world, Tony De Marco, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fighters will meet in a scheduled ten-rounder, a return of their match of Nov. 23.
The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that it had begun to mail a total of $6,079,324 to 425 affiliated agencies. This was described as the largest amount in the funds history.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--A General Assembly committee approved today a compromise plan for raising the first $10,000,000 of the cost of the United Nations Emergency Force in Egypt.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) --Villanova used a tight zone defense and an explosive fast break tonight to turn back Indiana, 79--69, before 3,884 in the second game of a doubleheader at the University of Pennsylvania Palestra. La Salle upset North Carolina State in the opener, 83--76, for a sweep of the twin bill by Philadelphia teams.

Directors of the Binks Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of painting equipment, declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $1 a share, a 5 per cent stock dividend and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Jan. 14.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 20--In the State Street Congregational Church here today, Miss AnnaLouise Watkins was married to Peter Betts Hubball of St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--In anticipation of European demands, the Administration has taken steps to help the coal industry make emergency shipments abroad.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 20 --Ted Schroeder arrived today from California and joined the chorus of tennis experts who foresee Australia's retaining the Davis Cup by a comfortable margin.

While India's Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was keeping official engagements here yesterday, his daughter put in a busy day following her own interests. They ranged from purely feminine pursuits to visits to two welfare enterprises.
ALBANY, Dec. 20--Legislation forbidding newspapers to carry "help wanted" advertisements that limit applications to persons under a certain age will be presented in the forthcoming session.
TRENTON, Dec. 20--The State Legislature sent to Gov. Robert B. Meyner today a proposal designed to broaden the powers of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Representative John Bell Williams of Mississippi labeled as "meaningless nonsense" today a report by a Negro educator that had criticized signers of the Southern Manifesto and a House subcommittee that had investigated the Washington school system.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 20--The police fired on a crowd of about 1,000 Negro demonstrators today outside the courthouse where allegations of treason against 153 persons were being heard.
The Columbia Broadcasting System demonstrated tape-recorded television pictures here yesterday that in many respects had the clarity and sharpness of a live broadcast.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 20 --Jubilant Montgomery Negroes decided tonight to end their long boycott tomorrow morning and ride buses again, without the restrictions of racial segregation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 716,652 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

"Protective Custody" will reach Broadway after all. The Howard Richardson-William Berney melodrama, which was withdrawn last Saturday in Washington, will open next Friday night at the Ambassador.
More contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund were recorded yesterday than on any day since the annual appeal began on Dec. 9.

Most of the New York Yacht Club cruise next summer will be within Long Island Sound, members learned last night at the annual meeting in the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse. Ports of call will include Greenwich, Duck Island, Mystic and Shelter Island, with Block Island and Newport the farthest away.
LONDON, Dec. 20--The Conservative party's complacency over popular support of its Suez policy in Britain was shaken today.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 20-- Two symbols of colonial power were yielded by the British today as the British-French forces speeded their withdrawal from Egyptian soil.

OVEN-READY turkeys, which many chains offer now for from 43 to 47 cents a pound, depending on size, are most popular offering for Christmas dinner. And, as the City Department of Markets has pointed out, the birds cost several pennies a pound less than they did last Christmas. The chains, for example, are sellins large turkeys for 4 cents a pound less than last year at this time.

Calendars are keeping up with the times. Gains in the use of calendars in recent years have kept pace with the nation's expansion in business and the increase in population and new homes. Some 300,000,000 a year are used in the United States.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India called last night for an end of the "cold war," the abandonment of the world system of military alliances and the withdrawal of all troops stationed in foreign lands.

UPPER Hudson Valley winter hunters have started chivvying the European hare again, a sport that many of them hold to be better than fox hunting.

Dr. Moses A. Bluestone, a Coney Island physician whose patients ranged from young beach visitors with cuts to a 750-pound sideshow performer, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 61 years old.
One empty railroad car that slipped off the tracks in the Jersey meadows before dawn yesterday caused a tangle that delayed 20,000 persons.

ALBANY, Dec. 20--The State Industrial Commissioner ordered today a minimum wage of $1 an hour for workers in the retail trades in this state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Consumer supplies of pork in 1957 will be about 3 per cent less than this year if results of the Department of Agriculture's farm survey are borne out.

IN contrast to the shops, art galleries during the weeks immediately surrounding Christmas offer slender fare. But some of them take the opportunity to show work by younger and less known artists at this time.
ALBANY, Dec. 20--The State Public Works Department set machinery in motion today for the construction of $42,979,469 worth of highway projects.
Miss Eleanor Crosby and Miss Sarnia Hayes were honored last evening at a dinner dance in the Georgian Suite at 1A East Seventy-seventh Street.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP)--Buddy Parker today turned down an offer to coach the Detroit Lions again in 1957. But in a brief statement he left the door open for a possible seventh season at the helm.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 20 (AP) --State Senator Joseph K. Carson Jr., a former member of the United States Maritime Commission, died in his sleep early today of a heart attack. He had observed his sixty-fifth birthday yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 20 --Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Windisch have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Amanda Windisch, to Charles Hilary King Jr., son of Mrs. Russell Grace D'Oench of Salisbury, Conn., and Mr. King of Atlanta, Ga.

Paul C. Smith, president and board chairman of Crowell-Collier, said yesterday that company officers were cooperating with the S.E.C. investigation. He said they were confident it "will disclose nothing unfavorable to the company."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 20 --Pakistan welcomed Communist China's Premier today with 5,000 schoolchildren, a few hundred colored balloons, a couple of reluctant pigeons and a careful measure of friendliness.
A series of price increases on synthetic yarns will probably lead to higher prices for synthetic fabrics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A Civil Aeronautics Board order revoking the licenses of four irregular airlines was upheld today by the Federal Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today estimated United States sugar consumption in 1957 at 8,800,000 short tons. This compares with 9,000,000 tons allotted for sale this year.

The Federal Reserve bought another $240,150,000 in Government short-term securities in the week ended Wednesday, raising to about $1,000,000,000 its additions to the money supply since the end of October.
The policy of greater independence toward which a resurgent Japan has been moving will doubtless receive further impetus as a result of the election of Tanzan Ishibashi as the new Premier.

Major steel producers put scattered price increases into effect yesterday. Industry spokesmen warned that the increases might become much more general in the next few weeks as a result of higher wage, freight and scrap bills.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee set out today to force "appropriate action" against the Soviet Union by the United Nations for deportations of Hungarians.
TOKYO, Dec. 20--In his personal complexities Japan's new Premier is a true product of his country's blended culture.

For his second week in command of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Leonard Bernstein had a meatier program than for his first. Once again he took over the arrangement planned by the late Guido Cantelli, whose concerts these were to be, and this time he dealt entirely with music worthy of his interests and ours.

The explosive drama that we have been witnessing in Hungary these past few weeks has rocked the conscience of the civilized world. Its effects have only begun to be felt; and no one can yet foresee their conclusion.

WHEN International House was opened to forty Hun garian refugees through the good offices of the Ford Foundation the other day, Miss Alcine Guilfoyle of Quitman, Ga., was at the reception desk. She is a student at Teachers College working for an English instructor's license, and lives in the House.

TYRONE, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP)-- Alden Roach, president of the Columbia-Geneva Steel Division of the United States Steel Corporation, was killed tonight in the fiery mountainside crash of a corporation-owned twin-engine plane near here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India agreed today that their talks had strengthened friendship and understanding between their two countries.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 20-- Plans for the construction in Stamford Harbor of one of the largest yacht basins on the northeast coast were announced here today.

Sharp declines in factory sales of refrigerators, standard electric ranges, freezers and electric water heaters this year will be partially offset by big gains in newer large household appliances.
DUBLIN, Dec. 20--The belief is growing here that the Irish Republican Army has embarked on a determined campaign to unite Ireland.
A revised tanker charter proposal made by the Military Sea Transportation Service apparently has prove more attractive than the earlier version of the proposal.

Skiers were wondering yesterday whether they would be heading for the hills or heading for home tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 20--The Rev. John A. Burke, ecclesiastical director of Britain's Roman Catholic Film Institute, said today that he could "see no reason why adult Catholics should not see" the motion picture "Baby Doll."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20-- The radio propaganda war among Arab countries has suddenly been critically intensified.

The Union Electric Company has contracted to sell its Poplar Ridge Coal Company subsidiary to the Peabody Coal Company. Transfer of the subsidiary to Peabody is expected early in 1957, the utility said yesterday. The price to be paid by Peabody was not disclosed.
Mayor Wagner yesterday signed the local law providing for permanent personal registration of the city's voters.

BOSTON, Dec. 20--The, Massachusetts Commissioner of Banks has moved to block a merger of the First National Bank of Boston in Suffolk County and the Granite Trust Company of suburban Quincy in Norfolk County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A leading liberal Southern Democrat took a stand today against a Northern Democratic-urban Republican coalition that is marshaling for an attempt to harden the Senate's anti-filibuster rule.

Two new films open at firstrun theatres today. "The King and Four Queens," a romantic drama starring Clark Gable and Eleanor Parker, arrives at the Mayfair. The United Artists release was directed by Raoul Walsh and produced by David Hempstead for Russ-FieldGabco.
The Board of Education yesterday awarded the largest single contract for a school building in its history.

The master of the freighter Alcoa Pilgrim testified yesterday that his pilot signaled three times to indicate a passing maneuver before the Pilgrim collided with the African Star. The collision occurred Tuesday night off Ellis Island.

A Queens County jury early yesterday morning acquitted James T. Ryan, a suspended patrolman, of charges of grand larceny, kidnapping and assault in connection with an $1,800 payroll robbery in Queens last March 23.
LONDON, Dec. 20--British Government funds and industrial stocks showed minor gains in the stock market today. Turnover was small.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20-- President Eisenhower illuminated a national community Christmas tree today in the hope that an enduring spirit of Christmas would bring mankind to a better world.

TELEVISION moved ahead briskly last night: Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy appeared together for the first time on Channel 4.
EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 20 (AP)--Scotland Yard ordered gravediggers tonight to exhume the bodies of two rich old women in cemeteries near this Victorian seaside town.
It's tournament time with a vengeance in college basketball. Dozens of carnivals involving hundreds of varsity quintets are on the docket during the holiday period.
Sales finance companies borrowed $120,000,000 from the larger New York City banks last week, contributing to a $218,000,000 rise in loans to business.

VIENNA, Dec. 20--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, relying on the American political handbook, made a hit today in Buregenland. He toured the feudal villages of the Austrian province adjoining Hungary, shaking hands and kissing babies as he addressed Hungarian refugees and their "selfless" Austrian hosts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- A House Armed Services subcommittee branded today as "unlawful" a Navy directive allowing the award of a contract when a Navy negotiator thought the proposed prices were reasonable.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The National Labor Relations Board today found unionists at fault in a pitched battle with towboat owners on the Mississippi River.
Charges of "give-away" and "worse than Dixon-Yates" rang out yesterday as state power contracts with the Reynolds Metal Company and the Niagara-Mohawk Power Corporation came under attack.

City officials are planning to ask the state for an "equitable share" of the proposed $250,000,000 bond issue for expanding State University facilities.

Rabbi Elias L. Solomon of Congregation Shaare Zedek, Broadway near Ninety-third Street, long a leader in local and national Jewish activities, died yesterday in Mount Siani Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 77. He resided at 875 West End Avenue.
The marriage of Mrs. Aileen Plunket of Dublin to Valerian Stux-Rybar took place here Wednesday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Church, Methodist. The Rev. John Bartle Everts performed the ceremony.
BERLIN, Dec. 20--East German Communists are playing workers against students apparently to curb freedom of thought in colleges, and also in factories.

ATLANTA, Dec. 20 (UP)--The academic qualifications of a Negro seeking to enter the University of Georgia Law School were "never taken up" before the Negro's application was rejected, a Federal judge said today.
PARIS, Dec. 20--Almost in spite of itself, the French National Assembly voted today in favor of Premier Guy Mollet's foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The United States informed LatinAmerican countries today that, while West Europe in the next few months would suffer petroleum shortages, Latin America generally would be spared because of tanker shifts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20-- A multi-million dollar crude oil pipe line, with a capacity in excess of 500,000 barrels a day, will be built from Delaware Bay to this area's refineries by a new corporation, Cape Pipe Line Company.
The question of a successor to Lou Little as head coach at Columbia remained undecided last night after he received a campus tribute from 500 friends and associates.
TORONTO, Dec. 20 (Canadian Press)--H.C. Hindmarsh, president of The Toronto Star, died early tonight in a hospital after suffering a heart seizure in his office. He was 69 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--The General Assembly completed debate today on two proposals designed to expand and reallocate the non-permanent seats on the Security Council.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 20-- The Moroccan Government has asked France to accept the jurisdiction of the World Court at The Hague to settle the dispute over the arrest of five Algerian nationalists Oct. 22.
TOKYO, Dec. 21--Tanzan Ishibashi, 72-year-old economist who became Premier of Japan yesterday, seems to have most of the country behind him.
VIENNA, Dec. 20--Hungary enacted today a decree under which persons who disturb the public order and "especially production" can be jailed without trial.
LONDON, Dec. 20--Britain agreed today to the use of her salvage vessels, including units of the Royal Navy, under the United Nations flag and protection in the clearance of the Suez Canal.
THE item of chief interest on last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center was George Balanchine's "Allegro Brillante," which was newly added to the repertoire last season.
LONDON, Dec. 20--Sir Anthony Eden forcefully denied today any prior knowledge by Britain of Israel's attack on Egypt.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20-- Howard M. Gifft, Professor of Engineering and newly appointed Dean of Faculty at Cornell University, died at his home here today of a coronary thrombosis. He was 48 years old and lived at 1 Parkway Place.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Federal Government today began an investigation of transactions in $4,000,000 of securities issued in 1955 and 1956 by the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20--The United States told the United Nations today that it would "thoughtfully consider" new Soviet proposals for world disarmament.
Only thirteen persons have been disqualified out of 141,686 checked for state employment during three years' operations of the State Security Risk Law.
Bad weather beclouded the start of Christmas travel yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 21--George M.Stevens of 296 Primrose Avenue, a retired lumber dealer, died last night in the Hospital for Special Surgery, New York, after a long illness. His age was 84.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21(UP) -- Walter Wolfner, managing director of the Chicago Cardinals tonight charged Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League with "unfair tactics" and "censorship."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Hungarian Government ordered the Budapest police today to start an immediate drive against black marketers operating in the capital's streets.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 21-- William J. Sullivan, former City Court prosecutor here and judge of the Westport Town Court, died last night in Norwalk Hospital. He was stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage at his office here two hours before his death. His age was 47.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India expressed hope today for elimination of the Iron and Bamboo Curtains so that "distorted views will not prevail."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21--Deborah Kerr, under terms of a new multiple-picture contract with Twentieth Century-Fox, will co-star in "Love Affair," to be produced for the studio by the Jerry Wald Company. The picture will be directed by Leo McCarey and is scheduled to go before the cameras Feb. 14.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 21 --The new Ellenville National Bank opened its doors today, restoring the Yuletide spirit for many of its 8,500 depositors. Business was brisk.

MONTREAL, Dec. 21 (AP)-- The Donaldson Line reported today it would start a new through steamship service to Canadian Great Lakes ports with the opening of navigation next spring.

LONDON, Dec. 21--Governnient funds led another general recovery on the stock markets here today. A shortage of offerings accentuated price increases.
Twenty-one artists, who last week criticized the Frank Lloyd Wright-designed museum building under construction on Fifth Avenue, were told yesterday that their criticisms had no foundation.

Pink, white and silver decorations provided a sparkling setting for the 105 young women who were presented to society last evening at the twenty-first annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball. Thirsty teen-agers and the development of new outlets are bubbling sales of soda fountain manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- President Eisenhower decided today to take more time in determining whether to accept a recommendation of the Tariff Commission for an increase in the duty on imports of cotton velveteen fabrics.

The Youth Consultation Service, a private organization assisting adolescent girls, has contracted to buy the six-story building at 18 East Seventy-first Street from Manhattan Sanitorium, Inc, The property is 35 by 100 feet and has been used as a nursing home.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21--The Soviet press has used Secretary of State Dulles' return to the international scene as occasion for its latest and one of its more bitter attacks on, United States intentions and policies.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Vet's Boy, owned by Edward Seinfeld of New York, scored a mild surprise by charging to victory in the feature race at Tropical Park today. He reached the final pole a head before the Spring Hill Farm's I Geegee.
Churches will be bright with candle light services and pageants tomorrow and the next day to herald the coming of Christmas on Tuesday.

The Port of New York gave a misty welcome yesterday to the new 22,000-ton liner Carinthia. Port officials had arranged the usual ship and air reception for the Cunard ship, but a flyover of planes and helicopters was called off because of fog.
Corporate financing negotiations covering more than $50,000,000 were announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 (UP)-- A college freshman shot and killed his co-ed friend and her father today, shot her mother and then tried to Kill Himself.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Saturday, Dec. 22--There were indications here that the withdrawal of the last British and French troops from Egypt would take place today.
The Tweed commission has officially presented to Governor Harriman and the State Legislature its final plan to simplify and integrate the state's chaotic jumble of courts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--A controversy appeared to be developing today over the expected invitation by President Eisenhower to President Tito of Yugoslavia to visit this country.
Traffic on one of the main arteries of the Times Square area came to a standstill yesterday as city officials and stage notables paid tribute to the memory of a famed producerdirector-author.

Distillers Corporation--Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended Oct, 31 were 15.8 per cent above the level a year, earlier. Gross income was up 37.6 per cent.

The combined efforts of General Electric, Pan American Airways and the New York Telephone Company yesterday successfully ended a month-long search to find the intended recipient of a set of painted gourds. The gourds were missent from Puerto Rico to a General Electric plant in Plainville Conn.
Mrs. Indira Gandhi, only daughter of India's Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and a welfare leader in her own land, put some pointed questions to social workers yesterday.

John G.Griffin of 212-12 Ninety-fourth Avenue, Queens Village, Queens, manager of Keiser Co., Inc., sugar brokers of 120 Wall Street, died Thursday at Terrace Heights Hospital, Hollis, Queens. His age was 64.
Money brokers advanced the interest rate on time money percentage point yesterday. Henceforth, borrowers will pay 4 5/8 per cent on loans maturing in thirty days to six months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- The State Department has the right to refuse to grant a passport on the basis of confidential information it does not disclose, Federail District Judge Joseph McGarraghy ruled here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The United States offered today to lend Britain up to $500,000,000 for purchases in this country, including oil.

PARIS, Dec. 21--The BritishFrench evacuation of Suez brings to an end a strange, dramatic episode that remains somewhat obscure as regards its origins but tragically clear as regards some of its immediate consequences.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told the General Assembly tonight that Israel had promised to withdraw her troops from much Egyptian territory in the Sinai Peninsula by early next month.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 21--The Negroes of Montgomery, victors in a year-long boycott to end segregation in public transit here, quietly and in determined numbers went back on the city's desegregated buses today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec.21 (AP)--The State Supreme Court restrained the State Board of Elections today from certifying the election of Christopher Del Sesto, Republican, as Governor.

Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Heidi Mitchell Bingham to Lieut. John Ruckman Fell Jr., U.S. M.C.R. The Rev. George B.Ford, the pastor, performed the ceremony, after which there was a reception at 1A East Seventy-seventh Street.

Futures on the New York exchanges generally rose yesterday. Wool, potatoes, sugar, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa and lead advanced, hides declined and price movements for rubber, tin and copper were mixed.

The Radio Corporation of America will lose about $6,900,-- 000 this year on its color television set making and broadcasting activities, David Sarnoff, chairman, disclosed in a statement issued for publication today.

A long week's session of soulsearching by some of the nation's leading scientists begins here today with the opening of the 123d meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

"Troilus and Cressida," the Old Vic's fourth and final offering of its repertory season at the Winter Garden under the auspices of Sol Hurok, opens there at 7:30 tonight. On other nights the curtain will rise at 8:30.

RUDENESS and a total disregard of the proprieties have marked the long series between the New York Giants and the Chicago Bears. Despite the lack of gentlemanly behavior, however, it has been an absorbing series from its inception in 1925 through the dramatic 17-17 tie of only a month ago. Maybe Emily Post and other arbiters of etiquette would have frowned on some of the proceedings but the fans loved it all.
ONE of the fine old witty sayings about dove hunting is that it separates the men from the boys. It has also been known to separate them from their wives.

THE concert Alexander Schneider presented on Christmas Eve at Carnegie Hall demonstrated two things. Baroque music has a deep appeal to the new generation of concertgoers; and good music never has any difficulty finding its audience in this city if the admission charge is low.

WHEN Peter Joseph Dale entered the Police Department nearly twenty-eight years ago he was in search of "security." His job now is testing bombs and odd packages and devices believed to be explosive. The works of the eccentric person who deposits pipe bombs in public places.

Town Journal, a monthly magazine with a circulation of more than 2,000,000 among small-town families, will cease publication after the February issue. Executives of Farm Journal, Inc., which publishes the magazine, confirmed the decision yesterday.

Mrs. Vera King Kramer, divorced wife of a part-owner of the Edison Hotel, was found dead in bed yesterday in her apartment at 566 West End Avenue, near Eighty-seventh Street. One side of her face was bruised.

The New York Central Railroad will begin construction "soon" of two new electronic freight yards to cost $21,000,000. Alfred E. Perlman, president, said yesterday that the new yards, which will be located at Elkhart, Ind., ...
JAKARTA, Indonesia., Dec. 27--The Indonesian Government was reported today to have won back control of North Sumatra after a six-day bloodless revolt led by an Army colonel.
Futures prices on the New York exchanges closed irregularly yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) --A Senate study held today that pension funds, insurance companies and other institutional investors had a "significant" part in stimulating and extending the stock price boom of 1953-55.
The nation's capacity for making steel has climbed to a new high of 133,459,150 net tons a year--an increase of 5,096,060 tons, or 4 per cent, during the last year.
Directors of the Evans Products Company have agreed to a plan covering the acquisition by the company of substantially all the assets of the Haskelite Manufacturing Corporation.
BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 27-- Lewis F. Lang, former first deputy controller in New York City, died here today of a heart attack at his sister's home, 97 West Thirty-sixth Street. His age was 62.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 28 (UP)--Ken Rosewall and Lew Hoad, Australia's marvels of the court, scored smashing singles victories to complete a 5-0 sweep over the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round.
The thoughts of age and of youth keep turning to the Neediest at this season.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27--Miss Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the Soviet Union's highest ranking woman official, appears to have received the key role in a program to improve the discipline and ideological training of Soviet youth.
ONE out of every four ducks and geese shot down today and every day in the hunting season will be left to die in the water.
Directors of the Anaconda Company tentatively approved yesterday a proposal to raise additional capital by selling stock on subscription rights to its shareholders.
Ivan Chandler Dresser, special assistant to the general manager of the General Motors Overseas Operation Division, died of cancer yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 60 years old.

ALBANY, Dec. 27--Governor Harriman's office denied today that the Governor's release of a committee report favoring the continued sale of liquor to minors 18 years and older implied that he favored this proposal.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 27 (AP) --Washington and Lee scored 8 points in the last fifty-two seconds today to send Columbia to its first defeat of the season, 69--65, in the first round of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.
A pair of streaks came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night. The New York Rangers won a National Hockey League game after having been set down twice in a row.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 (UP)--Despite having to wait hours for high winds and rough seas to subside, speed-boat experts set four world records today on a mile straightaway course along the Inland Waterway near here.
Plans of a new Cuban company to construct a pulp and paper mill using bagasse as its basic raw material were announced yesterday. Bagasse is the fibrous residue of crushed sugar cane.

Charles Lee Swem, verbatim shorthand reporter for President Woodrow Wilson during his two terms in the White House, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. His age was 63. He lived at 60 West Tenth Street.
LONDON, Dec. 20--A Soviet physicist, K.S. Vulfson, has suggested a new and fairly simple method of measuring the speed of light--approximately 186,282 miles a second.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27-- After two rounds of the National Intercollegiate Chess League team championship at the Franklin-Mercantile Chess Club, tonight, the University of Chicago led, 7 -- .

WASHINGTON, Dec 27--A decade's study of apelike creatures who roamed South Africa a million years ago was advanced today by a scientist in support of his theory that the gap between man and ape had been bridged.
Business loans on the books of the larger New York banks fell $5,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This put the total at $11,471,000,000.
The United Parents Associations urged the Board of Education yesterday to end the impasse over teachers' salaries.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 27--The last three months have produced significant changes in the way United States foreign policy is carried out.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 27--In the rectory of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church this afternoon Miss Constance Patricia Demarest and Orlin Vincent Wry Jr. were married by the Rev. Donen O'Neill.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that he was seeking the cooperation of clergymen to appeal for safe driving over the New Year week-end.
The appointment of Darwin W. Telesford, a Negro lawyer, as an interim justice of the Municipal Court was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Columbia University named Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli yesterday as head football coach to succeed Lou Little.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1016 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-third Street, has been sold by the Gotar Realty Corporation to a syndicate represented by Harry J. Riker, executive vice president of Riker Co., the broker in the deal.
"Protective Custody," a new play starring Faye Emerson, has its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Ambassador Theatre.

ROME, Dec, 27 (AP)--Vincenzo Vacirca, anti-Fascist newspaper editor, died at his home yesterday. He was 70 years old. Signor Vacirca was a member of the central committee of the Social Democratic party from 1948 to 1952.

The projected increase in Arabiclanguage broadcasts by the Voice of America is simply one of the more obvious reflections of the rapidly developing importance of the Middle East in American foreign policy.
It will be thirty-four years next February since Woodrow Wilson, a broken, disappointed yet somehow victorious man, died.
Four hundred pounds of potatoes kept the International Longshoremen's Association and New York waterfront employers from getting down to scheduled contract negotiations yesterday.
