WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- Lawyer's for ten Chinese asked the Attorney General today whether he had "adopted any policies which differentiate between aliens who arrive in the United States from China and those who arrive from Hungary."

LONDON, Dec. 27--Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, said today he believed that "broad" questions about the Middle East could be discussed after the general problem of the Suez Canal had been solved.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) --The National Zoo has acquired a bird generally believed extinct--Arment's cowbird.

The Federal Reserve System bought $31,500,000 in Government ninety-day bills in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It bought $41,500,000 outright, but sold $10,000,000 held under repurchase agreements.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 27--America's quest for the Davis Cup ended in failure today after Sam Giammalva, playing superbly in his first challenge round, and Victor Seixas had waged a stirring fight in the doubles match.

Twenty-seven persons were injured early today when a Fourteenth Street bus collided with a private car, then jumped the curb and crashed into a store window. Ten of the victims were taken to Bellevue Hospital and seventeen to Columbus Hospital.
The snows finally came to the northlands yesterday. They came just in time to brighten what had promised to be a dismal week-end for a vacationing New Year's crowd.

The keel of the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk, fifth in the Navy's series of supercarriers, was put down yesterday at the Camden, N. J., yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation. The vessel is scheduled for delivery in 1959.
The wisdom of Solomon and the knowledge of Frank Buck would have been a great help to a Queens magistrate yesterday.

Controversy over the relative value of the Dead Sea Scrolls, including one that was labeled a forgery seventy years ago, disturbed the scholarly calm of the ninety-second meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature yesterday.
ALTHOUGH we have had to wait sixteen years to see Sean O'Casey's "Purple Dust," no hard feelings now. The performance that opened at the Cherry Lane last evening is gusty and humorous.
Madison Square Garden will be taken over by college basketball today with five games scheduled in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's fifth annual Holiday Festival tournament.
LONDON, Dec. 27--The stock markets here fully maintained their pre-Christmas firmness when they reopened today after the Yule holiday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 27-- The Hofstra, West Virginia Tech, Bucknell and Cortlandt State quintets advanced to the semifinal round of the sixth annual Hofstra invitation basketball tournament today.
The Lukens Steel Company plans to borrow $39,000,000 from its customers to help finance an expansion program.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Poore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Poore of 223 East Forty--ninth Street, to Thaddeus Brys.
NEWARK, Dec. 27--The New York Central Railroad today offered minor changes in its West Shore line schedule to meet the complaints of its New Jersey commuters.
WARSAW, Dec. 27--The Polish Government needs at least $500,000,000 worth of industrial raw materials and machinery to consolidate the regime of Wladyslaw Gomulka.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 27 (AP)--Israel officially opened a naval base today at Elath, a port on the Gulf of Aqaba, on the southern tip of the country.
The Misses Caryn Ryan and Burks Bingham made their debuts last evening at a supper dance given in the St. Regis Roof by Miss Ryan's parents, ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- President Eisenhower praises Woodrow Wilson's concept of "a great family of nations living peacefully together" in a message to be read in Paris tomorrow, the 100th anniversary of Wilson's birth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The United States attempted today to stimulate renewal of negotiations on the Cyprus problem.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27--Edwin G. Nourse, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, cautioned today against "high-pressure economics" that advocated employment and business expansion goals so high that they invited inflation and Government controls.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) --Pittsburgh upset Seton Hall, 76--66, today in the opening game of the Orange Bowl basketball tournament.

The new year may promise to be a happy one for some Dodgers. But not for all of them. A few are likely to start it a trifle unhappy when their eyes light on the salary terms appearing in their 1957 contracts.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 --"The Spirit of St. Louis" is going back into the photography stage of production tomorrow for approximately three days of filming.
Nature is being restored in Central Park. The natural unspoiled wildness of the Ramble is receiving a $225,000 treatment to preserve its peculiar charm.
The study of man in his relations with other men appears to be largely beyond the capabilities of the physical sciences at present, a group of scientists said yesterday.
BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 27--Both tolls and traffic through the Panama Canal during November were lower than in the previous month but higher than for the corresponding month last year.
The recent shop-steward committee elections in the Michelin tire works in Turin are an index of the disintegration of Communist domination of the Italian labor movement.
After a detailed survey of the loss caused by a fire in a painting restorer's studio on Tuesday, the over-all damage to pictures has been put at less than $200,000.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings, scoring in every period, withstood a lastperiod Boston spurt and took over the National Hockey League lead from the Bruins tonight with a 5--3 victory before a capacity crowd oof 13,909.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Far Rockaway, Queens, punched out a unanimous decision over Julio Mederos of Cuba in the Milwaukee Arena tonight. Jackson weighed 195 pounds, Mederos, 193 .

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (UP) --The local unit of the American Newspaper Guild voted tonight to cooperate with the management of The Philadelphia Daily News in a "reorganizational program designed to insure the continued publication" of the paper.
ALBANY, Dec. 27--Following is the text of the section of recommendations of the report on the state's higher education needs issued today by the Board of Regents:
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27-- Settlement of the twenty-month-old strike at major beachfront hotels was reported near tonight.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 27 (UP)--Noel and Herta Field, who sought asylum in Hungary in 1954 after having spent five years in Communist jails, said today they had no intention of returning to the United States.

Once again we are obliged to extend our congratulations to our Australian friends for their victory in the Davis Cup matches. They are splendid athletes, great tennis players and the sort of persons to whom one can lose, if he has to, without chagrin.

CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Dec. 27 (AP) --Three persons, including the resident Bishop of the east central area of the Evangelical United Brethren Church and his wife were killed today in a head-on truck-car collission. The accident took place on U.S. 40, six miles east of Cambridge.

"Baby Doll," the motion picture that earlier in the week ran into booking difficulties with one theatre in Albany and a chain of theatres in New England, has been set for showing in theatres in 1,118 cities throughout the country.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 27 (AP)--Some Soviet tanks began withdrawing today from the Danube River bridges in the Hungarian capital.
CHICAGO, DeC. 27--Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade continued largely quiet today.
NOT content to rest on laurels earned by their skillful prep aration of the Christmas feast, most housewives are now turning their lively attention to planning the New Year's Day table.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27--President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt has sent warm greetings to the Soviet Union and expressed the desire that friendship between the two countries will "grow in strength."

MALIBU, Calif., Dec. 27--A new fire threatened the main part of the Malibu community tonight. It was touched off by sparks from an uncontrolled brush fire that has caused millions of dollars worth of damage along the southern California coast.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation's sales rose sharply in the quarter and six months ended Nov. 30, but earnings were below the levels a year earlier, Henry J. Kaiser, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that 1957 would be more prosperous than 1956.
TOKYO, Dec. 27--Premier Tanzan Ishibashi filled today two of three remaining posts in his Cabinet. He delayed a more important appointment, that of Defense Minister.
The United States shipping industry is adopting a wait and see attitude so far as hostilities in the eastern Mediterranean area are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- President Eisenhower was reported today to be considering a request for Congressional authority to use the United States' armed forces as he deems necessary to maintain peace in the Middle East.
Cotton futures prices were unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday, with business on the New York Cotton Exchange light.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Frederick Morgan Davenport, former Republican Representa-, tive from New York and a specialist in Federal personnel matters, died last night at his home here. His age was 90.

Chibougamau Jaculet Mines, Ltd., of Montreal, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell to Copper Rand Chibougamau Mines, Ltd., the 922,000 remaining shares of its authorized but unissued capital stock for $2,766,000.
BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP)--Brown gained a quick 5-1 lead and then held off Northeastern for a 6-4 victory tonight in a Christmas college hockey tournament game at the Boston Arena.
The Board of Estimate has decided that there will be no $30,000,000 home for the Dodgers in the heart of downtown Brooklyn unless the sports center planned for that area can pay its own way.
MONTREAL, Dec. 27--The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen moved today toward a strike right after the New Year on the Canadian Pacific Railway.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (UP) --A Federal grand jury indicted four men today after reportedly hearing a geologist tell how he stole valuable oil-survey maps from the Gulf Oil Corporation and peddled them to a ring of racketeers.
The first volume of the American edition of Lord Beaverbrook's memoirs is planned for February publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) --Aided by a 61-point spree in the first half, the Philadelphia Warriors romped to a 112-87 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in the finale of a National Basketball Association double-header at Convention Hall tonight.
There's much tall talk about special Machiavellian measures the Giants and Bears are preparing for use against each other on Sunday.
ANY painters or sculptors not living or working on Tenth Street are beyond the pale for the creators of an unusual exhibition now on view at the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27-- President Eisenhower's foreign aid advisory committee left today on a study tour of eighteen nations.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 27 --Negro leaders called off tonight, pending a court test, their open defiance of a city ordinance requiring segregated seating in public buses.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Dec. 27--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who recently saw Hungarian refugees at the AustroHungarian frontier, saw others today at the reception center here. There were differences in their faces.
Three major steel producers announced increased "extras" charges on various products yesterday, generally in line with similar actions taken earlier by other companies.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 27 (AP)--The Argentine Government was on record today with a new declaration that the oil industry will be developed only as a Government monopoly, without private concessions.
The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to post a $25,000 reward for the apprehension of New York's mysterious bomber.
When Christmas toys have temporarily lost their charm and indoor amusements pall, parents as well as children may be in need of relaxed and "different" diversion.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 27 --A milling group of about forty jeering white teen-agers caused Negro leaders to call off today a scheduled demonstration of desegregated bus riding.

WHEN a tourist heads toward a certain bridge over the St. John's River on the outskirts of Jacksonville in Flor ida, his eyes inevitably are attracted by a pretty little stadium that cuddles among the palm trees on the right of the highway.
"A poet can't be bougnt and he can't be sold," Dr. William Carlos Williams of Rutherford, N.J., said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) --Former President Herbert Hoover has accepted an invitation to the inauguration of President Eisenhower on Jan. 21, Former President Harry S. Truman has declined.
IRONWOOD, Mich., Dec. 28 (AP)--Trapped by fast-spreading flames, a sleeping mother and five children perished tdaoy in a fire that left a seven-room farmhouse in ruins.
LONDON, Dec. 28--The presumed death of one young British officer in Port Said has aroused furious anger in Britain.
THE lucky recipients of jewelry gifts this Christmas should start now giving them necessary attention. Otto Grun, jeweler, offers advice on quick and easy methods of home care.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Bill Schmidt grabbed a rebound under his own basket and scored as the buzzer sounded today, enabling Connecticut to post a 5756 victory over Stanford and gain the final of the Orange Bowl basketball tournament.
STAUNTON, Va., Dec. 28 (AP) --Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that the "cold war" was not only continuing, but was also "in fact deepening."

BUFFALO, Dec. 28 (AP)--The 17-year-old Federal antitrust action against the Schine theatre interests moved to a new phase today when thirteen individual and corporate defendants were found guilty of criminal contempt. No date for sentencing was set.
HONG KONG, Dec. 28--Communist China made clear today its allegiance to the Soviet Union and paid unexpected tribute to the memory of Stalin.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28 (AP) --Penn State defeated Penn, 89--59, with brilliant shooting and a tight defense to advance to the final of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament today.
The thirty-eighth annual Yuletide Ball took place last evening in the ballroom of the St. George in Brooklyn in a festive holiday setting of Christmas greens.
Bismarck, the Prussian statesman, did not wear a kilt, despite the impression conveyed in a photo caption published in The New York Times of Dec. 22.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28-- While exploring a buried city in Sicily last summer, the Princeton Archeological Expedition uncovered and studied a spacious Roman villa.
The heads of two major airlines have hinted at the possibility of higher passenger fares.
Widespread lay-offs mark a nation-wide case of "distribution indigestion" in television manufacturing.

Commodity futures moved irregulartly yesterday on the New York exchanges, but the more active items were generally higher. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, cotconseed oil and soybean oil rose; rubber, hides, burlap and copper declined, and price movements for wool, potatoes and zinc were mixed.
Activity in the public market for new capital has dwindled to a nominal level for the yearend holiday period, but the backlog of new listings keeps growing substantially.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UP)--Coach Terry Brennan's East all-stars, headed by Notre Dame's All-America quarterback, Paul Hornung, were installed as one-touchdown favorites today as they wound up training for the thirty-second ...
CHICAGO, Dec. 28--New-crop wheat futures again showed some strength on the Board of Trade today, while there was not much demand for the March and May deliveries.
Dr. Frances R. Horwich announced yesterday a parting of the ways with the National Broadcasting Company as her "Ding Dong School" telecast went off the network for the last time.

MALIBU, Calif., Dec. 28-- The flame-ravaged Santa Monica Mountains were hit today by a third major fire. The new blaze exposed vast new areas of homes, ranches and resorts to the threat of destruction.

HOUSTON, Dec. 28 (AP)--Ronnie Stevenson scored 10 points in the last four minutes today as Texas Christian overcame a 10-point Navy lead and defeated the middies, 67--65, in the first round of consolation play in the Southwest Conference pre-season basketball tournament.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 28 --Sir Norman Brookes, a leading figure in Australian tennis, came out today in favor of holding open tournaments in the United States, Australia and Europe.

Radio station WQXR notified its staff of ninety yesterday that a dispute with Local 1212 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers might result in a strike and force the station off the air.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 28--Percy Marks, author and college English instructor, died yesterday at Grace-New Haven Community Hospital. His age was 65. He lived in near-by Hamden.
The Neediest Cases Fund, now in its forty-fifth annual appeal, received a gift of $100 from Governor Harriman yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 10 points down yesterday. The near months were firm, the others weak.
St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mildred H. Durand to Michael Rawstorne Caroe.

The liberalization of immigration laws in many countries, including the United States, would help solve the Hungarian refugee problem, according to Dr. Auguste R. Lindt, recently chosen United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The State Department reasserted today a desire to grant Poland economic assistance to help her maintain an independent course.
CAMDEN, S.C., Dec. 28--The band director of the white Camden High School was flogged late last night by four or five hooded men who accused him of having voiced pro-integration sentiments.
VIENNA, Dec. 28--The Kadar regime, which first appeased and then liquidated or infiltrated every other faction in Hungary, now seems to be trying to appease the West.

MONTEREY, Calif., Dec. 28-- A third and revolutionary way to produce a nuclear reaction was described here today. It does not involve uranium, as in the fission reaction, or million-degree heat, as in the fusion reaction.

A READER who received a numerous Christmas gift of pecans from a friend in the South writes to ask how to keep them fresh. The question is apropos, in view of a recent pecan crop well above the average.
With the somber statistics of the Christmas week-end death toll on the highways still fresh in mind, the nation began another four-day holiday week-end yesterday.

A gain in the week ended last Friday of 20,950 barrels a day in the nation's oil output was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This brought production to a new high of 7,376,100 barrels a day, compared with 6,991,600 in the week ended Dec. 23, 1955.

WHAT are they doing to Faye Emerson? In "Protective Custody," which opened at the Ambassador last evening, she makes her first entrance as we all know her--a handsome woman in glamorous evening attire, radiating success and selfconfidence.
More electricity was produced by American utilities in the week ended Dec. 22 than in any previous week on record.

New York's Regents, with their almost unlimited responsibility for the encouragement and supervision of education, have made more than a dozen recommendations dealing with the future of colleges and universities in the state.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 28--Brazil and Uruguay signed today a series of treaties and joint declarations. These dealt with trade, navigation, cultural exchanges and other aspects of relations between the two countries.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP)--Two gold-plated magnesium spheres highly polished and delicately balanced, were made ready for shipment to Washington tonight They will be launched into outer space as the first man-made earth satellites.
PARIS, Dec. 28--Christian Pineau, French Foreign Minister called West Europe tonight to unite to prevent its being taken over by one of the two great blocs dividing the world.
John Francis Conroy, Associate Superintendent of Schools in charge of junior high schools, died of a heart attack Thursday night in a theatre at Broadway and Fifty-first Street. He was 63 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) --George Meany suspended today the financial officers of two local labor unions at Philadelphia and Chicago on charges of maladministration of welfare funds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- The Government today halted the granting of tax benefits that have helped the taconite iron ore industry grow in five years from pilot-plant stage to major status in the iron and steel economy.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28-- Virginia took further steps today to set up a pupil assignment program aimed at avoiding racial integration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The State Department took punitive action tonight against three American newsmen who had defied a Government ruling and entered Communist China.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (AP) --The State Athletic Commission today moved to revoke the license of Cal Eaton, promoter and matchmaker of the Olympic Auditorium here.

Thirteen leading companies plan to spend 7 per cent more on expansion in 1957 than this year, according to an Associated Press survey. They have budgeted $6,888,000,000 for 1957, compared with $6,429,000,000 spent in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The Air Force Association asserted with bitterness today that the Air Force was being cut back to 110 wings by 1960.
A host of imitators of the Mad Bomber have arisen lately and their hoax calls have snowballed to the point where harassed policemen are unable to keep up with them.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 --Film production in Hollywood dipped to a new low today with only fourteen pictures before the cameras.
Gene Fullmer is ready to fight for the world middleweight championship. The young Mormon Elder from West Jordan, Utah, has been ready since last June.

In selecting John Hay Whitney as our new Ambassador to the Court of St. James President Eisenhower has made a particularly happy choice. Mr. Whitney has qualifications which should serve him well in his new post in this time of strain and stress.

Improved technology can greatly increase man's production of food and other necessities of life, it was agreed here yesterday at a symposium sponsored by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
HAVANA, Dec. 28--The terrorist campaign being waged throughout Cuba by enemies of the regime of President Fulgencio Batista is causing grave concern among the people.

ALBANY, Dec. 28--Governor Harriman and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits agreed today that a special prosecutor should be named to carry on the investigation of corruption in Suffolk County. The Democratic chief executive and the Republican legal officer could not agree, however, on who the new investigator should be.
The dark areas visible on the surface of the planet Mars, commonly thought to be vegetation, were said yesterday to be solidified lava.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York--more familiarly known as H.I.P.--has been providing its low-cost prepaid medical service through physicians' group practice for nearly ten years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28-- The majority report of four Southern members of a Congressional subcommittee recommended today that Negro and white students again be separated in District of Columbia schools.

Ancestral portraits, miniatures and photographs ordered destroyed under the will of the late Augustus van Horne Stuyvesant Jr. have been saved by a curious bit of litigation. The final decision was handed down in Manhattan Surrogate's Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 --President Eisenhower bestowed on Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther today a third Oak Leaf Cluster for his Distinguished Service Medal.
Miss Joan Struthers Croft was honored at a dinner dance last night in the Pierce Roof given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Croft of 1021 Park Avenue and Norfolk, Conn.
Directors of the Lone Star Cement Corporation and Superior Portland Cement, Inc., yesterday approved a proposal for a merger.
John P. McGrath, whose appointment a year ago as this state's member of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission stirred a major political storm, resigned yesterday from that position.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28--The United States plans to press for further action by the United Nations on Soviet intervention in Hungary. The move will be made when the General Assembly meets again next week.

"Holiday for Lovers," the new romantic comedy by Ronald Alexander starring Don Ameche, has found a Broadway haven. It is the Longacre Theatre, which will receive the comedy beginning Thursday evening, Feb. 14.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 28--Sam Giammalva of Houston stood forth today as the United States' Davis Cup hope for the future as Australia completed a 5-0 sweep of the challenge round series.

The fifth floor and part of the fourth floor in the office building being erected by Uris Brothers at 750 Third Avenue at Forty-sixth Street have been leased to Harcourt, Brace Co., publishers. The Cross Brown Company, agent for the building, was the broker.

It is good news that, as our Washington bureau reports, President Eisenhower is considering asking Congress for authority to use United States armed forces in the Middle East if necessary, as he already can use them in the event of Communist aggression against Taiwan (Formosa).
As year's end approaches, teen-agers as well as their parents are planning celebrations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it proposed to issue a permit to AMF Atomics, Inc., a division of American Machine and Foundry Company, for construction of a research reactor in Plainsboro Township, New Jersey.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP)-- A former Gulf Oil Corporation geologist who allegedly played a central role in the theft of valuable oil exploration maps did not "make a single dollar" from the maps, his attorney said in a statement today.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 28-- Amedee Froger, president of the Algerian Federation of Mayors, was assassinated today by an Arab terrorist. The assassin escaped.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 28-- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Thomas J. Herbert as chairman of the Government's Subversive Activities Control Board.

MIAMI, Dec. 28 (AP)--Baby Vasquez, a Mexico city lightweight; scored a technical knockout over Paolo Rosi of Italy in the seventh round tonight. A crowrd of 1,129 saw the upset in the televised fight at Biscayne Arena.
As of last night approximately 51,000 tickets had been sold for tomorrow's professional football championship play-off game between the Giants and the Chicago Bears at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) --President Eisenhower authorized a second American roundthe-world airline route today by permitting Trans World Airlines to link its international operations with Northwest Airlines, Inc.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 28 --President Sukarno tonight ordered the leader of the revolt in North Sumatra to end the insurrection "to prevent casualties and suffering."

The International Longshoremen's Association and New York waterfront employers agreed yesterday to set up a joint study of the controversial potato-handling operations at Pier 10, Hudson River and Albany Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28-- William Dubilier, a prominent figure in radio for forty years, got a patent this week for an improved electronic flash tube, successor to the flash bulb.
The nation's money managers should be able to keep bank lending within bounds without tightening credit further, a leading economist said yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (AP)-- An agreement ending the twenty-month-old strike at luxury hotels here will be signed next Saturday, officials of the Miami Beach Hotel Association and the Hotel Employes Union said today.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 29 --Riots flared in Algiers today as thousands of Frenchmen demonstrated during the funeral of Amedee Froger, chairman of the Algerian Mayors Federation. He was assassinated by an Arab terrorist yesterday.

VALENCIA, Spain, Dec. 29 (AP)--Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N.J., and Malcolm Fox of Baltimore were among the foreign winners today in the opening of a five-day international tennis tournament. Richardson defeated J. Gauthier of France, 6--2, 1--1, and Fox turned back J. Plasencia of Spain, 6--0, 6--2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing issued today a reminder that virtually all aliens who are in the United States in January must register their address during that month. The address cards are obtainable at all post offices and immigration field offices. They must be handed in at those offices, not mailed.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 29--A research expert on Soviet economics said today that available data indicated that the Russians were still decades behind the United States in industrial growth.

THE actual heads of the Demo cratic party these days are two Texans who are in some trouble at home, in some trouble nationally, generally in cahoots with each other-- and quite likely to come out all right in the end. Together, they will run the new Eighty-fifth Congress--and the verb is used in no loose sense.

Next to the month of June when a summer's cruising can begin, the yachtsman's best month is January. However, cold, blustery and snowbound, January is still the time for the National Motor Boat Show in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)-- The population of the United States at midnight New Year's Eve will be a little less than 169,600,000. The estimate was made by the Census Bureau. A year ago the population estimate was 166,800,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 29 (AP) --Unbeaten North Carolina, second ranked in the nation, won its eleventh game tonight by defeating Wake Forest, 63--55. The victory enabled the Tar Heels to capture the Dixie Classic basketball tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29-- Argentina's only whaling company is going out of business. WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The Atomic Energy Commission celebrated its tenth birthday today with a 3,500-word report on what it has done.
PARIS, Dec. 30--The French Government is negotiating with several European countries, notably Germany, to obtain financial participation in certain investments in Africa.
LONDON Dec. 30--British children are suffering in increasing numbers from "television headaches," an ophthalmologist resorted today.

National advertising linage in newspapers will chalk up a new record high for 1956 when all the figures are in. For eleven months of 1956 there was a gain of 2.6 per cent over 1955, according to a compilation based on figures from Media Records.
Once an ugly duckling in the Atlantic Ocean, the American Hawaiian Steamship Company Liner Leilani gives promise of being a swan in the Pacific.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 30-- Egypt gave consent today to the immediate start of full-scale clearance of the Suez Canal.
DALLAS, Dec. 30--The first question asked by every early arrival for Tuesday's Cotton Bowl football game between Texas Christian and Syracuse is "what happened to Jimmy Swink this season?"
Senator-elect Jacob K. Javits will oppose any attempt by Republican leaders to pick Vincent L. Leibell Jr. of Queens to succeed him as State Attorney General, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30--Newcrop futures registered moderate gains last week on the Board of Trade. But deferred deliveries were inclined to lag, reflecting slow export inquiry, which is not unusual at the holiday period.
VIENNA, Dec. 30--Eugene Ormandy Sought out exiled Hungarian musicians here today to give them a picture of life in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 30--Word that the United Nations salvage fleet had started clearing the Suez Canal helped the stock market maintain a firm tone last week. But business, still affected by the holiday season, was slow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--A group of business and financial leaders urged Congress today to set up a special commission to make a broad new study of the nation's money and credit policies.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 30-- Farnham Yardley of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, chairman of the board of directors of Jenkins Brothers, valve manufacturers, of 100 Park Avenue, New York, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital after a short illness. His age was 88.

WASHINGTON Dec. 30--The debate in Washington this weekend over the Administration's plans for a "keep out" warning to the Soviet Union in the Middle East is in some ways similar to--and in others different from --the debate that went on here prior to the pronouncement of the Monroe Doctrine 133 years ago.

THE Giants did a full-fledged taxidermy job on the mighty Chicago Bears at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. They peeled the pelts off the Monsters and jammed the remains down Chicago throats with such savage disdain that 56,836 awed customers at the world championship play-off had to forget their discomfort.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) Marion B. Folsom announced tonight that 62,600 new classrooms were built this year, a record. But the shortage "is still grave," he said.
The atomic age has come up with nothing, to cut down big business represented by kerosene refrigerators in many parts of the world.

MONTREAL, Dec. 29--Dr. Edward Pearson Warner, retiring council president of the International Civil Aviation Organization, will leave for Paris within the next few days for the January meeting of I.C.A.O.'s "jet age task force."

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 30 --Lewis Hoad, Ken Rosewall's team-mate in the successful defense of the Davis Cup, was advised today aboard an airplane en route from Adelaide to Sydney that Rosewall had accepted an offer from Jack Kramer to turn professional. "I wish Ken good luck," said Hoad.
IN their resolve to restore balance to the household budget after the extravagances of Christmas, homemakers would do well to keep their, eye on egg prices.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 31-- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that any attempt to aid antiCommunists behind the Iron Curtain "will meet with a proper rebuff."

President Eisenhower's decision to ask Congress for "full powers to deal with the Middle East crisis" was lauded yesterday by Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- President Eisenhower, refreshed by a week-end of golf and relaxation, returned to Washington today for two days of conferences with legislative leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30-- The chess quartet representing the University of Chicago defeated Ogontz Center, 4--0, in the seventh and final round to capture the National Intercollegiate Chess League title at the Franklin-Mercantile Chess Club tonight.
MONTEREY, Calif., Dec. 30-- Dr. Thomas Lauritsen of the California Institute of Technology has transmuted carbon into helium.

WHEN the late Fred Allen was a boy working nights after school in the Boston Public Library he was in veigled into taking part in an amateur vaudeville show put on by the library's employes. He had learned to juggle in an elementary fashion and had memorized some atrocious jokes and so was eminently eligible. After the show a girl in the admiring crowd said:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 --A prominent member of the Indonesian Parliament has challenged the Government to disclose whether a "starvation blockade" has been imposed on rebel-controlled Central Sumatra.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) --Most citizens refused to respond to "inflammatory appeals or to incitement to violence" in 1956, the Tuskegee Institute reported today in its annual race relations study.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The Administration's plan to ask for Presidential stand-by authority to defend the Middle East appeared this week-end to be heading for stormy Congressional and international treatment.
George J. Murch and Raymond W. Zrike have been elected vice presidents and directors of the Worcester Royal Porcelain Company, Inc.
PORT SAID, Dec. 30--The Egyptian authorities began today to collect rifles, pistols and machine-guns from the guerrilla volunteers of Port Said who had been armed to fight the British and French.
A combination of warm ground, high winds and salt spread on streets cleared snow and ice from roads and highways in the metropolitan area yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 30--A year of decision is ahead for Japan. For eleven years since the end of World War II, the main task of the Japanese Government has been the liquidation of that disastrous military venture. During this period Japan's destiny has been shaped largely by Washington.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 30-- The two-month-old strain in French-Moroccan relations has relaxed visibly and significantly in the last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--An alien who owns a New York export-import business has won a long legal fight to re-enter this country as a permanent resident.
BERLIN, Dec. 30--Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader of East Germany, served notice today that the regime wanted no opposition to the party line.
A report urging United States employers to stay in the International Labor Organization is scheduled for debate Thursday by members of the State Chamber of Commerce.

Following is the report of a committee on the Social Aspects of Science that was submitted to the Council of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The report was prepared as a sample of the problem of the impact of science upon society, which recent scientific advances have raised.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30 (AP)-- Robert Baylor Tunstall, Norfolk attorney and former railroad executive, died here today after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29-- The bitter rivalry of Argentina's Army, Navy and Air Force threatens to become intensified. The Navy's hopes for obtaining considerable quantities of surplus United States equipment appear on the point of being fulfilled.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- There will be forty-five new faces in the Congress that convenes next Thursday noon.

A FEW years ago Dr. Alfred J. Leibmann turned over to the New York Public Library, for permanent exhibit there, about, 225 manuscripts and printed documents on distillation that he had been years accumulating. They covered the period 1665-1910.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 30-- The opening of the $5,000,000 El Comandante race track, scheduled for Jan. 3, was indefinitely postponed when the owners' association refused to permit its horses to run because of the "bad conditions of the track."
The six-story apartment house for fifty-three families at 190 Wilson Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by Stuart Herman, realty operator, who immediately resold it. Alexander Herman was the broker.
Arturo Toscanini, one of the great names in music, has joined the long list of contributors this year to the Neediest Cases Fund.
DORTMUND, Germany, Dec. 30 (UP)--Nino Valdes of Cuba floored Hans Friedrich, a German heavyweight, seven times tonight for a knockout in the sixth round before 10,000 in Westfalen Hall.
Pleas for safe driving were made at a number of churches here yesterday. They were in response to a request by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy that the clergy help combat traffic accidents.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)--Sam Snead, the host pro won the $5,000 Boca Raton golf tournament today after three sub-par rounds. Snead had a margin of 4 strokes over the second place finisher, Lew Worsham.
WARSAW, Dec. 30--It has become clear that Poland's economy under the regime of Wladyslaw Gomulka will be as dependent on the Soviet Union as it was under the former leadership.

WASHINGTON, Dec.30--Some people might not agree, but the Inaugural Committee is sticking by its statistics: President Eisenhower is the thirty-fourth, not the thirty-third, President of the United States.
The nation is not headed for another round of inflationary price increases, according to Prof. Jules Backman of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at New York University.
A decline in profits and a letup in the rise of productivity have cast some doubt over the economic future, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York said yesterday.
YONKERS, Dec. 30--A Sanitation Department Worker, who last year received a Carnegie medal for lifesaving, last night rescued a woman from the Hudson River here.

Miss Rosalie Jane Littman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Littman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Pvt. Samuel Nathaniel Antupit of the Army, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Antupit of West Hartford, Conn., were married last evening in the Pierre by Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz.
Two detectives have received citations of honorable mention --the highest police awards--for heroic exploits in pistol battles with escaping criminals.
Organized science in the United States decided yesterday to increase its efforts to help solve the problems of society that recent scientific progress has raised.

The "case" of Korea has been upon the agenda of the United Nations, in either the security Council or the General Assembly, for a little more than eight years. It will come up again this week. It is a continuing problem and an undischarged responsibility.

Ever heavier highway traffic and the more powerful automobiles producing it, are increasing the demands on drivers' skill and alertness with each passing year. At present it is an open question whether drivers are physically capable of meeting these demands.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (UP)-- Fleming Mackell fired a threegoal "hat trick" tonight, enabling the Boston Bruins to take first place in the National Hockey League with a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30-- Reports from Syria tonight indicated that an agreement had been reached on a new Cabinet, including representatives of all five parties.

MALIBU, Calif., Dec. 30 (UP)--The last four of ten devastating mountain fires that swept over a total of 45,000 acres in Southern California since Christmas were brought under control today with the help of moist weather.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 30--A water pipeline in the Jerusalem corridor was blown up last night in the latest act of sabotage attributed here to Eyptian-controlled fedayeen (guerrillas).
Bomb scares that had frayed the city's nerves all last week continued yesterday, but at a slackened, pace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--A year-end survey shows that United States industry expects a prosperous 1957.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The head of the Justice Department's Tax Division reported today that the way of the tax transgressor was becoming increasingly hard.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 30-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer pledged his Government today to continue the pursuit of freedom and reunification for all Germany on the basis of a close alliance with the free world.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 30--Prospects for the Netherlands' economic development cannot be viewed optimistically, according to Sjoerd Posthuma, manager of the Netherlands Bank.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 30--Secretary of State Dulles flew to New York today for what was described as an "informal talk" with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. United States sources here said one purpose of the meeting was for Mr. Dulles to receive the latest available information on the situation in the Middle East.
The idea that science and religion are not at odds but can work together in important ways was stressed in sermons yesterday as scientists were welcomed to several churches in the city.
The National Broadcasting Company is making plans for Mary Martin to star in a twohour television version of "Annie Get Your Gun" in November.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 30--Israeli officials were waiting today for more details of President Eisenhower's proposals on the Middle East.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30--The wide display in the Moscow press of Peiping's expression of support for the Soviet Union has halted one source of speculation here concerning the pending visit to this city of Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 (AP)--Fifteen students--all the boys in an East German high school's senior class--have fled to West Berlin to escape Communist reprisals for having demonstrated sympathy with Hungary's freedom fighters.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)--The East swimming team breezed to a 225-167 victory over the West today with an exhibition of clear superiority in the relay events.

WHAT DO YOU KNOW ABOUT LABOR? By James Myers and Harry W. Laidler. 301 pp. John Day Company, New York. $4.75. Mr. Myers for twenty-two years was industrial relations secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

A new member entered the cast of the Saturday evening performance of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" at the Metropolitan Opera. Rosalind Elias sang her first Giulietta at the house and Martin Rich conducted his first "Hoffmann" of the season.
The steamship charter market today ends its most lucrative peacetime year and leaders expect continued prosperity during 1957.

THE art of choreography as a means of communication was lovingly and effectively explained by Agnes De Mille last night in her second appearance on "Omnibus" over Channel 7. As a lesson in the beauty and purpose of dance, the program was educational and entrancing.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (AP)--Sharon J. Mauhs, State Conservation Commissioner, announced today the appointment of a twenty-four-man committee to advise him on conservation matters.
Dr. Gwendolen Schlaegel Jones, a general practitioner, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--The Joint Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation recommended today that Congress be allowed to approve special tax benefits granted companies building defense facilities.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30-- India expects to save $63,000,000 in foreign exchange by the end of next June as the result of a restricted import policy announced today.

The Minneapolis-Moline Company has reported net income for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 of $534,463 after including a tax credit of $85,000. This was equal to 16 cents a share on 910,021 common shares and compared with $679,455, or 14 cents each on 908,965 shares, in the preceding year.

STIFF shirts will be scarce this New Year's Eve, thanks to the current trend in men's formal wear rather than the holiday spirit.

CAIRO, Dec. 31--Egypt has appealed urgently to the United States to release Egyptian dollar assets that have been frozen in American banks for the last five months, an official source said today.
LONDON, Dec. 31--Government Funds led an all-around increase in stock market prices today. Trading was lively and some gains were accentuated by shortage of stock.
The Navy is developing a ballistic missile to be fired from submerged submarines at targets hundreds of miles away, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a 5 per cent increase in coach and firstclass fares on all Western railroads and eight Eastern railroads.

Heightened competition, particularly in the field of wholesale and retail distribution, took a higher toll in failures in 1956 than in any year since 1941.
The city will soon demolish a water pumping station it built for $2,677,369 only seven years ago and never used.

Capital expenditures in 1956 soared to a record-smashing total of about $35,000,000,000, a jump of 22 per cent above the previous high in 1955. Indications are that there will be another increase in 1957.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 1--Two Irish Republican Army terrorists were killed tonight by Northern Ireland police in an attack on the village of Brookeborough, in County Fermanagh.
The use of oxyacetylene torches in welding and demolition work is becoming one of the city's major fire hazards, according to Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
The renting and leasing of cars and trucks, until recently an infant industry, has become big business.
Prices paid for membership on the two leading stock exchanges here varied widely in 1956.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP)-- Larry Hickman, Baylor's fullback, tonight apologized for kicking Bruce Burnham of Tennessee in the head during the Sugar Bowl football game.
The development of shopping centers came of age in 1956 and all signs point to continuing healthy growth this year.
The surplus-plagued domestic cotton industry last year moved on to slightly firmer ground.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company established record sales, earnings and production in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, David L. Luke Jr., president, reported in the annual statement released today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1--James B. Moore Jr. of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was elected commodore of the Frostbite Yacht Club for 1957 at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the organization at Manhasset Bay today. Moore succeeds J. Burr Jenkins of Larchmont.
Some old papers recently found cached in a basement-room ceiling in City Hall disclosed that in 1882 the Mayor way willing to work for $10,000 a year.

President Eisenhower's White House conference with Congressional leaders yesterday opened a critical year in the Middle East. The conference was held just two months after the British-French and Israeli attacks on Egypt.
Two factors led to a record coffee consumptions in the United States in 1956--increased population and lower average prices than in the previous two years.
The nation's scheduled airlines surpassed the previous year's operations during 1956, it has been reported.

Theodore Seltzer, president of Bengue, Inc., 2023 Kerrigan Avenue, Union City, N.J., manufacturers of a medicinal ointment, Baume Ben-Gay, and other products, died Monday in French Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 55 King Avenue, Weehawken, N.J.

Stock market activity simmered down in 1956. In 1954 The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks rose 52 per cent; in 1955 it was up 22 per cent. Last year, despite a number of brilliant individual performances, it rose only by 0.83 per cent.
WASHINGTON--President Eisenhower is more determined than ever to see the liberal foreign trade program he proposed to Congress three years ago enacted in its entirety.
A new corporate set-up for Printers' Ink, with a view to expansion, was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence Jr., president of the Printers' Ink Publishing Company.
It was a case of the big growing bigger and the small shrinking to almost nothing on the New York commodity exchanges last year.

The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority predicts a 70 per cent increase in the output of electrical energy within the next three years. According to S.L. Descartes, executive director, revenues over the period will rise by about 50 per cent.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)-- Corn Husker, in with the feather impost of 106 pounds, staged a tremendous rush in the stretch today to win the $29,000 San Gabriel Handicap at a mile and one-quarter on the grass. A crowd of 35,000 saw the Santa Anita feature.
Fringe benefits paid for workers' protection in the United States is 1956 rose to a new high level. Thus these payments, plus record wages and salaries, set a record in compensation for employes.
The year 1956 saw significant progress in all phases of the peaceful applications of atomic energy in the United States.
Charles E. Saltzman, former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, has become a general partner in Goldman, Sachs Co.
MILWAUKEE--Business activity in Milwaukee County in 1956 (first 10 months) was at a substantially higher level than in 1955.
The volume of production by the petrochemical industry last year was almost 10 per cent greater than that of 1955.
The police received a dozen frantic phone calls yesterday after the sidewalk explosion of a loud firecracker on West Fiftyseventh Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
High-level production and employment are putting a strain on the banks' ability to make new loans to business.
The apparel industry had a banner year in 1956. It expects continued good business.
New Year's Eve was just another working night for the police pickpocket squad, busier than most, in fact.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1--Pravda, Soviet Communist party newspaper, described today a new United States proposal for economic aid to the Middle East as a plan for permanent enslavement of that area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--Pooling of water resources and construction of road and rail networks are being considered by planners in the Eisenhower Administration for a long-range Middle Eastern development program.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) --Baylor's gang-tackling Bears, led by Del Shofner, upset Tennessee, the nation's No. 2 football team, 13 to 7, today in the Sugar Bowl. The wild game was marked by a third-quarter fist fight.
LONDON, Jan. 1--Discussions between Archbishop Makarios and representatives of the Colonial Office on Britain's proposals for self-government for Cyprus are continuing, it was indicated today.
SEATTLE--Sharp contrasts mark the Pacific Northwest economic picture as 1957 dawns.

The great wave of corporate mergers that began a few years ago continued unabated in 1956. There was one difference though: the Government took a much more active part in blocking consolidations it considered in restraint of trade.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP)--Trading on the London Stock Exchange was quiet today, with the world's other principal markets closed for New Year's Day. But jobbers reported a firm undertone.
MINNEAPOLIS--Merchants, industry and business men of the Ninth Federal Reserve district are looking ahead with confidence for an upsurge of the sixstate area's economy.

WASHINGTON Jan. 1--President Eisenhower demonstrated once again today the immense power of the Executive Branch of the Government when it desides to take the initiative with Congress in the field of foreign affairs.
Wool prices soared 50 per cent last year. While few expect the rate of increase to continue this year, few expect prices to return to the 1955 level.

COLUMBUS, Ohio--Business activity in the Columbus metropolitan area reached a peak in 1956 after a slow start. There were only a few exceptions to the trend. These included new incorporations and automobile sales.
New York City--the nation's leading commercial and industrial center--was the scene of speak activity in 1956.
For the last two years share turnover on the American Stock Exchange has been more than double that of any year between 1947 and 1953.
LOS ANGELES--With monotonous but impressive vigor, Southern California in 1956 continued its growth in terms of both habitation and commerce.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1-- Cary Grant has made a twopicture contract with Twentieth Century-Fox, although the studio has admitted only that the actor will co-star with Deborah Kerr in "Love Affair." That picture is scheduled to be made starting next month.
PARIS, Jan. 1--Little attention was paid here today to what has long been regarded as a basic French defeat--the passing of the Saar territory under German control.

Edwin J. Loewy, a vice president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., 1407 Broadway, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 930 Fifth Avenue. His age was 63.
The 17-state mutual savings bank industry is digging in its heels to fight for a greater share of the consumer's dollar.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--President Eisenhower announced today that additional Hungarian refugees would be admitted to the United States pending Congressional action on legislation to be submitted later.
PORTLAND, Oregon--The depressed lumber market, caused by tight money on home construction, hangs heavily over the Pacific Northwest economy.

The printing industry in the New York metropolitan area set a record for dollar volume last year. The industry, surpassed in size in the city only by clothing manufacture, is optimistic about this year's prospects.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn contended yesterday that the long-controversial IRT Nostrand Avenue subway extension project could begin producing an operating surplus in its eighth year of operation.
The post-war "shakedown" in the appliance and radio-television business reached its height last year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1--Going to work would be a pleasure if everyone could commute in the style offered by Chicago's "dream bus." It is expected to go into service soon.

United States consumption of wood pulp, the cellulose material used for making paper and rayon, rose to a record 24,055,000 tons in 1956. The total was 1,700,000 tons, or 7.8 per cent, larger than the comparable figure for 1955.

This is likely to be the best business year in history in the opinion of fourteen economists polled by the National Industrial Conference Board.

LONDON--Britain's shipbuilding industry enters 1957 prosperous, confident and with the biggest tonnage under construction in the world.

Some of the expansion and development projects by oil companies in the Middle East may have been deferred because of the Suez Canal developments, but have not been abandoned, according to oil executives here.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland--Two main trends were visible in Iceland in 1956. These were mounting economic difficulties and increased trade with the Soviet Union. Both are of political origin.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 2--The University of Connecticut, the winner of the recent Orange Bowl, tournament at Miami Beach, met its match tonight. The Uconns lost to Dartmouth, 70--67, in an overtime contest.

ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP)-- William Chapman Potter, former president and board chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died today at his plantation home near here after a long illness. He was 82 years old.
BONN, Germany--West Germany achieved the status in 1956 of the world's third greatest trading nation. Her commerce was surpassed only by that of the United States and Britain.
The British-French and Israeli attacks on Egypt have strengthened Communist influence in the Middle East.
The International Sugar Council, which has set export quotas for the last three years, has completed its first truly successful year.

President Eisenhower has ordered the continued admission of Hungarian refugees beyond the present quota of 21,500. At the same time he is preparing to ask Congress to open the door much wider to refugees from all countries suffering from Communist oppression.
Sugar prices moved up sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Both the world and domestic markets were influenced by sizable sales of actual sugar at higher prices.
Percy Hampton Johnston, honorary chairman of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank of New York, died in Honolulu yesterday in St. Francis Hospital. His age was 76.

WELLINGTON, N.Z.--For New Zealand, 1956 was a rather difficult year. The deliberate deflation of the credit squeeze gradually made itself felt in damping down an exuberant economy that was expanding too fast for its own good.

Aleer J. Couri, whose resignation as United States Appraiser of Merchandise was accepted by President Eisenhower on Monday, has been named a special consultant to the United States Commissioner of Customs.
The Swiss watch industry is about to start a fresh advertising drive to win a lower tariff rate on its jeweled watch movements.

DUBLIN--Ireland is passing through a fiscal and economic crisis brought about by the deficit in her trade balance, inadeguate capital for productive enterprises, the failure of agriculture to expand its exports fast enough, and underemployment. The latter has caused a heavy increase in the emigration of young persons in the last four years.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 1--President Eisenhower's enthusiasm for the European bicycling habit promises happier United States-Dutch relations in 1957, at least in the realm of the two-wheeler.
MANILA--The year 1957 is generally conceded to be critical for the Philippine economy.

PARIS--By virtue of the Paris-Bonn agreements of September 29, 1956, the Saar will be economically reintegrated with Germany Dec. 31, 1959, at the latest. The exact date will be set by a joint decision substituting, the Deutsche mark for the franc.

NEW DELHI, India--Pakistan's nine years of work toward a stronger economy ran into a major roadblock in 1956: food shortages.
RABAT, Morocco--In her first year of independence, Morocco has experienced most of the economic evils of transition and has not yet begun to benefit from the potential economic advantages of freedom.

ANKARA, Turkey--The volume and value of Turkey's exports and imports during 1956 dropped sharply below those of the previous year.
An issue of $10,000,000 of bonds of the King County, Wash., School District 1 (Seattle) is to be put up for sale on Jan. 16. The bonds will come due serially from 1959 to 1977.

Saturday afternoon professional hockey games will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System for ten weeks, beginning this Saturday at 2 o'clock.
The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it "deplored" the action of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany in placing a ban on the Strand Theatre for showing the motion picture "Baby Doll."
TORONTO, Jan. 2 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings regained the National Hockey League lead tonight by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2--0, for Glenn Hall's second shutout of the season.

The New York Knickerbockers and the Syracuse Nationals will meet in the feature game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

In the smallest and narrowest market since Nov. 23, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday greeted the New Year with a decline in prices. Rails, thanks to a late rally by Baltimore and Ohio and New York Central, closed about even. Industrials, especially steels, chemicals and international oils, were lower.

Cornelius F. Cahalane, retired police consultant of the Port of New York Authority and former Deputy Chief Inspector of the city Police Department, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in his home, 431 East Twentieth Street. His age was 81.

The Manufacturers Trust Company reported yesterday net operating earnings for 1956 of $18,093,040, or $3.59 a share, compared with $16,202,803, or $3.22 a share, the year before. Share earnings in each case were based on the 5,039,000 shares now outstanding.

The private carting industry moved yesterday, to set up a code of ethics. Joseph F. Periconi, former State Senator from the Bronx, was named by the Greater New York Cartmen's Association to do the job.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 2 (UP)-- Iyo Pimental of Venezuela scored the first big upset in the Dixie international tennis tournament today, defeating the fourth-seeded Roger Becker of England in the opening round, 4--6, 6--3, 6--3.

In the summer of 1953 a chunk of marble fell from the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. Many other bits have fallen since then, but a tug of war among city officials has delayed the repairing of New York's monument to Civil War heroes.

TOKYO, Jan. 3--Government sources were quoted by Tokyo newspapers today as saying an agreement had been reached with Washington on the regulation of textile exports to the United States. ZURICH, Switzerland--New peaks were achieved in almost every branch of business last year. National income was believed to have exceeded the record of 1955. As price levels did not rise appreciably, the gain was real.
A political and economic crisis of the first magnitude gripped much of the Communist world's economy as 1956 ended.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 2--The Soviet freighter Admiral Senyavin arrived unexpectedly in Balboa today from the Pacific. The 4,107-ton vessel was inspected promptly and formalities were concluded for the freighter to move through the canal northbound tomorrow.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 2--A great ice floe, driven by winds of near hurrican force, slammed the United States Navy freighter Arneb against the coast of Antarctica yesterday.
TORONTO, Jan. 2--The Abitibi Power and Paper Company today announced an increase of $4 a ton in the price of newsprint, effective March 1.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark-- Whereas industrial production increased in most European countries in 1956, it stagnated in Denmark. In September last, the Danish production index was 132 points or exactly the same as in 1955. In the last five years Denmark has had the smallest increase of production in Europe. This has caused anxiety.
Waterfront labor contract negotiations, which have run into a long series of obstacles and delays since they began last summer, may meet a new snag when they resume this morning.

A consent order to reinstate a Brooklyn College teacher with more than $40,000 in back pay, interest and court costs was signed yesterday by Justice Thomas E. Morrissey Jr. in Kings County Supreme Court.
ABOARD THE ENDEAVOUR AT SEA, Jan. 2--This ship, laden with dogs, aircraft and men of the Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition, has escaped from the icepack into the teeth of a gale.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 2--Pakistan asked the Security Council today to take up the Kashmir question. She warned that unless the drawn-out dispute with India was resolved "the gravest consequences might ensue."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP)-- Bill Talbert, the nonplaying captain of the United States Davis Cup team, said today America must revise its thinking on tennis or content itself with being a secondary figure in international competition.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 2 --Indonesia's Cabinet met in emergency session tonight to discuss a proposal that it resign.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2 (AP)--Lloyd Jordan, the twentyfirst coach in Harvard's eightytwo-year football history, said tonight a ranking committee at the university had voted to dismiss him.
This year promises to be the most critical since World War II for many national economies and private businesses.
HELSINKI, Finland--It is estimated that Finland's over-all production rose 3 per cent in 1956 despite the three-week general strike in March.

At first thought, it might seem unwise to attach too much significance to the remarks of Nikita S. Khrushchev when those remarks are made at the height of a New Year's Eve party with liquid refreshments flowing bountifully.

TOKYO--Japan is rapidly returning to the forefront among the great industrial nations. This is evidenced by humming factories, bustling offices, roaring traffic and huge, welldressed throngs in hundreds of richly-stocked department stores of the nation.

The First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday net operating earnings for last year of $51,962,046, or $5.20 a share, compared with $42,466,976, or $4.25 a share, in 1955. The figures reflected combined earnings of the bank and its af filiate, City Bank Farmers Trust Company.
These letters and numbers were the first registered on the New York Stock Exchange ticker in 1957.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 2 --A new Government program that, it is predicted, will go far to meet the demands of the Hungarian revolutionaries is expected to be announced Sunday.
Grand Central Terminal's investment information center was transformed yesterday into an insurance clearing house with the formal opening of a New York Life Insurance Company exhibit.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2--Paced by soybeans, grain futures generally rose today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--A coalition of fourteen Northern Democrats and Republicans drafted plans today to change the Senate's filibuster rule as a first step toward obtaining passage of civil rights legislation.
Early in the fight a leatherlunged ringsider let go a blast at Sugar Ray Robinson.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway broke a corporate record yesterday--the first working day of the new year--by mailing a "flash" annual report to its shareholders.

The epidemic of bomb hoaxes spread yesterday to schools. The police were not surprised They had expected such scares as an effort by pupils to extend the Christmas holiday recess However, they took no chances and searched the supposedly threatened buildings.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 2 --Rhode Island Republicans planned today to challenge Gov. Dennis J. Roberts' right to a fourth term by an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

"Small War on Murray Hill," a comedy by the late Robert E. Sherwood dealing with a vital interlude in the American Revolution, has its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 2-- The right to express opposition "is a fundamental privilege of democracy," Gov. Luis Munoz Marin declared today.
The high command of the united labor movement has given an object lesson to its 140 autonomous international unions by moving to make its own household a model of clean unionism.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--President Eisenhower replied today to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's latest note on disarmament but gave the Kremlin no hint of what United States counter-proposals would be.
ALBANY, Jan. 2--Governor Harriman has decided to recommend a series of electoral reforms next Wednesday to the incoming Legislature.
MONTREAL, Jan. 2--The Canadian Pacific Railway's transcontinental rail operations were paralyzed today by a strike that made 75,000 workers idle.

"THE LAST PARALLEL," a Marine's Korean war journal, is a current Book of-the-Month Club selection and, probably, a book for the years that sets new standards for candid narratives about citizens in armor.
HONG KONG--The true state of Communist China's economy is as difficult to determine as the exact extent of its ambitions in Asia.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (UP) --Larry Hickman, Baylor's fullback, apologized today at the bedside of Tennessee's Bruce Burnham for the kick in the head that sent the Vol guard to the hospital with a minor concussion and a broken nose.

Gene Fullmer's first name is just that--Gene. Not Eugene, not Jean, but just plain Gene. It seems that his father was a great admirer of a former heavyweight champion, Gene Tunney and he named his son after him.

A lean, glib cello player from Tarrytown, N.Y., named Heliodoro "Call me Ric" Rico, always wanted to become a famous trackman. But he was only an average sprinter on the New York University squad, so he switched to law. This week he is possibly Manhattan's most overworked barrister--all because his never-subsiding interest in track got the better of him.

PROBABLY more good game has been ruined by tricky cooking than any other comestible known to man. It seems to goad people into a frenzy over wine sauces, herbs, spices, odd garnishings and complex mixtures.

GROTON, Conn., Jan. 2 (AP)-- Vice Admiral Wilson Brown, naval aide to four Presidents and superintendent of the Naval Academy from 1938 to 1941, died today at the Submarine Base Hospital here. He was 74 years old.

Twenty-four years ago next May Congress started to realize the dream of the late Senator George Norris of Nebraska by creating the Tennessee Valley Authority. T.V.A. was to help develop all the resources of the Tennessee Valley, including farming forests and wildlife, navigation potentialities and--above all--hydroelectric power.

I have given careful consideration to the declaration by the Soviet Government to which you had invited my attention in your letter of Nov. 17, 1956, but find myself in basic disagreement with the analysis of your Government as it relates to the source of international tension.
Dr. Isaac N. Steinberg of 310 West Eighty-sixth Street, secretary general of the Freeland League for Jewish Territorial Colonization, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 68.
A thank offering to two physicians turned into a gift to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

TOKYO--Great expectations still are held by Japanese traders and industrialists for a greatly expanded trade with Communist China and the Soviet Union now that a peace agreement has been concluded with Moscow.

A former treasurer of the Abyssinian Baptist Church Federal Credit Union, was indicted yesterday on charges of embezzlement. He has been a close associate of the church's pastor Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
CAIRO--Under current conditions Egypt must import about 400,000 tons of wheat annually. The remainder of about 600,000 tons consumed each year is produced in Egypt.
CAIRO, Jan. 3 (AP)--Continuing political ferment in the Arab world was evidenced today in reports ranging from Yemenite charges of aggression to plans for an Iraqi government in exile.
HALIFAX, N.S.--Nova Scotia's economy continued its forward trend last year, and there was every indication this would be maintained during 1957.
Increases in the price of crude oil sent petroleum issues shooting up in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Jan. 3--The heavy drain put on Britain's gold and dollar reserves by the need to support sterling has been checked.
Economic activity in Jamaica attained peak levels last year, notably in new industrialization that will add to future progress.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--Hydroelectric power development continues to be a matter of the highest importance in British Columbia. It is a subject with international ramifications that must be resolved eventually at the top level.
RIO DE JANEIRO--There is an exciting tale in South America these days: the tale of its boom cities.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks dropped $2ll,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The drop was the largest weekly reduction since 1954. In the same week last year business loans were down $114,000,000.
The nuclear power timetable for Latin America is running on schedule.

THREE should be more than one forum for the un hackneyed. The Metropolitan Museum of Art has had the vision, thanks to the gift of an anonymous donor, to organize three concerts dedicated to such a purpose.
Sixteen top squash racquets players will compete in the fourth United States Open singles championship tomorrow and Sunday at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--It is quite too flip a term to do justice to so sober and bookish a man; the temptation, nevertheless, is overpowering to call Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana the poor man's Walter George.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras-- The three-man military Junta that took power Oct. 21 will soon have to make decisions involving the political and economic future of Honduras.

BOSTON, Jan. 3--A measure of both the difficulties and phenomenal accomplishments of Station WGBH-TV, the country's only educational noncommercial video outlet on the Eastern seaboard, is to be found in its minuscule budget in the electronic era.
The text of a Chinese Communist statement last week asked for a measure of real independence for non-Soviet Communist parties.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3--A Federal distirct, judge ruled today that Florida and Miami bus segregation laws were unconstitutional.

When legislative and political leaders meet Monday in the Hotel Roosevelt to try to nominate a successor to Jacob K. Javits as State Attorney General we think the time will have come to stop the foolishness and get down to fundamentals.
The electronic computer has been put to work on a new job for advertising.

OTTAWA--The extent and effect of foreign, particularly United States, investment in Canada will form an important part of the report of the Royal Commission on Canada's economic prospects later this year.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--Salmon fishing, British Columbia's fouth largest industry and one of the bulwarks of Canada's export's trade, is getting very close attention from scientists, who believe the run can be considerably increased.

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday net operating earnings for last year of $49,213,201, or $3.78 a share. This compared with $42,302,708, or $3.25 a share, in 1955. Earnings in both cases were computed on the 13,000,000 shares now outstanding.
The need for the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., to raise its newsprint price $4 a ton was challenged yesterday in light of the Canadian concern's recent large gains in net earnings.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3--A large East German delegation headed by Premier Otto Grotewohl arrived today with assurances of continued solidarity with the Russians.
The State Chamber of Commerce gave its support yesterday to continued United States participation in the International Labor Organization.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3--The United States plans to construct an air base in central Taiwan (Formosa) for Nationalist China, the cost of which is estimated at $25,000,000.

In the chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon Miss Celia Grant Larson became the bride of David Sturtevent Ruder. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Frederick Morris, performed the ceremony. A small reception was given in the River Club.

TORONTO, Ont.--The Toronto Stock Exchange, which enjoyed record-breaking business for the first eight months of 1956, suddenly finds its forward sweep halted by the Federal Government's tight-money policy and the Suez situation.
Britain has sold a fourth turbine airliner type in the North American dollar market.
RIO DE JANEIRO--The Brazilian economy was a mixture of brightness and gloomy shadows in 1956.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 --Screen Gems has added six series to a schedule of pilot films to be offered to networks and sponsors for the 1957-58 season.
TORONTO-Uranium remains the glamour metal of Canadian mining
WARSAW, Jan. 3--Nomina tions of candidates for the first Parliamentary election to be held under the Gomulka regime are taking place in Poland.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld.--A lumberman from New York will begin this winter to harvest black spruce from the fabulous groves of Labrador, Newfoundland's northern storehouse of natural wealth.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- The current economic paroxysms of Boliva demand drastic counter-measures but are only temporary and are on the way to solution, according to Vice President Dr. Nuflo Chavez Ortiz.
ALL but one of Robert Sherwood's admirable qualities can be found in the posthumous "Small War on Murray Hill," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening.
TWO Balanchine ballets had their first presentations of the season in last night's performance by the New York City Ballet at the City Center.

A fourth victory was gained by Alberic O'Kelly de Galway of Belgium in yesterday's sixth round of the international masters' chess tournament at the annual Congress in Hastings, England, according to a report received from British news sources.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's letter to Governor Harriman on the city's fiscal program:
WHEN Mildred Dilling plays the harp in the smaller towns in this country, she likes to tell the audience, between numbers, something of the instrument's ancient and romantic history.

In further restoration of their united front, breached at Suez, the United States, Britain and France have joined in rejecting "in the present circumstances" the Soviet propaganda proposal for a new "summit" meeting on disarmament.

Chris Brasher speaks as he runs--forthrightly. Yesterday at a luncheon at the University Club, Brasher minced no words in accusing the International Olympic Committee of being the prime factor in the "nationalistic" aspect of the world-wide athletic games.
