TORONTO--The battle of the Canadian brewers, begun in earnest in 1953, foamed to its biggest head yet in l956.

LIMA, Peru--Anyone painting a portrait of Peru in the year just past would use both drab and bright colors. Which tone would predominate in 1957 depends upon a number of factors, principally fiscal and political.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--Following are the officers of the new Congress, and of the major parties in Congress, who have been elected or are assured of election:
CHICAGO, Jan. 3--January soybeans ran into moderate selling early in today's session on the Board of Trade.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--At the end of What will probably prove to be the best year in its history, British Columbia looked to 1957 confidently but without what one business observer called "the shear optimism" of twelve months ago.

HAVANA--The world demand for sugar that has forced the price to the highest level since 1951 and the cauntry's rapid progress in industrialization promises to make 1957 a highly prosperous year for Cuba.
Small apartment properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn passed to near control in realty transactions reported yesterday.
YOU can write it in big type, one of our scouts in the wholesale market told us yesterday, eggs are the lowest in many years, even lower than "the low, low year of 1954-55."

ALBANY--The combined Seaway and power projects rising along the St. Lawrence River have raised hopes among business men and industialists in northern New Work that a new and more prosperous economicera is on the horizon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3--Pakistan is expected to ask the Security Council to send a United Nations military force into Kashmir.
Exports of coffee by LatinAmerican countries last year were the largest in history.
The medical profession was urged here last night to improve its human relations with pa tients. The suggestion came from Charles Garside, president and chairman of the Associated Hospital Service.
DETROIT,Jan. 3--Michigan State University at East Lansing became taday the second Michigan, educational institution in three weeks to receive a $10,000,000 gift.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 3--By Monday no Israeli troops will be west of El Arish in the Sinai desert, a Government spokesman said tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3--The General Assembly's Political Committee voted today to invite South Korea to participate in discussions on unification and rehabilitation of Korea.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island--Canada's general prosperity, and the expanding developments in the country's Atlantic provinces are looked to here to provide a stimulous to this province's economic future.

CARACAS--Venezuela's boom was expanded in 1956 by the granting of the first new oil concessions in eleven years. Along with this was the continuing construction spree, huge public works and domestic new production records in oil and iron ore and manufacturing industries.
WINNIPEG--This year the Canadian prairies produced 516,000,000 bushels of wheat--9 per cent more than in 1955 and 17 per cent more than the average for the past 10 years.
SANTIAGO, Chile--After many years of inflation, Chile has finally turned the corner.
The first electric wrist watch available to the public was introduced yesterday by the Hamilton Watch Company, Lancaster, Pa.
Five hundred Jewish communal and Zionist leaders honored Louis Lipsky last night for his more than sixty years of service to the American Zionist movement and American Jewish organizational life.
The nation's crude oil production in the week ended last Friday set a new peak average of 7,392,350 barrels a day, according to the American, Petroleum Institute.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP)--George D. Widener's Ambergris, winner over Decathlon in the Wilson at Jamaica last season, marked his winter debut with an impressive triumph in the featured seventh race today. The Tropical Park program attracted 10,058 chilled patrons.

VANCOUVER., B.C.--The expanding activity of B.C. Airlines, one of the oldest charter services on the West Coast which recently came under new management, has pointed to the continuing role of the bush pilot in the development of British Columbia.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica--The two major crops of this predominantly agricultural country played see-saw during 1956. As banana production fell steeply, coffee went up, in both production and price.

BOGOTA, Colombia--Colombia, in the last year has developed the worst economic crisis in her history, according to economists and business men. But she will emerge from it if the Government pursues effective measures, these sources say.
About 250,000 subway riders were delayed as much as two hours last night in one of the worst rush-hour tie-ups in recent years.
Mayor Wagner's office made public a five-year fiscal program yesterday under which the city is seeking $147,000,000 of additional financial help from the state by 1961-62.
The Detroit Harvester Company, in its fiscal year ended last Sept. 30, increased sales 25 per cent to a record high. Earnings were the highest in six years.
The Board of Education's proposed budget request of $22,000,000 for increasing teachers' salaries in 1957-58 drew mixed reaction yesterday from three teacher groups.
INDORE, India, Jan. 3--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru guided India's ruling party today to a new attack on military pacts and militaiy build-ups.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti-- Haiti, with a troubulous political year behind her a looking toward what at its best could only be described as an uncertain year economically. The country is in need of outside help.
BUENOS AIRES-- Argen tina's economy was set on the road to recovery last year. But the Provisional Government was well aware that it faced a long drive before it reached its objective.

World sugar futures continued strong in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices rose 3 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 33,050 tons. The spot price climber 5 points to 5.15 cents a pound the highest level since 1952, when quotations were influenced by the Korean conflict.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The convictions of a New York lawyer and a former instructor at Vassar College of contempt of Congress were upheld today by the Federal Court of Appeals.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- With United Nations help, a number of Latin-American countries have pushed ahead with programs to expand their iron and steel industries in 1957.
The Worth Street station of the IRT, Lexington Avenue line will be eliminated within the next two years, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.
MONCTON, N.B.--Canada's four Atlantic provinces today are poised for the next step in their united attempt to improve their economic condition.

A voluble Gene Fullmer, happy and unmarked, appeared at the headquarters of the International Boxing Club yesterday to pick up a check for $20,915,40. That was his share of the surprising gate of $194,645.20 paid by a crowd of 18,134 that saw Fullmer lift the world middleweight championship from Ray Robinson at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.
The next chapter in the history of the Middle East is certain to be bright with the wealth of oil and dark with the abundance of misery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The Public Health Service announced today the formation of a marriage registration area consisting of twenty-nine states, four territories and one independent city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The House of Representatives organized for the Eighty-fifth Congress today with harmony the keynote.

QUITO, Ecuador--Until recently, Ecuador's wealthy persons along the coast preferred to invest their capital in the import and export business, those from the Sierra in rural or urban land. As a result, industries were slow to develop. Of late, however, there has been an important change.
OTTAWA--Canada's $375,000,000 cross-country pipeline to carry natural gas from the rich fields in Alberta to the industrial centers in the East finally was started last year.

A LONG ISLAND SOUND rock hunter is a man who will do almost anything to get a shot at a duck. Among the more agonizing things he will do is spend money. He will freeze, too, but that doesn't hurt so much.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- The House International Operations subcommittee reported today that millions in United States aid to Iran had been administered in a "loose, slipshod" way that was "shocking."
Martin T. Lacey has pulled out of the bitter fight for control of 125,000 union truck drivers and warehousemen in the metropolitan area.
The price of petroleum in the Southwest goes up today an average of 35 cents a barrel, or about 12 per cent.

Stewart McDonald, former Federal Housing Administrator, died of pneumonia yesterday in Doctors Hospital. His age was 77, He entered the hospital last Friday from his apartment in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

While the United Nations salvage vessels work their slow way up or down the Suez Canal, and as the Israeli troops withdraw slowly across the Sinai Desert but not from Gaza, and President Eisenhower and his advisers outline a new Middle Eastern policy--while all this is going on the problem of mode than 900,000 Arab refugees remains unsolved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--In appraising the qualifica tions of Everett McKinley Dirksen to be the the Republican's new whip in the Senate, there are those who find special significance in the Senator's middle name.
It was clear where Leonard Bernstein's sympathies lay in his concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall.
The aggregate of new Canadian bond issues payable in United States dollars reached a record high level in 1956, more than 30 per cent in excess of the previous post-war--high established in 1951.
Johnny Podres, the hero of the victorious Dodgers in the 1955 world series, yesterday became the third player to accept terms with the Brooklyn club. The others are Pee Wee Reese and Don Newcombe.

Darrell Royal and the University of Texas made such a striking impression on each other a couple of weeks ago that it took only a few minutes for the former Oklahoma quarterback to agree to coach the Longhorn football team for the next five seasons.
WASHINGTON Jan. 3-- President Eisenhower announced today the designation of James T. O'Connell of Upper Mont clair, N.J., as Under Secretary of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The Senate arranged today for the orderly burial tomorrow of a bipartisan move for an effective curb on filibusters.

MONTREAL--News from Europe and the Middle East, tighter credit and a weakening in the foreign price of copper appeared to have a somewhat depressive effect on the Canadian business picture in the latter part of 1956.

Many subscribers have been reported for the eighteenth annual White Elephant Party, to be held in the ballroom of the Ambassador on Jan. 18. With the support of the subscribers and Rheingold, sponsors of the event, it will be possible for all proceeds to go to the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association to aid its work in behalf of homeless children.
QUEBEC--The total value of mineral production in Quebec reached a record figure of more than $440,000,000 in 1956, according to a recent announcement by the provincial Mines Minister.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 3-- Christopher Del Sesto, the Republican candidate who lost the Governorship of Rhode Island, today explained why he would not contest the decision further legally.
QUEBEC--Mining development in the far northern region of Quebec is centered on the socalled Labrador Trough, which actually is a broad, low ridge.

PANAMA--Industrial projects that may have a far-reaching permanent effect on Panama's economy took root in the Republic last year.
REGINA, Sask.--Nature smiled again in 1956 on Saskatchewan's oft droughtscourged 110,000 farmers.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay-- The Uruguayan peso, quoted at 3.60 to $1 last January, sank to its lowest level, 4.50 to $1, in July, but early in December had climbed back to 3.80 and the outlook was that it would continue rising.
About 13,000 commuter's on three railroads were delayed up to an hour and twenty-two minutes at the height of the mornning rush hour yesterday.
Cotton futures, moved 8 points up to 3 points off yesterday in a small volume of trading.
"The Maltese Falcon," a feature film produced by Warner Brothers Pictures in 1941, was withdrawn suddenly from television yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--A report highly critical of George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, has been filed with the Massachusetts legislature by a special commission that investigated the railroad.

SAN SALVADOR--El Salvador, predominantly agricultural, ended 1956 with prospects of abundant crops and good prices for her chief exports, coffee and cotton. At the same time, with a United Nations economic agency lending a hand, business leaders hoped for continued industrial expansion.

Contract negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association and New York waterfront employers got off to a "fresh start" yesterday.
READING, Pa., Jan. 3 (U.P.)--A woman and five children of preschool age burned to death today in a one-story frame home at Temple, five miles north of Reading.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad-- In his address at the opening of the Trinidad Legislative Council in October, 1954, the Governor, Sir Hubert Rance, urged the colony to take stock of its financial position.

"Twelfth Night," the eighth presentation by Donald H. GOldman's, band of Shakespearwrights, will be presented at 7:45 O'clock tonight in their 199seat theatre at 264 West Eightyseventh Street. HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Jan. 3 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which is in the process of regrouping its production forces, has made a deal with Alfred Hitchcock to produce and direct "The Wreck of the Mary Deare:"

JUST as usual on the first week-end in January, Edward J. Wormley is in Chicago. The International Home Furnishings Market opens there on Monday and Mr. Wormley makes it a point to be present.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 3--Charles Edwin Clapp Jr. of near-by Campbell, author and free-lance writer, died yesterday in University Hospital here of a bacterial infection of the blood stream. He had been in the hospital for five weeks. He Was 57 years old.
The vigorous drive by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to curtail highway tragedies here a last year proved effective.
MEXICO CITY--Except in the drought regions 1956 was the third successive year of good crops and prosperity for Mexico.
Fourteen of the twenty common stocks that made the best gains in points in the year's first market session continued upward yesterday.

Cecil Smith of San Antonio and Bob Skene of Beverly Hills, Calif., the nation's only active ten-goal outdoor polo players, retained their high rating in the 1957 handicap list, released yesterday by the United States Polo Association.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 3-- An immediate clean-up of the "mess" caused by the construction of part of the Connecticut Turnpike was demanded today by the Greenwich Board of Selectmen.
TORONTO--Canada's aircraft manufacturing industry has grown to the position of a $400,000,000-a-year producer.
OTTAWA-- The $900,000,000 project of trarsforming the sprawling St. Lawrence into a gigantic electric powerhouse and one of the world's great trade routes is nearly half finished.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 3 --The Government had another mine strike on its hands today. It occurred in Tatabanya, one of the most important coalmining centers of Hungary.

TRENTON, Jan. 3--Gov. Robert B. Meyner is expected to propose next month a record $340,000,000 state budget for the fiscal year 1957-58.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) --The Government today sold its tin smelter at Texas City, Tea., to the Wah Chang Corporation of New York, for $1,350,000 plus a sum not to exceed $2,000,000, based on future production.
WASHINGTON, Jan.3--The Eighty-fifth Congress assembled today under unchallenged Democratic control. It prepared at once to meet a historic foreign policy issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (U.P.)-- Adlai E. Stevenson critized President Eisenhower's proposed new Middle East policy today as a "military blank check to fight in the Middle East."
David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, asserted yesterday that his union was entirely free of racketeers and pledged to keep it so as long as he was in office.
New debentures and common shares of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, priced to yield the company about $15,000,000, will be offered to investors today.

The Knickerbockers fluctuated from hot to cold and from slick to sloppy at Madison Square Garden last night, but at no time were they in danger of losing to the Syracuse Nationals. At the end of a trying night it was a 126-111 victory for the New Yorkers.

A company founded on the idea that United States capital and know-how could help raise living standards abroad--and make a reasonable profit at the same time--is expanding in several directions in Latin America.

EDMONTON, Alberta--Alberta is expected to prove a fertile ground for new capital investments this year. There are many projects of interest to Canadian, United States and overseas capital.
The New Republic, a weekly journal of opinion since 1914, will go off newsstands and be available only to mail subscribers starting with its March 4 issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- Wearing white orchids, two new women members of Congress took the oath of office today with 426 ether members of the House of Representatives.

ALBANY, Jan. 3--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits an nounced tonight that he would not join the group of United States Senators who will attempt tomorrow to change the chambers rules in the interests of civil rights legislation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (U.P.) --The Pacific Coast Conference voted unanimously today to uphold penalties against four member schools for permitting excessive financial aid to athletes.
The Federal Reserve System began to contract the money supply last week in line with reduced post-holiday needs for funds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--A Congressional committee reported today that the crash of the liners Andrea Doria and the Stockholm last July could have been avoided if crewmen had "properly used" the information provided by radar.
A strong possibility has arisen that the Metropolitan Opera will take over the artistic administration of the New York City Opera Company.
Several gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund arrived yesterday with expressions of regret that they had not been sent sooner.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 3-- France and Morocco have concluded an agreement granting Morocco 17,000,000,000 francs ($48,570,000) in credits.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 3--The United States announced today that it would lend the United Nations up to $5,000,000 to help meet the initial cost of clearing the Suez Canal.

The Broadway success "Dial M for Murder" has rung a wrong number in Moscow.

Los Angeles raised $18,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance sewage and airport improvements.

A bowling program that would be televised live each Saturday from 10:30 to 11:30 P.M. is tentatively scheduled to make its debut Jan. 19 over WOR-TV.
Tonight's off-Broadway premire is "Capacity for Wings" at the 125-seat Royal Playhouse, 62 last Fourth Street. The opening performance will start at 8 o'clock.

Melvin Senville, builder, who recently announced plans for a new office building at 360 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Fortieth Street, yesterday reported a revision in the design.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday took the wraps off its new lightweight train, the Dan'l Webster, in a blaze that was not entirely glorious.
When the New York Rangers meet the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at Madison Square Garden, they will be experimenting with a new starting time--7:30.

The United Nations does not always speak in long-drawn-out debates, nor with measured sentences, nor in carefully weighed reports, nor in words at all. Sometimes it speaks in the universal language of pictures.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8-- How to maintain academic standards while college enrollment doubles occupied the attention of the nation's leading educators here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--The Eisenhower Administration will ask Congress for record appropriations to finance expanded welfare, programs in the 1958 fiscal year, beginning July 1. The stress will be on aid to health and education.

WARSAW, Jan. 9--A new policy aimed at pacifying Polish peasants was announced today.

A difficult program, one decked with a few glittering arrangements, was played last night in Town Hall by Josette and Yvette Roman. These sisters make up quite a skillful two-piano combination. As in previous years...

J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation, taxed metropolitan newspapers yester day with "doing a miserable job" in reporting the story that developed out of disclosures of corruption in Suffolk County.
CAIRO, Jan. 10 (AP)--The international Red Cross is arranging for a second ship to carry Jews who are being expelled by Egypt or are leaving under duress.
LONDON, Jan. 10--The stock market welcomed the news today that Harold liacmillan was the new Prime Minister with some recovery in prices.
The Bell System found 1956 to be "another eventful and progressive year," Frederick R. Kappel, president, told stockholders in the quarterly and preliminary annual report issued...
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 10--Five Negro ministers were arrested here today for refusing yesterday to observe the state law requiring segregated seating on a city bus.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 10--Mr. and Mrs. Medley P. Ray have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret M. Ray, to Robert Whitcomb Herring. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Herring.

The president of the American Medical Association believes that "the voluntary health insurance movement in this country, built on the premise that protection is a better buy than benefits, is one of the most dramatic stones of our time."
WASHINGTON, Jan, 10--Two Senate committees were still maneuvering today for the right to investigate labor racketeering. Back of the maneuvers lay big-time politics.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Republican legislators were hopeful today that they would be able to stave off any increase in state gasoline taxes for at least two years.

Actors Equity has rejected a request from Herman Levin, producer of "My Fair Lady" and president of the League of New York Theatres, to engage Edward Mulhare, Irish performer, as a temporary replacement for...
CHICAGO, Jan. 10--Wheat futures generally showed strength early in today's session on the Board of Trade. But prices eased toward the close and finished with small changes.
Your chairman's cordial invitation, on your committee's behalf, to meet yith you and express my views on the President's request for authority in relation to the Middle East brings me before you.
A week-end is just ahead that skiers dream about all summer. Conditions are so good throughout the north country that enthusiasts can head for the mountains without a worry.
The Administration in Washington has recognized that there are many inadequacies in the medical and hospital expense insurance that 70 per cent of the American people already own.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10-- Business and industry gave $100,000,000 to American institutions of higher learning last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan.10--President Eisenhower called today for a "broad national inquiry" into the nation's financial system, public and private, to see what it is, how it works and whether it functions to the best advantage.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 10-- Gabriela Mistral, Chilean poet who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1945, died today of cancer at the Hempstead General Hospital. Her age was 67. She had lived since 1953 in Roslyn Harbor.
CAIRO, Jan. 10 (Reuters)-- Yemen's Ambassador to Egypt has challenged Britain to allow neutral observers into the AdenYemen borderlands where, he said, "tension is very high."
Rochester, N.Y., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 19 on $3,300,000 of bonds to finance various improvements. The oblibations will come due serially from 1958 to 1970.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10-- The directors of Provident Trust Company and the Tradesmens Bank and Trust Company today approved plans for merging the two institutions into a half-billion dollar institution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- President Eisenhower warned Congress today against the dangers of inflation from excessive price increases, wage rises or Government spending.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Congress found little to cheer or criticize in President Eisenhower's Message on the State of the Union today, but that seemed to be the way the President wanted it.
Contract negotiations involving this port's 3,500 tugboat and oil craft workers bogged down yesterday afternoon. No future talks were scheduled.

From prospering West Germany came the news yesterday that tight money would be looser, effective today. According to Reuters, the British news agency, the West German central Deutscher Laender Bank lowered its discount rate from...

The 1957 world championship at contract bridge appeared almost certain yesterday to be going to Italy. In forty-eight hands played yesterday, Italy's champions battered the United States squad to increase their lead to 7,980 points at the end of seven of nine sessions.
The State Banking Department plans to seek a law to make independent bank audits mandatory. It said yesterday it was considering asking a similar requirement for credit unions.

PIBROCHS and strathspeys will fill the great Ninth Regiment Armory in Fourteenth Street west of the Avenue of the Americas tomorrow night. It is the night of the annual Pipers' Ball. The mu sic will well and bubble from...

MANY, many years ago in the ancient and barbarous kingdom of Glome there was a wicked king who had three daughters. The eldest, the Princess Orual, was so ugly that she wore a veil to hide her humiliation. The middle princess, Redival by name, was pretty enough, but wanton and base of mind and soul.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Eisenhower proposed today international control of "outer space" missile and satellite development as a disarmament measure.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10--The General Assembly voted today to establish a fivenation committee to watch the situation in Hungary.

The merriest title scramble in years is in prospect in the Ivy Hockey League, which opens its twenty-third season tomorrow. The five sextets have had as many ups and downs as a roller coaster in their preliminary skirmishing.
Freezing temperatures and heavy snow yesterday gave the northern part of the nation its worst weather of the winter.

TOWNSHEND, Vt., Jan. 10-- Philip Darrell Sherman, former Professor of English at Oderlin College, died yesterday at Grace Cottage Hospital, after long illness. His age was 75. He had resided in Vermont since 1947.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan, 10--A fear that a, lack of religious teachers posed a serious threat to the future development of American Jewish religious life was expressed here today.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. summoned about twenty officers of the three major firemen's line organizations to his office yesterday and accused them of "shockingly intemperate and irresponsible" actions.

The heavy task of pulling Britain out of the political and economic slump resulting from the Suez fiasco has now fallen on a new man, Harold Macmillan, appointed Prime Minister to succeed the ailing Sir Anthony Eden.

IGOR STRAVINSKY has been guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony on a number of occasions. He has seldom, if ever, been received with the warmth and affection which were his reward at Carnegie Hall last...
Stocks yesterday made the best gains thus far in 1957--but they were small. Oils, papers, sugars and a selection of other issues advanced. Rubbers were notably weak.

The steel industry poured more ingots and steel for castings last month than in any previous December. This brought production for the fourth quarter of last year to a record and raised total 1956 output to 115,218,604 tons.

The Federal Reserve System continued to sell Government securities last week in line with reduced seasonal demands for credit. The system sold $40,700,000 of bills held outright and $209,700,000 of bills held under repurchase aereement.
Two new Army ferries were welcomed to New York's fleet of harbor craft yesterday with traditional whistle salutes and a water display by city fireboats.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 10 (AP)--Syria's Government declared today its "deep-rooted belief" that maintenance of peace and security in the Middle East was "solely the responsibility of the peoples of this area."
LONDON, Jan. 10--Sir Anthony Eden gave up his only home and major part of his income when he resigned as Prime Minister last night.
Commercial and industrial companies are paying back seasonal borrowings much more rapidly this year than last, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 10-- Israel will vacate a captured Egyptian base in northern Sinai next week but will balk at withdrawing from a former Egyptian stronghold dominating the Gulf of Aqaba.
LONDON, Jan. 10--Harold Macmillan, Britain's new Prime Minister, is a man of striking contrasts.

Myriads of pink and red roses decorated the grand ballroom of the Plaza last evening for the fourth annual Ball of the Roses. The event, a dinner dance and entertainment, was given by the volunteer...

Southerners' respect for law and order outweighs their hostility to racially mixed schools, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday. It released a second report on integration trouble spots made under its auspices.
Senator Ralph E. Flanders asserted yesterday that Western policy for the reunion and rearmament of Germany "has been either stupid or insincere."

FOR nearly half a century B.F. Dolbin has been a face-reader. Like a stargazer, he has contemplated an infinity of faces, discovering and recording in no less than thousands of drawings the meanings of the marks of time, of the idiosyncratic...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP)-- Representative Francis E. Walter served notice today that Congress would proceed "very, very carefully" on legislation to let Hungarian refugees remain in this country permanently.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 --Deborah Kerr is the first of five prospective stars signed by Hecht-Hill-Lancaster for the film version of the stage success "Separate Tables."
Columbia University announced yesterday the establishment of special faculty council to study the "new and awesome" problems of the atomic age.

OTTAWA, Jan, 10--The Royal Commission on Canada's econ omic prospects foresees a population of more than 26,000,000 in 1980 with a real income twothirds greater than the present. The population today is 16,000,000.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The normally sad face of Harold Macmillan brightened into a faint smile today as he reported to his Sovereign and become Prime Minister.
LONDON, Jan. 10--Queen Elizabeth II chose Harold Macmillan today as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

The city's seven major newspapers completed the year with a 4.4 per cent gain in linage in December over the same 1955 month. A breakdown, based on figures from Media Records, indicated that only one newspaper showed a loss. The gains ranged up to 8.2 per cent.
The market for Government securities scored its sharpest rally in three-and-a-half years yesterday.

Wake Forest, working for its points via definite patterns, defeated Seton Hall, 64--55, before 4,123 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Dayton routed St. Francis of Brooklyn, 84--60, in the curtain-raiser of the basketball double-header.

A letter purporting to have come from the so-called Mad Bomber has been received by The New York Journal-Ameri-, can. That newspaper made it public yesterday, saying its authenticity had been attested by competent authorities. Police officials refused comment.
A Columbia University dean said yesterday that the integrity and statecraft practiced by Alexander Hamilton could serve as guides for young nations today.
LONDON, Jan. 10--The Labor party intends to press vigorously for an early general election.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has notified two television advertisers that the Judy Garland show they had agreed to sponsor on Feb. 25 has been canceled.

The construction of a new three-berth pier to cost $7,350,000 in the Fulton Terminal section of the Brooklyn-Port Authority Piers will begin about April 1. This was announced yesterday by Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the bi-state agency.
The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League yesterday recalled Ron Murphy and Camille Henry from their Providence farm in the American League.

HAVING succeeded with the possible in "The Time of the Cuckoo," Arthur Laurents has now tried the impossible. He has tried to illustrate the analysis of a neurotic woman in "A Clearing in the Woods," which was acted at the Belasco last evening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Mrs. Mary Knowles, a librarian of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., was found guilty today of contempt of Congress.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (UP)--The National Collegiate Athletic Association today outlined a broad program to implement President Eisenhower's youth fitness plan...

Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley's plan for extending oneway traffic operation in midtown sections of Broadway, Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
The underside of a starfish or the back end of a trapdoor spider may not have obvious charms in nature's setting, but, adroitly caught in a camera lens, they star in a museum gallery show.
Armco Steel Corporation is offering to its stockholders rights to buy 1,088,179 shares of common stock at $56 a share in the ratio of one new share for each ten held of record of Jan. 9.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 (UP)-- Donnie Marshall's whirling back-hand shot with six seconds left lifted the Montreal Canadims to a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a contest that nearly produced a riot.

PARIS, Jan. 10--The impression among European experts on the Middle East is that the Eisenhower doctrine for that region brings the United States closer to the United Nations than to its North Atlantic treaty allies.

The New York Central Railroad yesterday presented its request for an average increase in Westchester County commutation fares of 33 per cent to make that service break even and also yield "at least" 6 percent on investments.

Sugar futures advanced sharply on heavy trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The world options (sugar destined for countries other than the United States) had one of the steepest increases in recent years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Administration officials said today they expected an invitation soon from President Eisenhower to Britain's new Prime Minister, Harold Macmillan,...
Legend and tradition have a tale about three men in a tub. Nursery rhymes also picked up the yarn, embellishing it with "rub-a-dub-dub."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Dean Acheson took a critical look today at the Administration's new Middle East proposal and pronounced it vague, meaningless, hackneyed and dangerous.
The Port of New York Authority's budget for 1957 covers the "possible expenditure" of $6,590,600 for improvements at La Guardia Airport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The action of Majority Leader Johnson in co-sponsoring, with Minority Leader Knowland, a proposal designed to permit an emphatic Senate majority to end debate on all "motions" to take up "measures,"...

The transatlantic liner Oslofjord tilted over 35 degrees in a Hoboken shipyard yesterday when a floating drydock gave way. Fifteen workers were injured--five of them seri ously enough to be hospitalized.

HOW deep can a hat crown be? New York milliners, now showing their spring collections, answer the question emphatically. Hat crowns are the deepest they have been since the Twenties and Thirties. There is little chance of March winds blowing off the latest in millinery.
The Port of New York Authority allotted $13,000,000 yesterday to start construction of the often-delayed $600,000,000 arterial highway relief program.

The Railway Express Agency on Tuesday will extend its new single carrier surface transportation service for export-import trade to Austria, Belgium, France, Japan, the Saar, weden and Switzerland.

Six acres of land at the intersection of Routes 1 and 18 in New Brunswick, N.J., have been sold by Samuel D. Hoffman and Martin Jelin to Leo Rosner, hotel operator, for improvement with a motor hotel containing 102...
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Walter E. Meyer, an attorney, and brother of Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of The Washington Post and TimesHerald, died here last night after...
WARSAW, Jan. 10--Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China is scheduled to arrive tomorrow from Moscow.
ANDOVER, N.B., Jan. 10 (AP) --A huge B-52 bomber crashed in New Brunswick hills today after an air explosion while the pilot was partially hooded to test his reflexes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 561,519 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 10 --Soviet and Hungarian troops occupied a number of Budapest factories today.

Now that Jacob K. Javits is in his United States Senate seat and Louis J. Lefkowitz is installed as his successor as State Attorney General, we should not forget the basic defects of state Constitution and state law that were recalled and emphasized by the prospective creation of a vacancy in office.

If the new Federal interstate highway system is not to be turned from a public blessing into a national curse, Congress must take action at this session--before the $33 billion road-building program approved last year becomes much further advanced...
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10--Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, has under consideration a three-stage plan for negotiating a definitive Suez settlement.
Stork Club waiters yesterday joined kitchen employes in a strike for union recognition. Replacements were hired, and the restaurant, at 3 East Fifty-third Street, continued to operate.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 --Warner Brothers will start construction next month on a $600,000, two-story building to meet the demand for studio space brought about by its television film activities.

Gross income of the Stanley Warner Corporation for the quarter ended Nov. 24 increased to $27,143,240 from $23,892,053 in the similar period of the previous year, S.H. Fabian, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.
Waterfront employers and longshore union leaders declared yesterday that there was some "elasticity" in their proposals and counter-proposals for a new dock labor contract.
PARIS, Jan. 10--The French Government's statement on Algeria received a mixed reception here today.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (UP)-- The Cleveland Boxing Commission today granted to the welterweight champion, Carmen Basilio, a five-week postponement of his title match with Johnny Saxton.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 10 --The worst outbreak of violence in the fight over bus segregation left Montgomery without public transportation today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Texas Democrats introduced a bill today authorizing the Government to rent land from farmers and ranchers in Southwestern states until the area recovered from drought.
Mr. President, Mr. Speaker and Members of the Congress of the United States:
The cost of operating the city's school system in 1957-58 has been estimated at more than $412,000,000, the highest in its history.
The Dodgers signed three more players yesterday. At the same time General Manager Buzzie Bavasi said he thought the Brooks could win this year's pennant.

James A. Michener, who returned from Austria a week ago, has turned over to Random House the manuscript of a new book to be called "The Bridge at Andau." It is an account of the Hungarian revolution and the people who lived it.
Harry Knox Smith, artist and designer in stained glass, died Wednesday in his home, 601 West 115th Street. His aged was 77.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 10 --The First National Bank of Birmingham has voted a stock dividend of one share for each nine shares held and transferred $1,000,000 from undivided profits to surplus, raising capital and surplus to $10,000,000.
Department store operators were urged yesterday not to stop selling merchandise on which profits were being shaved by cutprice operators.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) --Victor R. Hansen, Assistant Attorney General, said today that the Justice Department had begun an investigation of recent increases in crude oil prices.

A young railroad operator contributed $5 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

REMARKABLE is the tribute being paid to Art Larsen by his fellow tennis players. In a spontaneous gesture of high emotional content the racquet-wielders have rallied to the help of the stricken national champion of 1950 by staging a benefit show for him at the Seventh Regiment Armory tonight. Not only have these top-flight...
The state may for the first time gear its insurance programs for unemployed, sick and injured workers to changes in the cost of living.
Nelson Seitel, the city's Labor Commissioner since July 1, 1955, will quit his $20,000-a-year post on March 1.
BELHAVEN, N.C., Jan. 10-- The argument that game birds and animals have clocks in their heads and know the exact moment when hunting becomes illegal has always seemed like nonsense, even in...

A New York County grand jury recommended yesterday a re-examination of laws affecting the so-called "caution drugs," those that are sold only on prescription. The jury investigated a black market in Salk antipolio vaccine.
OTTAWA, Jan. 11--A nineday strike against the Canadian Pacific Railway was brought to an end today. The settlement was effected through the renewed intervention of Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent.
A project to centralize the handling of rubber imports in the port and to set up a special terminal on Staten Island has apparently collapsed.
The appointment of Mrs. Katharine Assante as the 1957 New York Polio Mother of the Year by the New York March of Dimes took place yesterday at her home at 656 West 178th Street.
Cotton futures moved 3 points higher to 1 point lower (15 cents up to 5 cents off) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11--Hungary protested to the United Nations today that "no committee of any kind" had a right to conduct an investigation into her affairs.
An international celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton, first Secretary of the Treasury, began here yesterday under bright but frosty skies.

LONDON, Jan. 11--Harold Macmillan believes that the reestablishment of Britain as a strong, solvent and self-confident partner of the United States must be the first objective of his new Conservative government.

FT. BRAGG, N.C., Jan. 11 (AP)--More than 1,200 battleready paratroopers leaped from C-119 Flying Boxcars onto Drop Zone Normandy here today in the first field test of the Army's streamlined new "pentomic" division. "Pentomic" is derived from the five groups that comprise the division and from atomic.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11--The General Assembly today repeated the United Nations insistence that Korea should be unified through free elections in the north as well as in the south of that country.

WARSAW, Jan. 11--Reports have reached Poland that Nikita S. Khrushchev barely survived a challenge to his leadership of the Soviet Communist party in the Central Committee meeting in Moscow last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, urged today a Congressional investigation of the newsprint industry, saying that "skyrocketing prices" are "working a hardship on the American press and other users of newsprint."
ATLANTA, Jan. 11--A Southern Negro conference called on President Eisenhower today to 'come immediately" to a Southern city and speak words of "wise counsel" on civil rights disorders.
It is with satisfaction that one begins to feed the birds for another winter. It always makes...

CHICAGO, Jan. 11--Unless thousands of home furnishings manufacturers can be wrong, the American public will rest easy in their present decor. Nothing very different in furniture design is being polished up for sale in 1957.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 1 (AP)--An auditing concern reported today it had been unable to trace $588,000 removed from the "brown envelope" bank fund of Orville E. Hodge, imprisoned former state auditor.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 11--Two gasoline bombs were shattered against a bus near here tonight. None of the seven passengers was injured, and only slight damage was done to the vehicle.
Natalie Ryshna, who made her New York piano debut five years ago, returned for her third Town Hall recital last night.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 11--Without a formal declaration, Yugoslavia appears to be changing her attitude toward the Kadar Government in Hungary.

A good-sized audience went to Carnegie Hall last night to hear the violin recital of Ruggiero Ricci. Of that audience, a sizable percentage consisted of small fry, mostly young males ranging from 30 to 13 years old, presumably budding violinists.
CAIRO, Jan. 11--Yemen called a meeting today of the joint command of the Egyptian, Saudi Arabian and Yemeni Armies to discuss the British military action in southern Arabia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Leonard W. Hall of New York resigned today as Republican National Chairman, effective Feb. 1.
MEDAN, North Sumatra, Jan. 10--Lieut. Col. Djamin Gintings, North Sumatran military commander, expressed the conviction today the "Simbolon affair" would not end in bloodshed.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. --"The Day Christ Died" w be produced by Darryl Zanuck as one of his independent pictures for 'Twentieth Century-Fox.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11--Premier Janos Kadar of Hungary conferred yesterday with Soviet leaders and Premier Chou in Moscow, the Soviet news agency reported tonight.
The successful treatment of alcoholics through the use of group psychotherapy was reported here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11--World industrial production increased by 6 per cent in the first nine months of 1956, compared with the corresponding period of 1955, according to United Nations data.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 11 (AP)--The National Association for Advancement of Colored People denied today giving any financial assistance to Autherine Lucy in her fight to become the first Negro at the University of Alabama.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) --The American Automobile Association said today there should be a decrease in gasoline prices rather than an increase.

The one-story taxpayer building containing three stores at 49-11-17-19 Thirtieth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, has been sold 'by Aaron Blum, realty operator, to the Hann Realty Corporation for investment. Helmsley-Spear, erty is assessed at $80,000, of Inc., was the broker.
CAIRO, Jan. 11--Egypt's semi-official Middle East News Agency charged today that the Israelis had murdered more than 8,000 Arab youths in the Gaza Strip in a campaign of "annihilation."
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 11--A Federal District judge ruled unconstitutional today the Virginia plan to retain segregation in schools.
Last night's Imperial Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria lived up to the Webster definition of imperial. By its honor guest, decor and entertainment, it was "befitting an emperor."

STATION WOR-TV last night carried an hour's play of the world championship bridge tournament at the Biltmore Hotel. The visual technique of showing the hands was not too satisfactory, but there was still ample interest for the kibitzer.
The United States Coast Guard's training barque Eagle will arrive here today from New London for an extensive overhaul preparatory to taking her annual June cadet cruise.
Louis J. Lefkowitz, the state's new Attorney General, said yesterday that he was not aware of any rift among Republican leaders over his selection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Employment in December continued at record levels for the month, although the total was lower than November's.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11--Failure of any heavy precipitation to materialize in the Southwest and West, and intimations of export business, gave wheat a stronger tone today. The forecast for the week-end carried no prospect for moisture where needed most.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP)--Pancho Contreras of Mexico defeated last year's winner, Eddie Moylan, in the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today to score a major upset.

PARIS, Jan. 11--The Eisenhower plan to seal off the Middle East from Soviet aggression or infiltration,is an interesting combination of old-fashioned power diplomacy and Wilsonian reliance upon the force of moral suasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)-- The results of a preliminary House investigation of stock transactions by Federal Circuit Judge Stanley N. Barnes have been turned over to the Attorney General "for appropriate action."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The Treasury announced tonight it had sold its special issue of 159day tax anticipation bills at an average rate that produced an interest cost of 3.305 per cent.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 11 (AP) --Mickey Wright, 21-year-old Sin Diego (Calif.) professional, ignored uncomfortable weather today to take a three-stroke lead in the opening round of the 54hole Sea Island women's invitation golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--Dr. Leopold E. Wexberg, psychiatrist and early figure in the field of rehabilitating alcoholics, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 67.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 11 --The people of Thailand believe that man-made law is valid only if it conforms to natural moral law, Prince Wan Waitkayakon of Thailand, president of the General Assembly of the United Nations, said here today. He accepted an honorary doctorate of laws from Fairleigh Dickinson University.
World sugar futures continued to soar to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was heavy and prices closed at the highs of the day.
New York University will oppose Muhlenberg and Manhattan will face Navy in a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The program will get under way at 7:30 o'clock.

BOGOTA, Cobmbia, Jan. 11-- A plan for paying Colombia's commercial debt to United States exporters was announced last night by Finance Minister Luis Morales Gomez. The program includes the long-term payment of 40 per cent of the debt. This 40 per cent is described by economists and bankers here as "in effect a loan by private United States banks to the Colombian Government."

Britain and the Malayan Federation have taken another important step forward in their productive cooperation and mutual interest. The federation will become independent this year, and remain within the Commonwealth. Steady political progress has been made toward this end.
American tourists are among the world's most welcome exports. They spent more than $1,500,000,000 in 1955, and the indications are that they topped that figure in 1956.
A New York concern disclosed yesterday that it had opened an office in Warsaw for trade with the remnant of private enterprise that has survived in Communist Poland.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11-- James D. Winsor Jr., an investment banker here, died today at his home in suburban Ardmore. He was 80 years old.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11-- Interracial brotherhood will be practiced as well as preached here.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11 (AP)--The fifty-first National Collegiate Athletic Association convention got into a tangle over parliamentary procedure today but emerged with two new laws concerning recruiting and aid to athletes. The action put the organization deeper into the enforcement business.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan, 11-- French authorities here have lined up a strong team to help present the French point of view on the Algerian issue in the United Nations General Assembly.

The impending withdrawal of Israeli forces from El Arish on the Mediterranean coast will be one more step in giving up, under U.N. pressure, territory that Israel occupied during her invasion of Egypt last fall. However, there is reason...
"The Ballad of Baby Doe," a musical drama scheduled to open on Broadway next fall, will be presented in an hour-long version by "Omnibus" next month on American Broadcasting Comnany television.
DETROIT, Jan. 11--An official of the United Automobile Workers outlined today some of the basic thinking of the union's leadership regarding 1958 negotiations with the motor industry.

If one of these days a prospective student shows up at Bard College wearing nothing more than a few fig leaves, it may cause considerable consternation on the campus but the reason will be somewhat understandable.

Federal mediators yesterday moved into the contract dispute involving this port's 3,500 tugboat and oil craft workers. The mediators issued a call for both sides to meet again Tuesday morning.

America's largest body of yachtsmen and pleasure boat skippers, the United States Power Squadrons, with more than 31,000 members in 218 unit squadrons, is slated to re-elect a New Yorker as chief commander at this afternoon's ceremony and annual election at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel.
Some 2,500 tennis enthusiasts responded to the Art Larsen benefit tennis program at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night.

The Temporary Commission on the Courts yesterday recommended nine changes in the new Youth Court Law to meet widespread criticism. Among other things the amendments partly, open Youth Courts to the press and postpone the deadline to put them into effect from Feb. 1 to next Jan. 1.
Columbia's whirlwind attack leveled Harvard's previously adamant defense in an Ivy League basketball contest at University Hall on the Columbia campus last night.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (UP)-- Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, today lectured club owners who criticize referees. His action followed a near riot over the officiating of Frank Udvari at the Forum last night.
BOTH popular and advanced taste will be gratified by a number of this week's exhibitions of painting and sculpture.

The death of a 67-year-old widower brought the special police squad assigned to track down the so-called Mad Bomber into action yesterday. In the dead man's home at 3514 Rochambeau Avenue, the Bronx, were found old Consolidated Edison bills and some notes said to have been written in block printing.

Stocks ended the week definitely on the minus side yesterday. Sugars and some oils held out against the downward movement led by the chemicals, motors and rubbers.

Jackie Robinson informed Charles (Chub) Feeney, the New York Giants' vice president, by phone last night that he definitely had decided to retire from baseball.

Goodman of New York City would make bread more often, she wrote, if the procedure of kneading and raising the dough twice did not take so many hours. Could she, as our grandmothers used to do let the dough rise overnight, then continue with the baking the next day?

THE nineteenth Ceramic National Exhibition, now on view at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West Fifty-third Street, is the only exhibition of its kind in the world. It comprises examples of pottery sculpture in many
CLEVELAND, Jan, 14 (AP)-- Five records were chalked up by the Great Lakes fleet in 1956, the Lake Carriers Association announced today.
WARSAW, Jan. 14--Wladyslaw Gomulka told Poland tonight that Sunday's elections would have the effect of a plebiscite on his leadership of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party.
Four major Jewish organizations submitted a document to the United Nations yesterday charging the Egyptian Government with violation of the "rights, status and very existence" of Jew's in Egypt.

Commissioner Francis T. Mylott disallowed yesterday more than half of the searching questions aimed at the Consolidated Edison Company by an important minority group facing utility increases amounting to $9,600,000.
A new twist has developed in the non-stop battle between Fairbanks, Morse Co. and Penn-Texas Corporation.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)--Twenty of the top players in the National Basketball Association tuned up today for tomorrow night's seventh annual EastWest All-Star game in the Boston Garden.

The perils of deducing national political trends from election results in one district are well known. Yet it is difficult to believe that the result of Sunday's French National Assembly election in one Paris district is without signifi

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 14-- After two years of discussion the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to take an option to buy for $136,000 the old home near Bedford Village of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States.
Garnett (Sugar) Hart of Philadelphia knocked out Gene Johns of Harlem in the star bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 14-- This city's crash economy drive saw school officials pledge today to campaign against abuses and to achieve a 10 per cent cut in present expenses without paring the essentials of teaching.
VIENNA, Jan. 14--Reports of isolated demonstrations in the western sections of Bulgaria continued to reach Vienna today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 14-- Negotiations aimed at easing Britain's foreign exchange and financial difficulties with an infusion of Deutsche marks began here today.
WARSAW, Jan. 14--Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China has given assurances of continued support for efforts to evolve a more democratic form of communism in Poland.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 (UP)--Pancho Gonzales turned his torrid serves on Ken Rosewall today and ruined the little Australian's professional tennis debut. Gonzales won, 6--3, 3--6, 6--3, 1--6, 9--7.
Perhaps investors felt there was a paucity of new preferred stock offered during 1956. Now comes some statistical proof that their reactions were justified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The trial of Robert Shelton, a newspaper man, on a charge of contempt of the Senate opened today. The defense contended that the defendant had been called before the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee by mistake.

The Household Finance Corporation's $30,000,000 issue of 4 5/8 per cent, twenty-year debentures goes on the market today through an underwriting syndicate jointly managed by Lee Higginson Corp., White, Weld Co. and William Blair Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14-- The Philco Corporation today filed a $150,000,000 suit in Federal District Court here against "monopolies" in electronics.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 14--President Eisenhower took a hard day-long look today at what searing sun and little or no rain have done to farms and ranches over a large section of the SouthWest.

Dedicated to a "Salute to Liberty," the sixth annual April in Paris Ball for the benefit of the French Hospital in New York will commemorate the 200th anniversary of the birth of the Marquis de Layfayette.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14-- United States officials indicated today that future United States relations with Egypt in the economic field depended in large part on Egypt's cooperation in solving Middle East political problems.
WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 14-- Recommendations drenched the Government's drought conference today.

One of the great problems shared by the dwellers of urbia and suburbia is that of privacy.
McMURDO SOUND, Antartica, Jan. 14--A Navy Seabee was pulled to his death today when the weasel in which he was riding broke through the bay ice off this United States base.
A Long Island City boy has $917.50 in the bank and the offer of a free artificial leg because six young shoeshine boys went to work for him. He lost most of his left leg to cancer last May.
PARIS, Jan. 14--Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France joined his political adversaries today in opposing United Nations interference in France's troubles in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--A bill was introduced today on President Eisenhower's detailed proposals for a commission to study all phases of credit and finance. The aim is to fulfill "the needs of a stable and growing economy."
A single salary schedule for all principals in the city's public school system was urged yesterday by the New York Principals Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14-- Paul C. Smith, president of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, unfolded a story of financial frustration today before a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing examiner.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation has agreed provisionally to manufacture the Frye Safari, a "promising replacement" for the DC-3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) --President Eisenhower asked the Senate today to approve the promotion of Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker, a key figure in the 1954 Army-McCarthy hearings, to the rank of major general.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14--Following are excerpts from a report on conditions in the Gaza Strip, presented to the General Assembly today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold:
Budgets aggregating $10,299,237 for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 were sought by eight city departments yesterday at hearings before Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
India is building a bridge that may never be used, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit said here yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 14--Fifteen changes in the state's criminal law were urged on Governor Harriman and legislative leaders of the two major parties today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)-- Twelve natural gas producers were denied today a Supreme Court review of protests they made against Federal Power Commission plans to regulate them.

The threat of a proxy fight between the management of Loew's, Inc., and a dissident group of stockholders diminished yesterday with the final selection of a slate of thirteen direc tors to be submitted for election at the annual meeting of stockholders on Feb. 28.
The Lincoln Square Chamber of Commerce yesterday distributed 400 posters in the area reaffirming its intention of continuing a legal fight against the $185,754,000 redevelopment.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 14--The guiding geniuses of the Stuart sailfish light tackle tournament, which ended in a blaze of glory Saturday, were spending much of today gloating over their handiwork. They had nearly as much reason to exult as they thought they had.
A new citizenship center and an undergraduate residence hall will be constructed on Columbia's Morningside Heights campus.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14-- C. William O'Neill, three-term attorney general, became Governor of Ohio today, the first full-term Republican Governor in eight years.
A plan was reported yesterday to enable physicians to collect their fees twice for performing the same service in cases where low-income families have two health insurance policies in effect.
A prominent psychiatrist yesterday urged the establishment of an American-Israel exchange program in psychiatry designed to benefit the entire Middle East.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14--The United States presented to the United Nations today a new five-point proposal for world disarmament. It included international control of intercontinental missiles and of experiments for warfare in new regions of space.

The temporary commission to study revision of the State Constitution has begun its work, which consists in part of reporting on proposals for changes in and simplification of the Constitution. In our opinion, and we are confident that many if not all of the members of

The long-term lease on the King Edward Hotel at 120-26 West Forty-fourth Street has been purchased by King Edward Affiliates, Inc., from King Edward Hotel, Inc. Menken-Schwebel Associates were the brokers in the transaction.
Prime Minister Macmillan has taken office with what amounts to an almost defiant demonstration that, in the face of criticism at home and abroad, he proposes to keep the British flag flying high.

Pearl S. Buck has written her second television play, which is titled "The Enemy." It will be presented by the Robert Montgomery program on March 4 from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.

All speculation as to Jackie Robinson's career in baseball ended yesterday when he requested that he be placed on the voluntary retired list. Robinson made his request in a letter to Horace C. Stoneham, the president of the New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 14-- Mrs. Robert Tripp Ross, wife of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for public information, has promised "full cooperation" to a Senate subcommittee investigating the award of an Army contract to a concern she heads.
DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP)--The nation's auto makers have built 239,355 cars so far in 1957, compared with 277,154 in the first two weeks of 1956.
VIENNA, Jan. 14--Austria protested to the West today that prolonged delays in the evacuation of Hungarian refugees were threatening to overtax her facilities.
Crosscurrents ripped at stock prices yesterday and the market closed with its widest losses of the new year.
Both sides in the waterfront contract dispute held lengthy caucuses yesterday, but there was no joint meeting.

THE world premiere of a new cantata, "Seven Prayers," by Ludwig Greenbaum and an extraordinarily vital concert performance of Honegger's opera "Judith" were presented last night by the American Concert Choir and Orchestra.
LONDON, Jan. 14--Government securities rose sharply today. Elsewhere in the stock market price movements were irregular, but a majority of leading industrials went ahead.

BERLIN, Jan. 14--Ambassador James B. Conant, dropping his political position for a technical talk here tonight as a scientist, produced a strong argument for a West German link in the proposed European common market.
Performing artists of the New York City Opera Company yesterday appealed to the board of directors to continue the company as a separate entity rather than as an appendage of the Metropolitan Opera.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14--Humphrey Bogart died in his sleep early this morning in the bedroom of his Holmby Hills home. The 57-year-old movie actor, an Academy Award winner, had been suffering for
CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Wheat futures rose today to the highest levels since the final week in November.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 14--Yale University has increased undergraduate charges $200 a year, effective in September. The new fee will be $2,000 a year.

A majority of the Soviet Union's most eminent mathematicians and physicists have challenged the present political control of Soviet science.

THE lights went out. There were moments that approached panic. Then, led by the French singing the "Marseillaise," the prisoners of each country sang in the darkness their national anthems. When the lights came on again they knew that they were only partly free, since they had been liberated at Waldheim, a Nazi prison in the Russian sector and they had a long way, still, to go home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)-- A real estate committee reported today a swing away from Government-backed home loans in favor of noninsured mortgages with higher interest rates.

ALBANY, Jan. 14--Governor Harriman has given state legislators reason to hope for a pay increase. The legislators now are talking in terms of a rise of $1,500, bringing the salaries of the 150 Assemblymen and fiftyeight Senators to $9,000 a year.
TOKYO, Jan. 14 (AP)--American passenger liners, which have dominated Pacific shipping lanes since World War II, will be getting some tough competition from Japan in the next few years.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP) --The Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League today signed Tommy McDonald, the breakaway back who was an allAmerica choice at Oklahoma in 1955 and 1956.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14--Malik Feroz Khan Noon, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, said today that a small United Nations force should be sufficient to police Kashmir during a United Nations-sponsored plebiscite there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--H. Meade Alcorn Jr., State Republican Chairman of Connecticut, appeared today to be the choice of party leaders and the White House to succeed Leonard W. Hall as Chairman of the Republican National Committee.

EL BALLAH, Egypt, Jan. 14 --Israeli forces were blowing up Egyptian military installations in El Arish today as they prepared to abandon the Sinai Peninsula town to the United Nations Emergency Force.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14--C. Wayland Brooks, a former Republican Senator from Illinois, died here early today in Passavant Hospital. He was 59 years old. Mr. Brooks was admitted to the hospital last Tuesday after having suffered a heart ailment.

ALBANY, Jan. 14--Governor Harriman urged the Legislature tonight to throw a temporary roadblock in the path of the proposed combination of the First National City Bank of New York and the County Trust Company of White Plains.
WASHINGTON, Jan.14--President Eisenhower today nominated C. Douglas Dillon, now Ambassador to France, to be Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--After only a single day's serious questioning on President Eisenhower's new Middle Eastern policy, two facts are fairly clear: the

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14-- (UP)--Lou Little, retired Columbia University coach, made four suggestions to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee. which opened a three-day ses ion here today. Twenty-five coaches met in closed session.
PROVIDENCE, Jan. 14 (AP)-- Johnny Lee scored 25 points tonight in leading Yale's basketball team to an 84-53 victory over Brown in an Ivy League game.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 14--The Supreme Court agreed today to hear three cases involving the sale of allegedly obscene books and the mailing of obscene and indecent literature.
Newspaper publishers were described yesterday as being in "a strait jacket and at the mercy of the first mill which decides to raise the price" of newsprint.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14--The Israeli authorities have restored law and order in the Gaza Strip, a United Nations military officer said in a report today. He also gave the impression that Israel planned to occupy the area permanently.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 14-- If Mrs. W. Pepper Constable of Princeton, N.J., is asked what it takes to be a squash racquets champion, she'll answer without hesitation: "Love of the game and plenty of practice."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 --Superior Court Judge John J. Ford today took under advisement petitions by musicians of Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, for permanent injunctions against entertainment company contributions to the union's trust fund.
Comments by an actress during a television interview brought her bad news yesterday in the State Supreme Court.

TOKYO, Jan. 14--The preliminary surveying and construction work are under way on drydocks at Grand Bahama Island, off the Florida coast. The docks will handle the giant oil tankers that are being built by the National Bulk Carriers of New York at the Kure shipyards, in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement covering the proposed sale to the public om most of the Government-held shares of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)-- The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that veterans need not repay the United States the premiums it pays on their commercial life insurance after they ask that their policies be protected against lapse while serving in the armed forces.
The Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday signed Roy Campanella and Carl Erskine to 1957 contracts.

The next long-term financing by municipal housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will be limited to a sale of two bond issues totaling $28,615,000, Public Housing Commissioner Charles Slusser announced yesterday.
Sugar prices increased yesterday for the sixth consecutive trading day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume continued heavy.

JACKIE ROBINSON has invariably been quotable because he's usually as impetuous in conversation as he once was on the basepaths. As a result of his ill-considered pop-offs, he undoubtedly holds the major league record for the ballplayer making the most apologies. But at least he has the moral gumption to recognize each boo-boo when it hits print and his expressions of regret are genuine and sincere.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14-- John Foster Dulles declared today that in possible international Communist aggression in the Middle East lay "the most serious threat we have faced over the past ten years."
THANKS for the memories. Brooklyn Museum. That sen timental song keyed yesterday's sentimental venture by Robert Riley, director of the museum's Design Laboratory, into the fashions of the Thirties.
Advertising is being enlarged for two imports--White Heather Scotch and Old Bushmill's Irish Whisky--as a consequence of recent gains in sales.

THE juices of grapefruit and pineapple, one sometimes too acid, the other sweet, blend in a frozen concentrated beverage by the Dole Hawaiian Pineapple Company. New Yorkers are the first in the country to get a taste of this fruit juice, being introduced in stores here this week.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14--The Soviet Union renewed today its call for a meeting of the heads of five Governments to consider plans for world disarmament. The five are the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Orlando Delli Paoli of the Bronx for conspiracy to violate the Federal alcohol tax laws, Paoli had been sentenced by a Federal District Court to two years imprisonment.

EASTBORNE, England Jan. 14 (Reuters)--Dr. John Bodkin Adams, fashionable physician to the elderly rich in this coast resort, was accused in court today of having poisoned three of his patients for motives of greed.
DUBLIN, Jan. 14--Fifteen young men, including two from Northern Ireland, were sentenced here today to six months' imprisonment.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Jan. 14 (AP) --Jeff Dyer of Springfield, Mass. spotted Ewart Potgieter 11 inches in height and 120 pounds and pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision tonight. The bout was the South African giant's United States debut.

FRANCES WYATT stepped out of the chorus of "The Voice of Firestone" last night on Channel 7 and took over the program's starring assignment. She was a replacement for Patrice Munsel of the Metropolitan Opera, who has been ill with a sinus attack.
The temperature dropped to 5 degrees at 2 A.M. today, making it the coldest Jan. 15 on record. The previous low for the date was 6.3 degrees in 1927.

The Superior Oil Company of California, showed a sharp rise in its earnings for the three months ended Nov. 30 over the corresponding period a year ago, reflecting in part the increase in gross income.

President Eisenhower's current visit to the drought areas of the Southwest will serve a useful purpose only if it is followed up by strong action to remove once and for all the "dust bowl" threat from the many millions of acres of mismanaged lands of our country.

NEWARK, Jan. 14--The Public Utilities Commission today temporarily approved a revised schedule proposed by the New York Central Railroad for its West Shore line between Weehawken and West Norwood, N.J.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 --Gregory Peck has made a deal with Jerry Wald to star in the producer's Twentieth CenturyFox production of "Sound and the Fury." The William Faulkner novel has been put into screen-play form by Irving Ravitch and his wife, Harriett Frank Jr.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 14--Any hopes Premier Janos Kadar may have had of inducing leading figures of other Hungarian parties to join his Government seem likely to be disappointed.

The city's Department of Labor is trying to iron out the dispute between Actors Equity and Herman Levin, producer of "My Fair Lady," over the temporary replacement of Rex Harrison by Edward Mulhare, an Irish performer.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP)--An official of a United States con cern said today that the Suez crisis might bring lasting benefits in stabilizing the Middle East.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Jan. 14 (AP) --Hickory Smoke and eightyfive other 3-year-old trotters were eligible today for the $100,000 Hambletonian Stakes, to be raced for the first time at the Du Quoin State Fair Aug. 27.
The night game champions of the National League this year will be the St. Louis Cardinals --unless some other club can catch up with them by playing unscheduled floodlight contests.
