A major post-war ailment of the city's municipal hospital system--overcrowed conditions --may finally be eliminated this year through new construction and renovation of facilities.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company announced yesterday an increase in gasoline and heating oil prices ranging from to 1 cent a gallon throughout its marketing area.
MADRID, Jan. 14--Three policemen were injured and at least eight persons arrested today in violent demonstrations at Barcelona University.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 14-- Frederic Hewlett McCoun, formerly a lawyer in New York and from 1952 until last June Mayor of Quogue, died here today of a coronary thrombosis in Central Suffolk Hospital. Mr. McCoun, whose home was on
LONDON, Jan. 14--The British Labor party believes it can reinforce its demand for an early general election by registering important voting gains in seven forthcoming Parliamentary byelections.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14--The ideas behind President Eisenhower's proposals for the Middle East were welcomed today by the Canadian Government as evidence of the increased interest of the United States in that area.

AMES, Iowa, Jan. 14 (AP)--Don Medsker flipped in a twenty-foot push shot as the game ended to give Iowa State a 39-37 Big Seven Conference basketball upset over the nation's No. 1 team, Kansas, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14-- Prospects for an early appreciable reduction in excise taxes died today as a House Ways and Means subcommittee filed recommendations after months of study.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The practical and legal limits of the function, and the effectiveness, of the United Nations have lately been stressed by three different public figures for three different reasons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--Young men who join the National Guard or the Army Reserves will be required after April 1 to take at least six months' training on active duty. The Army, in announcing this and other revisions in reserve training today, said the changes were "based on military considerations."
Lindy Remigino the 100meter hero of the 1952 Olympic team, will be back in town Saturday.
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)--Terry Sawchuk, the star goal tender of the National Hockey League, today quit the Boston Bruins, dealing them a crushing blow in their bid for the championship.
The Ethiopian Government has received a $24,000,000 loan from this country's Export-Import Bank for development of its aviation facilities.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 15--Britain suggested today that the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee consider the prohibition or limitation of longrange submarines as a weapon of offense.
John George Niederer, long a metal craftsman specializing in bronze, died Saturday at his home in San Pedro, Calif., after a short illness. He was 101 years old.

WHAT happens when a rich, able and ambitious man marries a beautiful woman in love with her own childhood but not with her husband? This is the question Carl Jonas asks and answers in his new novel, "Our Revels Now Are Ended:" Like its predecessors, "Jefferson Selleck" and "Riley McCullough," this is another story...

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP) --The seemingly tranquil meeting of the powerful football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association erupted into action today and took strides to outlaw the grabbing of protective face masks.
WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 15-- President Eisenhower ended his tour of parched Great Plains states today with a pledge to seek $76,000,000 in Federal funds for emergency drought relief.

A 48-year-old scholarly former steelworker has become president of the country's biggest electronic business. John L. Burns, whose election to the presidency of the Radio Corporation of America was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, was once a laborer in a steel mill.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 15-- An agreement was signed this afternoon between Turkey and the United States to protect American investors here against loss through expropriation.

VIENNA, Jan. 15--John MacCormac, a New York Times correspondent, returned here today from a two-and-a-half-week visit to Budapest, after the Hungarian news agency M.T.I. had announced that he had been expelled from Hungary.

A ranking official of Youth Aliyah, an international agency devoted to the rescue and rehabilitation of Jewish children, expressed sharp concern yesterday over what he termed "virulent anti-Semitism" among Hungarian refugees in Austria.
If a Presidential candidate had the support that turned out last night for Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey, he would be well on his way to the nomination.

Very much off the beaten track is Gian-Carlo Menotti's "madrigal fable" called "The Unicorn, the Gorgon and the Manticore," which was produced by the Ballet Society and presented last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--A systematic campaign of antiSemitism against Egyptian Jews was alleged in a report issued today by B'nai B'rith.
Four brotherhoods of nonoperating employes threatened yesterday to strike against the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad next Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)-- Industrial output set a new high in December as prices of industrial commodities continued to advance, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A new child-adoption service, described by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy as "history making," has been started by the city.
David W. Frankel, a realty investor, has signed a contract to buy the seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building at 2 Beekman Place.
While the Yankees had nothing to report on the outstanding player of the year, Mickey Mantle, the Giants and the Dodgers yesterday continued to reveal contract signings.

In the old days, especially in rural communities, the general store supplied just about everything a customer could want. Now, translated into modern terms, the shopping center provides a wide variety of wares in an effort to attract the shopper to do all of his buying in one place. More than that, the center must look beyond..

THE collegians may have forgotten that the foot still has a proper place in football, but the professionals are too smart ever to overlok so marketable a commodity. It was a startling display of their merchandise that they gave in the Pro Bowl game at Los Angeles the other day.
LONDON, Jan. 15--Britain's insistence on excluding foodstuffs from the workings of the proposed European free trade area is meeting strong opposition from some Continental countries.

Snow began blanketing the metropolitan area early last night after a day in which the temperature had fallen to a record of 3.1 degrees in the city. Below-zero readings were reported in the suburbs. The Weather Bureau said the snow might reach a depth of three to five inches before it stopped today. A heavier fall was expected in northern New Jersey and eastern Long Island.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--The State Department announced today that the United States "welcomes" the proposed European common market and free trade zone.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. 15-- Hungary's Olympic champion water polo team routed the New York Athletic Club, 16--3, in the feature event of a benefit performance for the Free Hungary Fund at the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.

PARIS, Jan. 15--Shortly after Harold Macmillan was named Foreign Secretary in Eden's Cabinet he met Dulles during a Paris NATO conference. Dulles reported afterward: "We talked on a friendly and intimate basis. Somebody once said concerning the British and the Americans, 'With others we negotiate but among ourselves we talk as partners.'"

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 15 --President Sukarno is planning to form an advisory council that would give him broad powers to meet growing crises now facing Indonesia, Presidential sources reported today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP)--Most grain futures ended lower on the Board of Trade today after moving within a very narrow price range.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $299,884,485 for the twelve months ended Dec. 31. This compared with $273,155,604 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)-- Incidentai benefits of research aimed at harnessing the hydrogen-bomb reaction for industrial power may begin to accrue soon, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
Experiments shattering a fundamental concept of nuclear physics were reported yesterday by Columbia University.
Stockholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America, at a special meeting in Flemington, N.J., yesterday approved a twofor-one split of the common stock.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday 1 point up to 4 points down (5 cents a bale higher to 20 cents lower).
MOSCOW, Jan. 15--The Soviet leaders are seeking measures that would effectively counter--balance United States moves in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--The trial of Robert Shelton, a newspaper man, on a charge of contempt of the Senate ended today.

Jerry Marshall, master of ceremonies for WNEW's "Make Believe Ballroom" will leave the radio station at the end of this week. He said his future plans would be announced "as soon as they are formulated."
EL ARISH, Jan. 15--Israeli troops today gave up El Arish, the only large town in the Sinai Peninsula, and pulled back to within twelve miles of their own border.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Next Tuesday--Jan. 22--Rear Admiral George J. Dufek, commander of Task Force 43 in the Antarctic, will turn over to the American Antarctic Division of the International Geophysical Year the base at the South Pole the Navy has been building for the past month.
ALBANY, Jan. 15--Governor Harriman reported today that New York State had found homes for nearly one-third of the Hungarian refuges who had been resettled in this country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--About ten Soviet MIG-17 swept-wing jet aircraft have been delivered to Syria in the last few weeks.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (U.P.)--Young Don Candy of Sydney, a top prospect for Australia's Davis Cup team, faltered only briefly today in whipping Jerry Crowther of Miami in the opening round of the Coral Gables-University of Miami tennis championship.
ALBANY, Jan. 15--The setting of Feb. 14 as the date for special elections for three vacancies in the Senate has revived interest in legislation to revise the method of filling such vacancies.

GIAN-CARLO MENOTTI'S many and articulate ad mirers have been saying for some time--in the face of equally glib skeptics--that this Italian-born composer and librettist has brought American opera into the twentieth century by blending high musical and dramatic values.

The Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has lost no savings deposits so far because of a competitor's increase in the interest rate from 2 to 3 per cent, Harold D. Helm, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.

STATESVILLE, N.C., Jan. 15 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Neely Gilbert of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Pressly Gilbert, to Herbert Howard Browne Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Browne of Columbia, S.C. An early summer wedding is planned.

BOSTON, Jan. 15--The favored East, blanked for the first three and a half minutes and still trailing at half-time, finished strongly and routed the West, 109--97, in the National Basketball Association's seventh annual All-Star game at the Boston Garden tonight.

CAIRO, Jan. 14--Egyptian political circles expressed grave fears today that a new Middle Eastern crisis might explode soon over Israel's refusal to withdraw from the Gaza Strip and strategic Sinai bases guarding the Gulf of Aqaba.
LONDON, Jan. 15--The decline and death of an aged wealthy widow and the conduct of her physician were described in court today. The case already is regarded as one of Britain's classic murder trials.
PARIS, Jan. 15--Debate to clear the way for French entry into a Western European common market opened today in the National Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--John Foster Dulles asserted today that the alternative to President Eisenhower's Middle Eastern program would be "a very great likelihood" that United States troops would have to fight there.
LONDON, Jan. 15--President Eisenhower has warmly congratulated Harold Macmillan on his appointment as Prime Minister, wishing him "every success" in his new post.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP)--Sullivan County's Board of Supervisors, deadlocked over selection of a temporary chairman, adjourned early today after a fourteen-hour session.
CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 15-- Charles McDonald Puckette, general manager of The Chattanooga Times and vice president of the Times Printing Company, died today at his residence on Lookout Mountain.

He apparently died in his sleep. Associates said he had not been ill and had visited downtown Washington yesterday.

IN any era, John Mason Brown once said, Edith Hamilton would be exceptional; in ours, she is unique. On the threshold of her own tenth decade she has written a new book, "The Echo of Greece," a requiem of decline and fall and immortality that Gibbon would have expanded to ten volumes without saying more. The Greeks are still our teachers and Miss Hamilton is our most beguiling teacher about the Greeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Substantial progress has been made in the last few days toward working out a common Western policy for the highly inflammable situation around the Gulf of Aqaba and the Gaza Strip.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Administration put itself deeper into the farm business today despite an avowred desire to get out. It proposed a record budget for agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Jan.16-- The United States is beginning development of Afghanistan's civil airline and airports as one phase of economic aid intended to counter Soviet penetration.
A MEMORIAL program for Arturo Toscanini was pre sented on television last night by the National Broadcasting Company, with which he had been associated during the last years of his conducting career.

An insurgent group within the Independent Watchmen's Association, Local 1456, is preparing to challenge a Waterfront Commission regulation that requires a "rigorous" physical examination for all pier watchmen in this port.
The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., achieved the highest sales and second largest earnings in its thirty-six-year history in the year ended Nov. 30, Donald W. Douglas, president, reported yesterday.
BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 16 --Efforts are being made to extend the three-day-old boycott of public surface transport here to include places of amusement and of retail trade.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan., 16 (AP)--The Calumet Farm's Bardstown defeated fifteen other speedy thoroughbreds today to win the $68,500 Tropical Handicap, the closing feature at Tropical Park, before 12,081 racing fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- President Eisenhower based his budget today on expectations of continued national prosperity and further inflationary pressures.

The engagement has been announced here of Miss Elizabeth Higgins Zuill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Vail Zuill of Channelway, Smith's Parish, Bermuda, to Theodore Whaley, Cart. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Cart of Harbourton, N.J., and Southlands, Warwick, Bermuda.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 --Future uses of television by the armed services and industry were painted in bright colors today.
CAIRO, Jan. 16--The Government charged today that British and French banks had "been at war against us" and had discriminated against Egyptians in making loans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn has passed the word that Congress should quickly and decisively grant President Eisenhower's request for stand-by authority to use troops in the Mideast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)-- A retired rear admiral, once head of the Navy's guided-missiles program, said today reliable reports indicated that "there are objects coming into our atmosphere at very high speeds."

STUART, Fla. Jan. 16--The snook is a fish that may well have been invented by Bret Harte, one of whose characters boasted that his name had developed through the centuries from the aristocratic Seven Oaks to Se'noaks to Snook. This fish is eccentric.

Arturo Toscanini was like a flaming sun which shed a vivifying light on music. His death does not mean that this sun has sunk forever. It irradiates all the performances imprisoned on disks and tape, reminding us of the purity and consecration of his musical faith.

LIBERAL, Kan., Jan. 16 (AP)-- An explosion wrecked a compressor station at the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company station near here today, killing three men and hindering movement of gas to the Great Lakes area.
EASTBOURNE, England, Jan. 16--A mystery of changes in an aged widow's will was related today at the pre-trial hearing of the physician accused of murdering her six years ago with drugs.
The long-expected break in world sugar prices occurred yesterday in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices had risen sharply during the previous seven trading days.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 16-- Development of a large inland state park for swimming and other recreations is to be started this year in Westchester. It will be the first state park in the country.
The new quotas on Japanese textile exports to the United States elicited a mixed reaction among American textile men yesterday.
Like Alice of Wonderland and Looking Glass fame, the utility industry has to run fast to keep in the same place. Yesterday the outlook was for an even faster pace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Edward L. Elliott, New York broker, testified today that there were too many editors on the board of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company when he first found the concern in financial trouble.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mex., Jan. 17 (UP)--Harry Weetman, a British Ryder Cup professional, fired six consecutive birdies on the back nine after a slow start to post a 68 and tie three other players for the lead in the first round of the $15,000 Caliente open golf tournament today.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP)-- Fay Crocker took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the $5,000 Tampa women's open golf tournament today as Mickey Wright, the winner at Sea Island last week, drew a record penalty of 24 strokes.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--The Court of Appeals was reported deadlocked, 3 to 3, today over the appeal taken from a $50,000 libel verdict in favor of W. Kingsland Macy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17--The United States asked Dag Hammarskjold today to arrange for "deployment" of the United Nations Emergency Force along the Egyptian-Israeli armistice line and at the entrance to the Gulf of Aqaba.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17-- For the last couple of weeks, neither cold nor drizzle nor the icy, turned shoulder has kept the Indian politician from the pursuit of the ticket.

A cornerstone-laying ceremony for the $7,000,000 New York School of Printing was held yesterday within the great open spaces of the partly completed building as the temperature hovered around 17 degrees.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 17 --The Tennessee House of Representatives gave overwhelming approval today to Gov. Frank G. Clement's five bills empowering local school boards to pre serve racial segregation in public schools.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP)--The medical director of a large industrial concern blamed the "suicidal cult of manliness" for the "rat race" in which many American men find themselves today.
DR. ALBERT SCHWEITZER, scholar, theologian, organ ist and healer, entered his eighty-third year this week, still toiling for sick and unhappy human beings at Lambarene in French Equatorial Africa.

The much-talked-about steel shortage actually is confined to such items as heavy plates, structural shapes and some types of pipe, all used in capital goods expansion programs, executives of the American Steel Warehouse Association reported yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP)--Col. Harold Fowler, a prominent figure in aviation through both World Wars and a former First Deputy Police Commissioner in New York, died today. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Senate Investigations subcommittee challenged the leadership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today to state whether it was encouraging witnesses "to hide and conceal facts" about labor racketeering.
Snow, ice and below-zero weather have a wonderfully stimulating effect on boat shows. They make winter-bound folks hanker for the summer ahead and for vacation days afloat.
The price of world sugar (destined for countries other than the United States) continued to fluctuate sharply yesterday with volume heavy on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) --Representative Abraham J. Multer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that Americans who had invested in United States Savings Bonds were "being gypped by their own Government."

Sal Maglie yesterday became the twenty-third Dodger to agree to terms for 1957, and his salary probably will make him the highest-paid 40-year-old pitcher in major league history.

The cold spell remained a major topic of conversation yesterday, and the Weather Bureau contribution was a prediction that the temperature would not go above freezing before Monday.

Two asserted burglars resorted to sharply varying methods of operation yesterday. One thief walked up and down seventeen flights of stairs and escaped. Another burglary suspect tried to flee an elevator and was apprehended.

The snowfall in New York and other areas of the country this week brought a warm glow to a few people--makers of snow removal equipment. Their sales, of course, depend directly on inclement weather.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) off to 3 points up yesterday. The market opened quiet, and held within a six-point range all day. There was some trade buying in March early, offset by local and southern selling.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Butcher hogs hit a new high today for the last eighteen months. Prices were steady to 25 cents up. The peak was $19.10, paid for eighty head. This was the highest price since July 14, 1955, when $19.60 was paid.
FOR a desolate man, Jean Anouilh knows how to write a remarkably gay comedy. For a classical actor, Ralph Richardson knows better than most how to act with the gusto of a low comedian.

Edwin H. Denby of 4 Gramercy Park West, a noted New York architect for more than half a century, died yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Nursing Home. His age was 84. His office was at 333 Fourth Avenue.

Stocks opened firm yesterday, dipped to the lowest level since Dec. 4 and then staged a partial recovery, helped by favorable news. The net result was a slight decline for the day, with the rails relatively far weaker than the industrials.

Wagner's "Siegfried" will have its first Metropolitan Opera performance since the 1950-51 season Wednesday evening, Jan. 30. It will be a highlight of the fourteenth week of opera at the Metropolitan.

Both finally leave unanswered questions of the immortal hand and eye that framed his magic symmetries.
Don Bessent, Ed Roebuck and Don Elston, all right-handed relief pitchers, signed their 1957 contracts with the Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday. There are now twenty-six Dodgers in the fold.

Jan. 21 --A chance remark by Otto Preminger, director-producer, to Herschel Burke Gilbert, composer and conductor, has resulted in the latter going into independent movie production. ALBANY, Jan. 21--A bill to increase state aid for education in several school districts in Nassau and Westchester Counties was introduced in the Legislature tonight. Its sponsor was Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Republican of Scarsdale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21--Richard M. Nixon was sworn today for his second term as perhaps the most powerful Vice President in the country's history. CHICAGO, Jan. 21--Owners of slum properties were pictured today as reaping unwarranted profits from urban renewal programs sponsored by the Government.

PARIS, Jan. 21--Oil deposits in the Sahara region of Africa could fill all of France's needs in fifteen years, according to Pierre Guillaumat, head of the Government's Petroleum Research Bureau.

The leader of the Republican majority in the New York State Senate said yesterday that New York must evolve a banking structure to permit growth without favoring any bank, class of banks or bank holding company.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics advanced to 91.6 on Wednesday from 91.3 on Tuesday. The figure for Jan. 25, 1956, was 89.1.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) --An early morning fire destroyed a lumber yard and eight oil tank trucks in the community of Limestreet near here today. An insurance agent said the loss would exceed $100,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 --Led by the company's new chief official, Joseph R. Vogel, a contingent of Metro-GoldwynMayer executives late yesterday rode some eighty miles up the California coast from the Culver City studio to a sneak preview of a movie.
MONACO, Jan. 24 (UP)--Princess Grace of Monaco nursed her infant daughter today and the father, Prince Ranier, took bows on the palace balcony.
HAVANA, Friday, Jan. 25 (UP)--Two Air Force B-47 Stratojets collided over a small Caribbean island last night and the six men aboard the planes were reported "missing," the Air Force reported.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 24--State Senator Walter H. Jones denied today that he wished to replace United States Senator H. Alexander Smith. He pledged to support Senator Smith should he seek re-election next year.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (UP)-- Danny Kravitz and Dick Rand, both catchers, returned signed contracts to the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 24-- French military sources here estimate that about 2,000 weapons a month are involved in the arms traffic from Tunisia and Morocco into Algeria.

William A. Bonner was elected president of the Board of Underwriters of New York yesterday at the organization's annual meeting. He succeeds Frank B. Zeller. The trade organization is composed of insurance companies writing ocean marine insurance in the American market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading. Cocoa, rubber, hides and copper rose; wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and tin declined, and price movements for sugar, coffee and potatoes were mixed.

The Shell Oil Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries last year had a net income approximating $135,800,000, or $4.49 a share, H.S.M. Burns, president, estimated yesterday.

ROME, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP)-- The wreckage of an Air Force tanker plane in which seven men died was spotted today in the Adirondack wilderness. Heavy snow, rugged terrain and darkness halted efforts of ground parties to reach the scene.
TOKYO, Jan. 24--The population of the city of Tokyo is now 8,294,544, the metropolitan government announced today. After New York and London. Tokyo is considered to be the world's third largest city.

Shareholders of Franklin National Bank, Franklin Square, L.I., have approved payment of a 2 per cent stock dividend on Feb. 22 to holders of record of Jan. 15. The dividend of 62,500 shares will be payable at the rate of one new share for each forty held.

Richard S. Perry, a vice president of William Iselin Co., Inc., factors, has been elected a director, Morton Goodspeed, president, announced yesterday. John L. Cole was promoted from assistant vice president to vice president.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)--Ichio Ogimura and Tomi Okawa of Japan headed the men's and women's lists, respectively, today in the world table tennis rankings. The United States was unlisted in the top ten.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP)--An American women's squash racquets team arrived in London by air today to play Britain on Feb. 27 for the Wolfe-Noel Cup. Britain holds the trophy.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 27 (UP) --Al Watrous of Birmingham, Mich., and Robert Stupple of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, tied for first place today in the Professional Golfers Association seniors championship with fifty-fourhole totals of 210.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 (AP) --Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina drove a Maserati 2,500 with daring skill in a blistering sun today to win the City of Buenos Aires Grand Prix automobile race.
Siobhan McKenna, who recently appeared here as "Saint Joan," will give her interpretation of "Hamlet" at the Theatre de Lys tonight at 7:30 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27-- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that everyone in the country from the Administration on down should try to economize to avoid a depression.

After playing tricks on a sports-minded public with a before-daybreak snowfall that made road travel sloshy for some hours, the weather man produced an afternoon of warm sunshine--almost yachting weather.

The American Jewish Committee charged yesterday, that "thousands of copies" of a Hungarian language newspaper, published here in what they described as "a flagrantly proNazi spirit," had been distributed among Hungarian refugees at Camp Kilmer.
Mrs. Winifred Ives Clarke former Overseer of the Poor of Oyster Bay, L.I., died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Federal Reserve Board officials here have been stressing that the recent dramatic easing in the statistical position of the money market has been caused by technical factors and not by a change in Federal Reserve policy.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 27 (UP)--Ann Quast of Marysville, Wash., staged a brilliant rally today to capture the Doherty women's amateur golf tourney. She defeated the defender, Joanne Goodwin of Dartmouth, Mass., on the thirtyeighth hole.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 27--An early-morning fire in this upstate racing town today caused the death of a policeman and leveled a block of business establishments on the main street.
VIENNA, Jan. 27--Word has been received from Budapest that more than 100 Soviet experts have been sent to the Hungarian uranium mines near Pecs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--John Foster Dulles went through four gruelling days of public questioning last week on the President's Middle East program without losing his temper.
Cotton prices in the domestic market showed small changes early last week and moved into higher ground on Thursday and Friday.
The Helura Trio made its New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
LONDON, Jan. 27--Britain's tall, square-jawed Defense Minister, Duncan Sandys, is not a man who carries his hat in his hand, even on a mission to repair the United StatesBritish alliance.
"The Doctor in Spite of Himself," Moliere's seventeenth-century farce mocking the medical profession, has been adapted into a musical comedy for Broadway production next fall.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27-- Relations between Lebanon and Syria are badly strained as a result of a long series of Syrian measures that the Lebanese feel are intended to make life difficult for them.
The possible impact of the current City Council investigations upon the mayoralty election in November is causing serious concern to Mayor Wagner and other Democratic leaders.

The eighteen-story (and penthouse) apartment building for 130 families at 2 Sutton Place South, southwest corner of East Fifty-seventh Street, has been sold by Uris Brothers to Henry Payson Associates.
PARIS, Jan. 27--Pierre Poujade, leader of an extreme Right-Wing tax-strike movement, finished a poor fourth today in his first bid for a seat in the National Assembly.

A homely, old-fashioned upcountry saying comes to mind as we read the drought news from the Southwest and some accompanying dispatches from Washington. Something has to be done for the land's sake without too much delay.

ATHENS, Jan. 27--The dissolution of great empires, even when gradual, has always been an agonizing process. This was true in the instances of Rome, Spain and Ottoman Turkey. It is true again today in the instances of Britain and of France.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27--The only major steel item that will be easy to obtain in the next few months is cold rolled sheet, according to sources here. Most other products range from "hardto-get" to "relatively easy."

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27-- The Florida fashion industry has carved out a place for itself in the nation's apparel trades. Its importance was pointed up by the interest and the business done in the first of three market weeks sponsored by the Miami-Florida Fashion Council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27-- George E. Durno, foreign news editor of the Washington bureau of International News Service, died here today after a brief illness. He was 54 years old.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 27--Four amateur frogmen tested the impact of winter upon their skills and equipment in the snow-fringed waters of Long Island Sound today. They were members of the Westchester Tritons, a group of eighteen skin divers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Secretary of State Dulles has won the votes of the Congress for his Middle East policy, but he has not won what is more important to the conduct of his
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 27 --Observers in Tunisia believe the ground is being prepared there for contacts between leaders of the Algerian independence movement and French officials.
The two leading Democratic spokesmen on state power swung to the support yesterday of the bill for state development of Niagara River power.
An Anglican priest from South Africa told a congregation here yesterday that the South African racial situation was growing more serious rather than improving.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 27--Sixty thousand Negroes are walking to work in South Africa, ostensibly to save a shilling (14 cents) a week in bus fares.
THE two fellows who are running neckand-neck for intercollegiate scoring hon ors in basketball are Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain of Kansas and Chet (The Jet) Forte of Columbia.
Governor Harriman's proposal for easing rent control over some landlords brought him into conflict yesterday with some of his own political supporters.

BERT LAHR and S.J. Perelman teamed up on "Om nibus" last night for a backward glance at the old school of burlesque, not the G-string variation. Their reprise was both nostalgic and hilarious (Channel 7).

Among the many fetishes which Communists cherish, the concept of "unity" holds a special and honored place. In the free world we are accustomed to the notion that a political party may embrace a wide spectrum of views on a given issue.
The twelve members of they Sontag String Sinfonietta play with the well-matched tones, the sensibility of nuance and the cohesive feeling of a string quartet.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 27--Israel gave emphasis today to her refusal to withdraw from the Gaza Strip by proceeding with plans to develop the territory seized from Egypt.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, who retired last November as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, had very definite ideas as to the nature of that office and the responsibilities that it imposed upon him.
WARSAW, Jan. 27--A new attack on Wladyslaw Gomulka has been launched by what is called the right wing of the Polish Communist party. M. Gomulka is the party's first secretary.
THE American Revolution, numerous novelists and historians have observed in recent years, was not only the revolt of a colonial people; it was also to a large extent a civil war.
ALBANY, Jan. 27--Governor Harriman's budget for the next fiscal year is to be submitted to the Legislature this week.
AMONG the odd food establishments in the city of od dities is what might be called a "custom cannery" at 170 East Ninety-second Street.

FROM the moment that word got out that the time mech anism in bombs left around the city by the "Mad Bomber" came from cheap watches, the most harassed man in town was an itinerant watch-repair man, a meek and simple fellow.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan.27--The Netherlands' foreign trade last year developed unfavorably.
PARIS, Jan. 27--The Government soon will pigeon hole 250,000,000,000 francs ($714,000,000) of the 1957 budget in conformance with a parlimentary decision.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 28-- Three misleading signals from the Admiralty in London caused one of the worst Allied disasters at sea, according to the official naval history, "The War at Sea, 1939-45," published today.

EL CENTRO, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)--Tony Lema of Elko, Nev., fired a 6-under-par 65 to tie Paul Harney, then shot a pair of birdies to win the extra hole play-off in the Imperial Valley open golf tournament today.

In the chill, pre-dawn darkness yesterday an unassuming physician boarded a plane for Haiti with his wife and a crippled Haitian child. They carried a guitar, a microscope and an artificial leg for use in the hospital they had just opened in Haiti.
VIENNA, Jan. 27 (AP)--Mrs. Georgette Meyer Chapelle came out of Hungary today after more than seven weeks in Communist jails and said, "Thank God I am an American!"

Sid Miles, the head of the physical education department at Wellsville (N.Y.) High School, was reminiscing during a Cornell football game at Ithaca. Togged out in a football official's uniform, he was relaxing between the halves.
A WOMAN'S life cannot be all peaches and cream unless her complexion is.
MADRID, Jan. 25--Spain started the New Year with an increasingly serious economic situation on her hands.
LONDON, Jan. 27--Stock market prices and the pound sterling both gave evidence last week of renewed confidence in Birtain's economy.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 (UP)--Norm Ullman and Dutch Reibel scored first-period goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--1. The victory, coupled with Montreal's loss to Boston, increased Detroit's first place lead in the National Hockey League to 3 points.

Traders and employes of the New York Produce Exchange will resume operations today with the same quotation boards, telephone numbers, tables, desks and files they were using when business closed Friday afternoon. But they will be in new quarters in a building up the street.

Arithmetic explains the automobile: Since 1930 motor vehicles have multiplied five times as rapidly as the nation's population. The increase for motor vehicles has been 150 per cent; the population has risen 30 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--HOW big can super tankers get?
ADELE ADDISON, young American soprano, is developing into an artist of distinction. Her recital at Town Hall last night had high purpose and impressive achievement.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams indicated yesterday that he was considering whether to seek a possible death penalty against three accused as members of a Soviet spy ring.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27-- Leaders of the old Congress of Industrial Organizations will press for a showdown this week on jurisdictional fights that have blocked new organizing and disrupted the merged labor movement.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UP)--The New York Rangers scored the game's first three goals and throttled a last-period rally to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--2, in a National Hockey League came tonight.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27--Sometimes one particular dog show gets to be a special favorite for an exhibitor because he almost always fares well in it. Such a favorite was the Maryland Kennel Club's fixture for Carlos L. Henriquez 3d of Yonkers and the latest of them became most successful of all for him tonight.
Two plays about television comedians--one starring Hal March, the other Mickey Rooney --will be televised only ten days apart over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Jerome Robbins' ballet "Age of Anxiety," set to Leonard Bernstein's music that was inspired by W.H. Auden's poem of the same name, was restored to the repertory of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night.
RAFA, Gaza Strip, Jan. 27-- Four Israelis returned today in exchange for 5,850 Egyptian prisoners of war.
The United Corporation realized a gain of $3,285,260 in net assets in 1956, its first year of operations as a registered investment company, according to the annual report mailed over the week-end.
Tugboat workers aboard 390 harbor craft voted unanimously yesterday to strike on Friday.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (UP)--The Boston Bruins scored in the first thirty seconds of play and went on to beat the Montreal National Hockey league game.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 --Am-Par Pictures Corporation, subsidiary of American Broadcasting-Par amount Theatres, Inc., plans to invest $3,000,000 in the production of six pictures to be made within the next six months.
The 1956 winners in the Music Education League competitions made their appearance at Town Hall yesterday afternoon as soloists with Thomas Scherman and the Little Symphony Orchestra Society.

The U.N. General Assembly will be considering this week how to get the Israelis out of the Gaza Strip and off the western shore of the Gulf of Aqaba without applying some kind of force and without restoring the unhappy circumstances which brought them there in the first place.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 27--Art Tokle of the host Odin (N.J.) Ski Club, captured the first New Jersey State ski jumping championship today. He made leaps of 156 and 155 feet for an easy triumph, before a crowd of 19,000.
Although buyers are placing large orders, they are being selective, according to reports last week from resident buying offices.
A pastor who proved he could picket as effectively as he could preach has earned for his church a 300-year-old art masterpiece.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27-- A vigorous campaign aimed at reduction and eventual abolition of the excise tax on new automobiles was promised today on behalf of the National Automobile Dealers Association.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27--The leadership of the merged union movement is expected to call this week for a Congressional investigation on inflation causes.
STOWE, Vt., Jan. 27--Billy Woods, the 18-year-old Waterbury (Vt.) High School senior, of whom much is expected by Olympic-minded Americans, captured the Victor Constant Trophy slalom today.
Glenn Gould, the spectacular young pianist from Canada, chose an unspectacular work for his debut with the PhilharmonicSymphony, which took place
ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, in Antarctica, Jan. 27--Rear Admiral George J. Dufek has revised his decision to withdraw units of the United States Antarctic expedition from the Weddell Sea.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 27 (AP)--With an undisputed twelfth national title within his grasp in his farewell to outdoor speedskating, Ken Bartholomew was knocked out of the meet by an injury today. He had to settle for a firstplace tie with Sob Snyder of Detroit.
ALBANY, Jan. 27--A Republican alternative for Governor Harriman's program for closing the gaps in the state's compulsory automobile insurance law is being developed.

A twenty-two-act revue entitled "Serenade to the White House," a salute to the Presidents since 1890, was the highlight of the First Night Ball and Command Performance held last night in the WaldorfAstoria.

Walter J. Shipman yesterday gained his third consecutive victory without loss in section one of the championship semi-finals at the Manhattan Chess Club. His opponent was Alexander Kevitz, former titleholder, who erred in repelling a Max Lange attack and resigned after eighteen moves.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27-- Scientists at Princeton University and the University of Pennsylvania have reached the final stages of planning for the construction here of a $6,000,000 high-intensity proton accelerator.
A 35-year-old man told a railway policeman yesterday morning that if he had a gun he should kill himself. The policeman assertedly handed the man a pistol, and he thereupon committed suicide.
The Pakistan riots, in protest against India's attempt to attach Kashmir by force and decree and in violation of repeated United Nations resolutions, are the wrong way to go at the problem.

Former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan made recommendations yesterday in a repor to Governor Harriman on improvements in workmen's compensation procedures. He said they would produce large savings.

A one-story masonry building at 73 South Van Brunt Street, Englewood, N.J., has been sold by Steven L. Javna Associates to Irma Mathes of New York. It will be occupied by the Firmat Manufacturing Company, maker of precision machine parts. The George J. Wolf Realty Company of Jersey City was the broker.
Coal was the dominant factor in business last week on the steamship charter market.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 27 --Paul-Henri Spaak predicted tonight that six West European Governments would agree at a meeting Feb. 4 on the terms of an eventually tariff-free common market and an atomic energy pool.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27-- Harold E. Stassen said today he believed the Republicans would have won both Houses of Congress in November if Christian A. Herter, instead of Vice President Richard M. Nixon, had been President Eisenhower's running mate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--Administration supporters were battling today a rising tide of Democratic criticism implying that John Foster Dulles should resign as Secretary of State.
A man with wide experience in the passenger branch of the steamship industry has been appointed manager of the agency department. United States Lines.
Tragedy may shake the faith of some, but it enhances and purifies the, faith of the deeply religious man, the Rev. Charles J. McManus declared yesterday.
The artistic creations of several hundred children were displayed yesterday in the Catholic Youth Organization's ninth annual crafts show.

The arrival of King Saud of Saudi Arabia on an official visit tomorrow is going to provide an interesting problem in America's traditional hospitality.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 27 (AP)--George Yardley, playing with a taped ankle, led the Fort Wayne Pistons to a 103-102 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in overtime today. A crowd of 3,397 watched the National Basketball Association contest.

PALM SPRINGS Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)--The $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament ended in a tie today among Jimmy Demaret, Mike Souchak and Ken Venturi. Souchak holed a 40-foot putt on the eighteenth green to gain his share of the deadlock.
Tennessee Williams' new play, "Orpheus Descending," will open at the Martin Beck Theatre on March 21.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 27-- West German opinion has begun to reassess the Eastern European crisis as a disaster for the cause of Germany's reunification.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27-- There have been reports that Dewey Short of Missouri, who lost his House seat last November, will take a position with the House Republican Campaign Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27-- Duncan Sandys, British Minister of Defense, plunged into talks on global defense policies with Secretary of State Dulles tonight soon after his arrival here on a four-day visit.
The Alabama Building Authority will receive bids Feb. 6 on $4,000,000 of office building revenue bonds maturing serially on Feb. 1 from 1959 to 1986.

TAIZ, Yemen, Jan. 26--The isolated Kingdom of Yemen has opened its shutters to the outside world.

SHIRLEY, L.I., Jan. 27-- Homer Seider's Rebel of the Lake Hopatcong Ice Yacht Club fleet took her second straight open championship of the Eastern Ice Yacht Association today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 27 --The stock market was lively all last week because the Swiss money market was much more liquid, partly owing to the release for balance sheet purposes of cash held by the banks at the year-end.
The United States is planning a pavilion for the 1958 World's Fair in Brussels, Belgium, that will counteract exhibits from Iron Curtain countries.
Although doctors do not yet agree on what causes and what can cure the common cold, there is no shortage of proprietary medicines for its treatment. And there will be more.

Last year industry made increasing use of physically handicapped workers--to the mutual advantage of both. Once-skeptical employers discovered that such employes, when properly trained and placed in the right job, are valuable company assets.

Hungarian refugee students arriving in this country will be able to obtain college scholarships as a result of a concert to be given by the Minneapolis Symphony on the evening of Feb. 17 at Carnegie Hall.
Earnings of the Liggett Myers Tobacco. Company declined slightly last year, despite an $18,001,192 rise in sales.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 --Helene Costello, once a $3,000a-week star of the silent screen; died Saturday night in Patton State Hospital, where she had been committed for narcotics addiction. Her age was 53.
TURN the corner of Fulton Street at Hoyt in Brooklyn and you are in a "museum" right on the street. Abraham Straus devotes its entire window front to telling the story of modern furniture.
The price of world sugar (destined for countries other than the United States) tumbled sharply yesterday with volume heavy on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a sentence imposed upon Frank Costello for Federal income tax evasion was excessive and illegal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 --Alan LeMay has sold movie rights to his novel, "The Unforgiven," in advance of publication to Hecht-Hill-Lancaster. The story, which deals with Indian wars in Texas, will be adapted for the screen by J.P. Miller.
DUBLIN, Jan. 28--Sean MacBride, leader of the Republican party, withdrew today his party's support for Prime Minister John A. Costello's Government.

Frank Gifford, the National Football League's leading yardage gainer last season, signed his 1957 contract with the champion New York Giants yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 28 --The Indonesian Parliament opened today a critical debate that will be carefully followed throughout the 3,000-island archipelago. At stake is the future of the Cabinet of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo.

The twenty-seven member schools of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association are spending $90,000 annually on track and field, according to a survey conducted by Brother Adelbert George, president of the organization.

HOW do theatre people get into these cultural jams? Here is Siobhan McKenna, with St. Joan firmly in her bag, now switching sexes and reciting two hours of Hamlet's part.
TRENTON, Jan. 28--The State Senate adopted and sent to Gov. Robert B. Meyner today a bill designed to finance New Jersey participation in the Federal road program.
TRENTON, Jan. 28--State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. declined today to withdraw from the race for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey.

Pierre Poujade, leader of a weird and demogogic petit bourgeois movement in France, received a sound drubbing in a Paris by-election on Sunday, coming out a poor fourth with 6.4 per cent of the votes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) --The White House rejected today Harold E. Stassen's argument that the presence of Vice President Richard M. Nixon on the G.O.P. ticket last November had cost the party control of Congress.

Insufficient data and mathematical methods are major problems of meteorology, Dr. F.W. Reichelderfer, chief of the United States Weather Bureau, said here yesterday. He was... one of the speakers at the opening session of the fourday, 150th national meeting of the American Meteorological Society. Four hundred persons are expected to attend.
ALBANY, Jan. 28--A bill to give the Legislature power to fill its own vacancies occuring between general elections ran into a serious snag tonight.
The theft of $110,000 in foreign and American money from the Times Square branch of a monetary exchange concern was reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 28--Governor Harriman is planning to recommend a new $4,000,000 state contribution toward the operating cost of New York City's system of colleges.

QATABA, Yemen, Jan. 27--The border conflict between Yemen and Britain's Western Aden Protectorate became quite lively this morning. British mortars pounded a low cactus covered ridge on which a few Yemenis had occupied positions.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28--Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet head of state, hailed a visiting Czechoslovak delegation tonight as the "best, closest and dearest friends." The Czechs demonstrated why they merited that description.
WASHINGTON, JAN. 28--A Government inquiry into reports of jury tampering in the case of Ben Gold, former New York labor leader, backfired in the Supreme Court today.

MANILA, Jan. 28--In an address at the opening session of Philippine Congress today, President Ramon Magsaysay found the state of the nation good.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28-- Britain proposed today an extension and elaboration of the British-United States agreement on joint research and development of guided missiles.
LONDON, Jan. 28--The 8year-old Duke of Cornwall, wearing a cinnamon-colored cap and blazer, went to school today with more than a hundred other boys.
LOBSTER tastes on a hamburger budget? So starts the blurb on the new paperbound edition by Permabooks of "How to Eat Better for Less Money" (294 pp., 35 cents).
Charles Van Doren last night ran his winnings on the National Broadcasting Company's television quiz "Twenty-One" to $122,000. No other quiz-show contest and can make that statement.

The Brussels conference on the proposed European customs union and atomic energy pool revealed that, despite agreement in principle, important details remain to be ironed out. Among these details are the conditions under which the French and Belgian-African territories are to be brought into the customs union.

President Eisenhower's special aviation assistant indicated last night that he would propose the creation of a powerful new agency to direct the growth of the military and civilian air traffic system.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 (AP)-- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that the Sinai Peninsula "should be controlled by United Nations forces until Egypt is prepared to sign a peace treaty or a nonaggression pact with Israel."

Mayor Wagner last night rejected a request of Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, to make public immediately the terms of the offer of the Consolidated Edison Company to take over the city's three subway power plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Secretary of Defense stepped on a political land mine today. Charles E. Wilson accused the National Guard, in effect, of harboring youthful draft dodgers during the Korean conflict.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen heard legal arguments for two and a half hours yesterday on a motion by City Councilman Hugh Quinn to expunge from the court record the recent grand jury report that censured him.

The Chase Manhattan Bank broke ground yesterday for its new sixty-story headquarters building. The rectangular tower with exterior metal columns and metal and glass walls will stand on a "superblock" bounded by Nassau, Liberty, William and Pine Streets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Eisenhower renewed today a public expression of hope that Herbert Hoover Jr. would serve the Government again after he retires Thursday as Under Secretary of State.

Lack of economic incentive, inadequate insurance protection and Government secrecy are the three main roadblocks in the way of rapid development of atomic energy for peaceful uses, according to the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--A four-year-old fight over the right of North American Airlines, Inc., to use the word "American" in its name came back to the Supreme Court today for a second time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28-- President Eisenhower put before Congress today a four-year emergency program for the nation's schools.
Final plans for the $186,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment were filed yesterday with the Housing and Home Finance Agency by the city's committee on slum clearance.

The Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., has received contracts to build three 47,750-deadweight-ton tankers--two for Aristotle Socrates Onassis and one for his father-in-law, Stavros G. Livanos--it was reported yesterday.

Norman H. Strouse, president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, said yesterday that color television was "slowly getting off the ground" and he and his associates explained what the agency has been doing to put commercials in color.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, virtually shut down by a strike throughout most of the first quarter, ended last year with earnings estimated at $3,492,000, equal to 10 cents a common share.
The Esso Shipping Company is adding television for admirers of that medium who work aboard its tankers.
VIENNA, Jan. 28--Unless Congress decides otherwise, the United States will admit 4,000 more Hungarian refugees next month.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--Governor Harriman sent to the Legislature tonight a recommendation that the state's Security Risk Law be extended for another year, but that its application be restricted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28-- Kenton R. Cravens, president of the Mercantile Trust Company of St. Louis, said today that proposed criminal penalties against banks that hire employes from Government agencies were "much too broad" and would be as harmful as the practices they sought to cure.
Without in any way infringing on freedom of the press, the New York State Bar Association has just taken a significant step toward curbing the evil practice of trying cases in the newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28-- President Eisenhower intervened actively today in the drive to elect a Republican Senator from Texas. A.G.O.P. victory there would probably give the party control of the Senate.

Tony DiBiase, young welterweight from the Astoria section of Queens, defeated Chris Christensen of Denmark in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The award in favor of DiBiase at the conclusion of the ten-round encounter was by a split decision.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28--President Eisenhower told the American Road Builders Association today that its convention, opening today, was evidence that the industry could accomplish the huge Federal highway construction program.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 (UP)--Shirley Fry, the 29-yearold United States champion, and Ashley Cooper, a 20-year-old Melbourne player, won the Australian singles tennis titles today.
The Government moved slowly and cautiously yesterday to impanel a special grand jury to hear evidence in the case of three persons charged with spying for the Soviet Union.

The Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, reported in a preliminary unaudited statement yesterday a net income of $65,250,000, equal to $6 a common share, on the 10,878,752 shares outstanding in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) --The Senate Rules Committee voted today $638,565 more to run Senate committees and their investigations this year. This brings the over-all total to $2,353,565.

When the Israeli basketball team meets Yeshiva at Madison Square Garden Sunday afternoon the visitors will be faced with a difficult task--stopping Red Blumenreich, the Mighty Mites' outstanding forward.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 28 (UP)--The Dominican-owned Compania Azucarera Haina agreed today to buy all the properties of the American-owned West Indies Sugar Company in the Dominican Republic for a reported $35,830,000.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28--A book titled "Matching the Hatch" was nominated for formal literary discussion this evening in a meeting of solemn critics gathered for another purpose in the El-Bo Room here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Joint Economic Committee of Congress opened its annual hearings today into the President's economic report.
Mayor Wagner will take personal charge this morning of efforts to settle a tugboat labor dispute that appears headed ford a strike on Friday.

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, voted last night to strike against twenty-six newspaper and magazine wholesalers Friday morning. The vote was taken after contract renewal talks became deadlocked.
VIENNA, Jan. 28--The Hungarian Government, having dealt with workers and writers, is now making a drive against students.
An industrialist who lives in Connecticut boarded a helicopter in Westchester recently to shuttle to a Long Island airport for a quick round-trip to Egypt.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP)--A steady selling drive sent grain prices down for fairly substantial losses on the Board of Trade today.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday appointed Acting Capt. Louis L. Roos, director of the department's legal bureau, as his administrative assistant. Captain Roos will also conduct departmental trials.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Jan. 28 --Four firemen were injured today while fighting a fire that caused a loss estimated at $250,000 in a lumber yard here.

Jacob Marley is dead, to begin with, as anyone familiar with Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" can testify. Less well known is the fact that Marley's ghost made its presence felt yesterday in the Plaza Hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 28--The Senate approved tonight a Reublican bill to stay the expansion of banks through holding companies. The Assembly is slated to act tomorrow.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Jan. 29-- A Government-owned oil tanker being prepared for service as a result of the Middle East crisis was racked by explosions today at the Todd Shipyards here.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Verne D. Mudge, commander of the United States Army's First Cavalry Division in the reconquest of the Philippines in World War II, died today. He was 58 years old.
King Saud of Saudi Arabia received Federal salutes and United Nations tributes when he arrived here yesterday for a state visit.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 (UP)--Stan Musial, the National League's highest-paid player, signed his 1957 contract with the St. Louis Cardinals today for a reported $80,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) --Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, urged Congress today to act "swiftly and without partisanship" to pass President Eisenhower's $2,200,000,000 school aid program.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 29-- Observance of the country-wide general strike of Algerian Moslems was somewhat less extensive today than on its opening day yesterday.
The Rev. Dr. Lewis Joseph Sherrill of 99 Claremont Avenue, Skinner and McAlpin Professor of Practical Theology at the Union Theological Seminary, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home.
Like a nagging child, school problems follow the parents.
A new version of the affair that led to Capt. Alfred Dreyfus' conviction is given in the American edition of Maurice Paleologue's "An Intimate Journal of the Dreyfus Case."
ATHENS, Jan. 29--Spring came early this year to Athens. Already the orange trees beside Parliament are in fruit.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP) For Eternity stumbled in the mud, recovered quickly, and then won today's feature at Santa Anita Park with comparative ease.
King Saud of Saudi Arabia, unlike his late father, King Ibn Saud, takes pot luck when he travels aboard United States vessels on matters of state.
LONDON, Jan. 29--A Laborite's plea for legislation obliging the Government consult Parliament before making war was rebuffed today by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 29--The Ethical Practices Committee, chief guardian of the morals of the united labor movement, has given unanimous approval to what amounts to labor's ten commandments.
Steels rallied yesterday from their sharp 1957 decline, and the market as a whole followed in a moderate recovery.

LESLIE DORSEY is young enough to have a dimple and old enough to appreciate nostalgia. His contemporary interpretations of Victorian decor are being enjoyed by many New Yorkers who dine in restaurants he has designed.

There's no fiercer all-over competition in sports than a college track meet that involves a team title. Since a fifth place often weighs as heavily in the final count as a first, there's always a mad scramble down to the wire for every point-scoring position.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP)--The American League is preparing a castastrophe plan that would enable a club, if disabled by a transportation disaster, to continue with a high-caliber line-up selected from a league player pool.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29 -- Two Lutheran Church officials left Vienna today for Budapest, it was reported here. They are believed to be the first individuals not connected with government to obtain entry visas for that country.
Todd Bolender's ballet, "The Masquers," was presented for the first time by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, with Melissa Hayden and Jacques d'Amboise in its central roles.
As blond and bearded as a Viking, Dr. Hannes Lindemann arrived here yesterday to tell how he had crossed the Atlantic in a seventeen-foot rubber boat.

The campaign to rid the city of the polio menace by the end of next summer entered a new phase yesterday. This phase is the start of a "group inoculation" program by teams of physicians from the city's five county medical societies.
ALBANY, Jan. 29--The State Thruway Authority told Governor Harriman and the Legislature today that the cross-state expressway was in sound financial condition.

Representatives of the Alfred I. du Pont estate of Jacksonville, Fla., have been notified that the deadline on bidding for a long-term lease on 277 Park Avenue has been extended from tomorrow until March 8, according to John L. Rayward.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30--More selling hit wheat futures this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices for the more active months dropped into ground not reached since mid-October.

The New York University basketball team built up a 32point lead at half time and went on to trounce Rutgers, 86--55, at Alumni Gymnasium on the Violets' Bronx campus last night. Tom DeLuca led the winning attack with 23 points.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 30 --Col. Maludin Simbolon, a fugitive since his coup in North Sumatra failed last month, has come out of hiding.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30--The Soviet Union demanded today that two United States assistant military attaches leave the country immediately.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Eisenhower's performance today at his 101st meeting with the reporters suggests that the first hundred news conferences in the White House are the hardest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Following are the texts of the greetings between President Eisenhower and King Saud of Saudi Arabia on the King's arrival at National Airport today:
CAIRO, Jan. 30--The Government of President Gamal Abdal Nasser brought into being today a powerful federation of labor representing 250,000 workers.

Dr. Maud A. Mackey, a retired Presbyterian medical missionary in China who survived the Boxer Rebellion, died Wednesday in Pasadena Calif., after a long illness, Her age was 85. She lived in Pasadena.
The Cities Service Company has placed an order for three 65,000-deadweight-ton tankers in Sweden.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 --Anthony Quinn, one of the busiest actors in Hollywood, will become a director on the musical version of "The Buccaneer."
Connecticut borrowed $29,153,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of educational institutions and other projects. The money

The Continental Oil Company last year had net earnings of about $51,800,000, or $5.30 a share, according to an estimate yesterday by L.F. McCoilum, president. This compares with a net income of $46,400,000, or $4.75 a share, in 1955.
Public hearings in the City Council's investigation of the fitness of Councilman Hugh Quinn to retain his seat will probably start on Feb. 8.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Harriman asked the Legislature today to appropriate $200,000 for research programs and pilot projects aimed at reducing poverty in the state.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan, 30-- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz told car dealers today that this nation was "seriously deficient" in its bombproof storage facilities for fuel oil.
George P. Metesky was indicted yesterday as the so-called "Mad Bomber." Metesky has admitted that for sixteen years he planted explosives in New York.

FOR its full impact, "Siegfried," the third monu mental building block in the edifice of Wagner's "Ring," has special need of a handsome, strong-voiced and yet lyrical tenor and an orchestra that glows and shimmers with poetry.
WELLINGTON, N. J., Jan. 30 --Cosmo Farquhar of 8 Primrose Drive, a code expert, died last night at Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus. His age was 89.
BARBOURVILLE, Ky., Jan. 30 (AP)--The task of digging out from the mud left by flood waters began in southeastern Kentucky tonight even as other communities downstream braced for high levels to come.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday that crime in the nation had reached the proportions of "civil warfare that affects all of us."

Despite the chilly weather, Manhattan College's athletes took a commanding lead toward their eighth consecutive team title in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association championships yesterday.
Boris Romanoff, choreographer, former ballet director of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday of a coronary thrombosis in his home at 850 Seventh Avenue. His age was 65.

Robert Montgomery's television program has purchased rights to a second Broadway stage comedy of two seasons ago. Both will be presented next month.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 30 --Two Opposition leaders announced today their "uncompromising" stand against the proposed re-election of the President. Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, for a four-year term beginning in August, 1958.
GENEVA, Jan. 30--The Soviet Union will be the only largescale exporter of wheat in Europe this year, the Economic Commission for Europe said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--New efforts to speed Senate action on civil rights legislation were rebuffed today by one-sided votes of a Judiciary subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission renewed its opposition today to any curtailment of its powers to fix rates in the transportation field.

The seesaw that Government securities have been riding over the last fortnight makes difficult joggling for the Treasury. It must fix terms for refunding $10,215,000,000 of debt due over the next six weeks.
LONDON, Jan. 30--British trade union leaders are worried about the widening effects of the oil shortage on production and employment.
ANDROS TOWN, Bahamas, B.W.I., Jan. 30--Blue marlin fishing has come to a violent boil in the blue waters of the Tongue of the Ocean after simmering briskly for a couple of weeks.

What is happening in Cuba? Why has the censorship been continued and even strengthened?
Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. The world sugar contract continued active, but most other items were dull and featureless.
DUBLIN, Jan. 30--Eamon de Valera, leader of the opposition, has introduced a motion of no confidence in the Government of Prime Minister John A. Costello. It calls for an immediate general election.

Howard Goldbaum, owner of the Breslin Hotel at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, has added to his realty investments in Manhattan by purchasing a six-story apartment house at 701 West 176th Street, northwest corner of Broadway.
TOMORROW, 4 P.M.: A French-Canadian story on film will be shown at the New York Public Library's Aguilar Branch, 174 East 110th Street, Free.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Sales in United States chemical producers this year are expected to be nearly 6 per cent above the record $24,300,000,000 of 1956, the Department of Commerce said today.

The "jalopy era" will end tomorrow when the state's compulsory car inspection program goes into effect.
THE Princeton seniors sang that verse in their Faculty Song at Nassau Hall on June evenings in homage to the man who knew all about football and even more about Flaubert.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- President Eisenhower defended the National Guard today against a charge that it was a haven for draft dodgers during the Korean war.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 30 (AP)--Police Commissioner Clyde Sellers announced tonight that "seven or eight" white men were in jail in connection with bombings of Negro homes and churches. Another white man has admitted shooting into a racially integrated city bus, he said.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Bills to give public school teachers and state employes substantial pay rises were submitted to the Legislature today by upstate Republicans.

The Yankees yesterday brought down two Bombers with a pair of fountain pens. Gil McDougald, who became Manager Casey Stengel's No. 1 shortstop last summer, and Joe Collins, first baseman-outfielder, dropped around to sign their 1957 contracts.

Sherman Billingsley, owner of the Stork Club, and Al Manuti, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, yesterday traded charges of "double-crosser" in the East Side restaurant's labor difficulties.
A design for what could be the world's most powerful nuclear research accelerator was described here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society.
